THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Randy Wakefield Anderson,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenwood County
Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3730
Heard December 10, 2003 â€“ Filed February 
  2, 2004

REVERSED and REMANDED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, Office of Appellate 
  Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
  Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  William Townes Jones, Greenwood, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: Randy Wakefield Anderson was 
  convicted of murder, armed robbery, and conspiracy to commit armed robbery.Â  
  He appeals, arguing the trial court erred (1) in allowing the admission of hearsay 
  evidence and (2) in admitting statements into evidence which were taken in violation 
  of his Sixth Amendment right to counsel.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS
Around midnight on May 10, 1998, Jamal Manick shot 
  and killed Lamont Rappley in the parking lot of a restaurant.Â  At trial, the 
  State alleged that Appellant conspired with Manick and Fred Ross to rob the 
  victim. Officer Shawn Fisher testified that upon arriving at the scene, he observed 
  the victim lying face down on the pavement with Appellant kneeling beside him. 
  Appellant told Officer Fisher: â€œMy manâ€™s been shot.â€ During this time, Kenneth 
  Williams, a friend of the victim, arrived at the scene. Officer Fisher instructed 
  Appellant to sit in his patrol car while he secured the scene. 
After securing the scene, Officer Fisher 
  returned to his patrol car to speak with Appellant.Â  Anderson explained that 
  he was walking with Williams through the restaurantâ€™s parking lot when a car 
  approached, and a passenger got out, shot the victim, jumped back in the car, 
  and left the scene. According to Appellant, he and Williams then left the scene 
  to call 911. 
Williams, a witness for the State, testified that 
  on the evening of May 10, 1998, the victim asked Williams to accompany him to 
  the restaurant to conduct a drug deal. When they arrived at the restaurant, 
  Williams â€œhung backâ€ as the victim met with Anderson to conduct the deal. Williams 
  stated that about five or ten minutes later, it began raining and he and the 
  victim began to leave the parking lot. As they were walking away, Williams saw 
  headlights and turned around; he then saw a man jump from the car, and shoot 
  the victim. After the shooting, he and Anderson ran to the victimâ€™s house, which 
  was nearby, to call 911. Williams admitted that he initially lied to the police 
  when questioned about the circumstances surrounding the shooting because he 
  â€œdidnâ€™t want it to look like a drug-crime.â€ 
Fred Ross also testified for the State.Â  According 
  to Ross, he was hanging out in an apartment with Manick on the day of the incident. 
  Ross claimed that Appellant arrived at the apartment and told themÂ  â€œthat he 
  had a lick,â€ indicating that the men could rob the victim. Ross testified that 
  later in the evening, he drove Manick to the restaurant where Appellant had 
  set up a drug deal with the victim. Ross stated that as they approached the 
  restaurant, Manick jumped out of the car and shot the victim. On cross-examination, 
  Ross acknowledged that he had a deal with the State allowing him to plead guilty 
  to accessory after the fact of murder and accessory after the fact of armed 
  robbery, charges which carry maximum ten-year prison sentences, in exchange 
  for his testimony. 
Bobby Lukie, who rode with Ross and Manick to the restaurant, 
  also testified that Manick shot the victim. Lukie maintained that he was not 
  involved in planning the robbery and that he merely ran into Ross and Manick 
  at a convenience store that night and decided to accompany them to the restaurant.Â  
  The defenseâ€™s theory of the case, however, was that it was Lukie, not Appellant, 
  who planned the robbery of the victim.
The jury found Appellant guilty of all charges and 
  sentenced him to thirty years for murder, twenty years concurrent for armed 
  robbery, and five years concurrent for conspiracy to commit armed robbery. This 
  appeal follows.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Hearsay
Appellant argues the trial court erred 
  in allowing Lukie to testify regarding statements allegedly made to him by Ross.Â  
  Appellant asserts that this testimony constituted impermissible hearsay.Â  We 
  disagree.
At trial, Lukie testified that around 11:00 p.m. 
  on the night of the murder, he drove by a convenience store and noticed Ross 
  and Manick standing outside the store. Lukie stated that when he asked Ross 
  and Manick what they were doing, Ross told him â€œthey had a lick or something 
  like that.â€ Defense counsel objected, arguing this testimony was hearsay. The 
  State argued the testimony was admissible as non-hearsay because the statement 
  was made in furtherance of the conspiracy.Â Â  The trial court agreed and overruled 
  the defenseâ€™s objection.
Rule 801(d)(2)(E), SCRE, provides thatÂ  
  â€œa statement by a coconspirator of a party during the course and in furtherance 
  of the conspiracyâ€ is not hearsay.Â  See also State v. Gilchrist, 
  342 S.C. 369, 371, 536 S.E.2d 868, 869 (2000) (noting that Rule 801(d)(2)(E) 
  allows for the admission of a coconspiratorâ€™s statement where there is evidence 
  of the conspiracy independent of the statement sought to be admitted). Here, 
  there was evidence presented at trial that Ross and Manick conspired with Appellant 
  to rob and murder the victim.Â  The statements allegedly made to Lukie by Ross 
  were sufficient to allow the jury to reasonably infer that the statements were 
  made in furtherance of the conspiracy, especially in light of the fact that 
  Lukie agreed to accompany Ross and Manick in their robbery of the victim.Â  Accordingly, 
  we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s ruling that the statement was not hearsay.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Sixth Amendment
Appellant also argues the trial court erred 
  in refusing to suppress a statement he made to police on June 16, 1998 because 
  it was taken in violation of his Sixth Amendment right to counsel.Â  We agree.
 At trial, a Jackson v. Denno [1]  hearing was held to determine the admissibility 
  of statements Appellant made to police.Â  Officer Fisher testified that, immediately 
  following the shooting, Appellant agreed to accompany him to the police station, 
  and a gunshot residue test was performed on Appellant. Officer Raczinsky went 
  to Appellantâ€™s home on June 15, 1998 to discuss the positive results of the 
  gunshot residue test. After this discussion, Appellant accompanied Raczinsky 
  to the police station, and following a brief interview, he was arrested for 
  murdering the victim. Raczinsky read Miranda warnings to Anderson and 
  escorted him to jail.Â  
At 11:30 the next morning, Appellant was 
  arraigned for the murder, and he signed a form requesting the services of a 
  public defender. Later that afternoon, Andersonâ€™s aunt visited with him at the 
  police station.Â  Raczinsky testified that after the visit, the aunt â€œsuggested 
  I go talk to [Anderson] again.â€Â  Raczinsky testified that he then went in to 
  talk with Anderson, read to him his Miranda warnings, and asked if â€œanything 
  had changed since the last time [they] talked.â€ Appellant then told Raczinsky 
  that â€œhe was at [the restaurant] in reference to a drug transaction.â€ Appellant 
  explained that he met the victim earlier in the day and had arranged to purchase 
  crack cocaine from him around midnight.Â  Defense counsel objected to the admission 
  of this statement, arguing it was initiated by the police and was made after 
  Appellant had invoked his Sixth Amendment right to counsel.Â  
The Sixth Amendment guarantees that in all criminal 
  prosecutions â€œthe accused shall enjoy the right to . . . have the Assistance 
  of Counsel for his defence.â€Â  U.S. Const. amend. VI.Â  â€œ[O]nce a criminal defendant 
  invokes his Sixth Amendment right to counsel, a subsequent waiver of that rightâ€”even 
  if voluntary, knowing, and intelligent under traditional standardsâ€”is presumed 
  invalid if secured pursuant to police-initiated conversation,â€ and â€œstatements 
  obtained in violation of that rule may not be admitted as substantive evidence 
  in the prosecutionâ€™s case in chief.â€Â  Michigan v. Harvey, 494 U.S. 344, 
  345 (1990) (stating the holding of Michigan v. Jackson, 475 U.S. 625, 
  106 S. Ct. 1404 (1986)). Likewise, the South Carolina Supreme Court has held:

When the Sixth Amendment right to counsel has attached, if 
  police initiate interrogation after a defendantâ€™s assertion, at an arraignment 
  or other similar proceedings, of his right to counsel, any waiver of the defendantâ€™s 
  right to counsel for that police initiated interrogation is invalid unless the 
  defendant initiates the contact himself.

State v. Council, 335 S.C. 1, 15-16, 515 
  S.E.2d 508, 515 (1999).Â  
Here, in ruling that Appellantâ€™s statement was 
  admissible, the trial court first found that Officer Raczinsky â€œwas not restrained 
  in his questioning of [Appellant] by the existence of the document [requesting 
  the services of a public defender] . . . because it was signed at a time different 
  from and a place different from [where Appellant was questioned].â€Â  However, 
  this very issue was considered by the United States Supreme Court in Michigan 
  v. Jackson, 475 U.S. 625, 634 (1986) and was resolved in favor of the defendant 
  because â€œSixth Amendment principles require that we impute the Stateâ€™s knowledge 
  from one state actor to another.â€Â  Thus, the police (one state actor) may not 
  claim to be ignorant of Appellantâ€™s request for counsel at his arraignment before 
  the court (another state actor).Â  Id.
As additional support for admitting Appellantâ€™s 
  statement into evidence, the trial court found that Appellantâ€™s signing of the 
  paperwork for a public defender was not enough to invoke his right to counsel.Â  
  However, pursuant to State v. Council, 335 S.C. 1, 15-16, 515 S.E.2d 
  508, 515 (1999), we believe signing the paperwork requesting a public defender 
  did invoke Appellantâ€™s Sixth Amendment right to counsel.
In Council, the defendant was arraigned 
  on October 14, 1992, and requested the court appoint an attorney to represent 
  him. Id. at 14, 515 S.E.2d at 514. An attorney was appointed to represent 
  the defendant on October 16, 1992, and the defendant made inculpatory statements 
  to the police on October 19, 1992.Â  Id. In discussing the defendantâ€™s 
  claim that the October 19th statements were obtained in violation 
  of his Sixth Amendment right to counsel, the court found as follows: â€œAppellantâ€™s 
  Sixth Amendment right to counsel attached on October 14, 1992, when he was arraigned.Â  
  Further, appellant asserted his right to counsel on October 14, 1992, when he 
  requested appointment of counsel.â€ Id.Â  As in Council, we find 
  that Andersonâ€™s Sixth Amendment right to counsel attached at the time of his 
  arraignment, and he invoked that right by requesting a public defender at 11:30 
  a.m. on June 16, 1998.
Accordingly, we find that Officer Raczinskyâ€™s 
  contact with Appellant violated the protections afforded Appellant under the 
  Sixth Amendment.Â Â  Even if the police re-entered the room at the behest of Appellantâ€™s 
  aunt, Officer Raczinsky admitted that he initiated the conversation with Appellant 
  by asking him if â€œanything had changedâ€ since the last time the two had spoken.Â  
  Thus, the trial court erred in admitting Appellantâ€™s statement about the â€œdrug 
  dealâ€ because it was made after Appellant had invoked his Sixth Amendment right 
  to counsel and was pursuant to a conversation he did not initiate.Â  Therefore, 
  Appellantâ€™s convictions are reversed and the case is remanded for a new trial.Â  

 REVERSED and REMANDED.
HOWARD and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  378 U.S. 368 (1964).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Electro-Lab of Aiken, Inc.,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Sharp Construction Co. of Sumter, Inc.,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Clyde N. Davis, Jr., Special Circuit 
  Court Judge

Opinion No. 3731
Heard December 9, 2003 â€“ Filed February 
  2, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robert J. HarteÂ  and David W. Miller, of Aiken and James D. Mosteller, III, 
  of Barnwell, for Appellant.
Thomas B. Jackson, III, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Electro-Lab of Aiken 
  asserts that Sharp Construction Company breached the partiesâ€™ contract by replacing 
  Electro-Lab with a different subcontractor.Â  The parties became contractually 
  bound, Electro-Lab argues, by virtue of Sharpâ€™s use of Electro-Labâ€™s subcontracting 
  bid in its general contracting bid and by certain acts following the use of 
  the bid.Â  The trial court disagreed, concluding that no contract existed between 
  the parties.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On April 24, 1997, bidding closed for 
  all general contractors on two projects to build schools in York County, South 
  Carolina.Â  Before the bid deadline, Sharp Construction Co., a general contractor, 
  received an oral bid by telephone from Electro-Lab pertaining to one of the 
  school projectsâ€™ electrical work.Â  Electro-Labâ€™s bid amount was $1,150,000.Â  
  Sharp listed Electro-Lab in its overall general contractorâ€™s bid submitted to 
  the projectâ€™s owner.Â  Sharp alleges this inclusion was actually a mistake because 
  it had inadvertently overlooked a lower bid from another electrical subcontractor, 
  Ind-Com Electric Company, Inc. for $1,140,000.Â  However, this oversight was 
  not discovered until after Sharp submitted its general contractorâ€™s bid.Â  At 
  the time Sharp submitted its general contractorâ€™s bid, the only information 
  it had about Electro-Labâ€™s bid was the dollar amount.Â  
Sharp, as the low bidder for the project, 
  was awarded the general contract and was required to provide payment and performance 
  bonds.Â Â  When Electro-Lab contacted Sharp to inquire about the project, Sharp 
  notified Electro-Lab that its bid was the lowest and that it was listed as the 
  electrical subcontractor in Sharpâ€™s successful bid. Sharpâ€™s project manager 
  testified that during this telephone conversation, he told Electro-Lab that 
  he would like to know what its bond rate was and asked Electro-Lab to fax its 
  bid in writing.Â  Shortly thereafter, Sharp discovered that Electro-Labâ€™s subcontract 
  bid was not the lowest bid received, and asked Electro-Lab if it could perform 
  the work for $1,140,000.Â  Electro-Lab agreed, and Sharp submitted the following 
  confirmatory fax:

Dear Michael:
  This letter is to confirm that we will be issuing a subcontract 
  for the electrical work on the above referenced project for $1,140,000.00.
  Please proceed immediately with having shop drawing completed 
  and performance and payment bonds issued.Â  A subcontract is forthcoming.Â  We 
  look forward to working with you.
Sincerely,
SHARP CONSTRUCTION CO.
OF SUMTER, INC. 
HAL TURNER

Following receipt of this letter, Electro-Lab 
  attended a pre-construction conference at Sharpâ€™s request and began gathering 
  submittals for the project from suppliers.Â  Approximately six weeks after bidding 
  closed on the project, Electro-Lab informed Sharp that it had been unable to 
  obtain the required bonds.Â  According to Sharp, during this telephone conversation 
  Electro-Lab requested that its name be withdrawn from further consideration 
  as the electrical subcontractor for the project.Â  Electro-Lab disputes this, 
  maintaining that it never requested to be withdrawn from consideration.
After Electro-Lab informed Sharp that 
  it could not obtain the bonds, Sharp entered into a subcontract for the same 
  dollar amount with Ind-Com, which provided payment and performance bonds as 
  required.Â  By letter, Sharp confirmed that it would be switching to a different 
  electrical subcontractor because of Electro-Labâ€™s inability to obtain bonding.Â  

Electro-Lab did not protest the change until 
  nine months later when it initiated the instant lawsuit, alleging that Sharp 
  breached their contract by switching the subcontract for the projectâ€™s electrical 
  work to Ind-Com.Â  After a full trial on the merits, the trial judge ruled in 
  favor of Sharp, determining that no contract existed between the parties and 
  that Electro-Labâ€™s proof of damages was legally insufficient.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An action for breach of contract is an 
  action at law.Â  Auto Owners Ins. Co. v. Langford, 330 S.C. 578, 581, 
  500 S.E.2d 496, 497 (Ct. App. 1998) (citation omitted).Â  In an action at law, 
  on appeal of a case tried without a jury, the appellate courtâ€™s standard of 
  review extends only to the correction of errors of law.Â  Okatie River, L.L.C. 
  v. Southeastern Site Prep, L.L.C., 353 S.C. 327, 334, 557 S.E.2d 468, 472 
  (Ct. App. 2003) (citation omitted).Â  The trial judgeâ€™s findings of fact will 
  not be disturbed upon appeal unless found to be without evidence which reasonably 
  supports the judgeâ€™s findings.Â  King v. PYA/Monarch, Inc., 317 S.C. 385, 
  388, 453 S.E.2d 885, 888 (1995) (citation omitted).
ISSUES

  1.                 
  Did the trial court err when it found no contract existed between the parties?
  2.                 
  Did the trial court err when it found that Electro-Labâ€™s proof of damages was 
  legally insufficient?

LAW/ANALYSIS
Electro-Lab argues a contract existed 
  between the parties by virtue of the use of Electro-Labâ€™s bid in Sharpâ€™s successful 
  general contracting bid, the partiesâ€™ subsequent communications, and Electro-Labâ€™s 
  attendance at a pre-construction meeting and its gathering of submittals from 
  suppliers.Â Â  We disagree.
â€œA contract is an obligation which arises 
  from actual agreement of the parties manifested by words, oral or written, or 
  by conduct.â€Â  Regions Bank v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 660, 582 S.E.2d 
  432, 439 (Ct. App. 2003) (citations omitted).Â  The necessary elements of a contract 
  are offer, acceptance, and valuable consideration.Â  Carolina Amusement Co. 
  v. Connecticut Natâ€™l Life Ins. Co., 313 S.C. 215, 220, 437 S.E.2d 122, 125 
  (Ct. App. 1993).Â  In this case, there was a valid oral offer to perform electrical 
  subcontract work for $1,150,000 based on the telephone bid received by Sharp 
  before Sharp furnished its general contractorâ€™s bid to the project owner.Â  See 
  id. (quoting Restatement (Second) of Contracts Â§ 24 (1981) (â€œâ€˜An offer 
  is the manifestation of willingness to enter into a bargain, so made as to justify 
  another person in understanding that his assent to that bargain is invited and 
  will conclude it.â€™â€). See also Klose v. Sequoia Union High Sch. Dist., 
  258 P.2d 515, 517 (Cal. Dist. Ct. App. 1953) (â€œA subcontractor bidder merely 
  makes an offer that is converted into a contract by a regularly communicated 
  acceptance conveyed to him by the general contractor.â€).Â  As a result, the issue 
  in this case turns on whether Sharpâ€™s conduct following Electro-Labâ€™s bid amounted 
  to acceptance of Electro-Labâ€™s offer.Â Â Â  
Jurisdictions outside of South Carolina 
  have consistently held that a general contractorâ€™s use of a subcontractorâ€™s 
  bid is not an acceptance that creates a contractual relationship between the 
  general contractor and the subcontractor should the general contractor become 
  the successful bidder.Â  See, e.g., Elec. Constr. & Maint. Co. 
  v. Maeda Pac. Corp., 764 F.2d 619, 621 (9th Cir. 1985); Merritt-Chapman 
  & Scott Corp. v. Gunderson Bros. Engâ€™g Corp., 305 F.2d 659, 663 (9th 
  Cir. 1962); Williams v. Favret, 161 F.2d 822, 824 (5th Cir. 1947); Finney 
  Co. v. Monarch Constr. Co., 670 S.W.2d 857, 859 (Ky. 1984); Holman Erection 
  Co. v. Orville E. Madsen & Sons, Inc., 330 N.W.2d 693, 696 (Minn. 1983); 
  Mitchell v. Siqueiros, 582 P.2d 1074, 1077 (Idaho 1978); Corbin-Dykes 
  Elec. Co. v. Burr, 500 P.2d 632, 634 (Ariz. Ct. App. 1972); K.L. House 
  Constr. Co. v. Watson, 508 P.2d 592, 593 (N.M. 1973); Neptune Gunite 
  Co. v. Monroe Enters., Inc., 40 Cal. Rptr. 367, 371 (Cal. Dist. Ct. App. 
  1964); Milone & Tucci, Inc. v. Bona Fide Builders, Inc., 301 P.2d 
  759, 763 (Wash. 1956).
In accordance with these jurisdictions 
  and based on general contract law principles, we agree that a general contractorâ€™s 
  mere use of a subcontractorâ€™s bid in a general contractorâ€™s successful overall 
  bid does not constitute acceptance of an offer.Â  â€œAcceptance of an offer is 
  a manifestation of assent to the terms thereof made by the offeree in a manner 
  invited or required by the offer.â€Â  Restatement (Second) of Contracts Â§ 50 (1981).Â  
  A typical contract contains mutual promises and is created by an acceptance 
  constituting a return promise by the offeree.Â  See Restatement (Second) 
  of Contracts Â§ 50 cmt. c (1981); Â Sauner v. Pub. Serv. Auth., 354 S.C. 
  397, 405, 581 S.E.2d 161, 166 (2003) (â€œA bilateral contract . . . exists when 
  both parties exchange mutual promises.â€).Â  Moreover, a contract only arises 
  when there is an actual agreement by the parties in which the parties demonstrate 
  a mutual intent to be bound.Â  Timmons v. McCutcheon, 284 S.C. 4, 9-10, 
  324 S.E.2d 319, 322 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  Sharpâ€™s mere use of Electro-Labâ€™s subcontractorâ€™s 
  bid in its overall bid falls short of manifesting any assent to the terms of 
  the bid or the required mutual intent to be bound.Â  As a consequence, no contract 
  existed between the parties by virtue of Sharpâ€™s use of Electro-Labâ€™s bid.
Electro-Lab argues that even 
  if the use of a bid by a general contractor from a subcontractor does not necessarily 
  form a contract, such use is indicative of the formation of a contract between 
  the two companies.Â  Electro-Lab asserts, based on the totality of circumstances, 
  that the culmination of Sharpâ€™s and Electro-Labâ€™s actions formed an enforceable 
  contract.Â  We disagree.Â  Following Sharpâ€™s use of Electro-Labâ€™s bid, Sharpâ€™s 
  project manager testified that he told Electro-Lab that its bid was low, inquired 
  about Electro-Labâ€™s bond rate and asked Electro-Lab to fax its bid in writing.Â  
  This communication falls short of amounting to acceptance of the bid because 
  it does not convey any assent to the terms of the bid by a return promise or 
  any mutual intent to be bound.Â  Such communications were merely preliminary 
  negotiations between the parties and do not amount to an enforceable contact.Â  
  See McLaurin v. Hamer, 165 S.C. 411, 420, 164 S.E. 2, 5 (1932) 
  (stating that there is no meeting of the minds between the parties when they 
  are merely negotiating the terms of an agreement to be entered into).Â  Similarly, 
  Sharpâ€™s discussions with Electro-Lab about performing the work for the $1,140,000 
  were also preliminary negotiations as evidenced by Sharpâ€™s confirmatory fax 
  instructing Electro-Lab that â€œ[a] subcontract is forthcoming.â€ See Caulder 
  v. Knox, 251 S.C. 337, 345, 162 S.E.2d 262, 266 (1968) (â€œThe intention of 
  the parties should be determined from the surrounding circumstances, as well 
  as from the testimony of all witnesses; and subsequent acts are relevant to 
  show whether a contract was intended.â€).Â  See also Bugg v. 
  Bugg, 272 S.C. 122, 125, 249 S.E.2d 505, 507 (1978) (â€œWhere it is determined 
  that the parties intended not to be bound until the written contract is executed, 
  no valid and enforceable obligation will be held to arise.â€).Â  Under the totality 
  of the circumstances, the culmination of Sharpâ€™s actions does not evidence any 
  assent to the terms of the Electro-Labâ€™s bid or a mutual intent to be bound.Â  
  Further, we do not find Electro-Lab, in attending the pre-construction meeting 
  and gathering submittals, established a mutual intent to be bound or any acceptance 
  by Sharp.Â  As a result, we find the conduct of Sharp and Electro-Lab following 
  the bid did not amount to acceptance of Electro-Labâ€™s bid and did not create 
  an enforceable contract. 
Electro-Lab also asserts that principles 
  of mutuality of contract require we find the parties bound in contract.Â  We 
  do not find the principles of mutuality of contract to be invoked under these 
  circumstances.Â  In support of this argument, Electro-Lab relies on Powers 
  Constr. Co. v. Salem Carpets, Inc., 283 S.C. 302, 322 S.E.2d 30 (Ct. App. 
  1984).Â Â  This case noted the doctrine of promissory estoppel could support an 
  action by a contractor who has submitted a prime bid in reliance upon a subcontractorâ€™s 
  bid.Â  Id.Â  at 306, 322 S.E.2d at 33.Â  Electro-Lab argues because, pursuant 
  to Powers, a subcontractor could be liable for damages under the doctrine 
  of promissory estoppel, principles of mutuality of contract require a general 
  contractor to be bound to a subcontract, or in this case, Sharp to be bound 
  to Electro-Lab.Â  Electro-Labâ€™s argument, however, is flawed for two significant 
  reasons.Â  First, the Powers case is premised on the doctrine of promissory 
  estoppel and not breach of contract as asserted by Electro-Lab on appeal.Â  Second, 
  principles of mutuality of contract only arise between parties to a contract.Â  
  Because we find no enforceable contract existed, the principles of mutuality 
  of contract are neither invoked nor violated.
Because we agree with the conclusion 
  of the trial court that no enforceable contract existed between the parties, 
  we need not reach Electro-Labâ€™s argument concerning the sufficiency of damages.Â  
  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 
  613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (ruling that an appellate court need not review 
  remaining issues when disposition of prior issues are dispositive).Â  Accordingly, 
  the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.
HOWARD and KITTRIDGE, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Ted Frame, Claimant/Employee,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Resort Services Incorporated, Employer, and Firemanâ€™s Fund Insurance 
        Company, Carrier,        Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Perry M. Buckner, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3732
Heard January 14, 2004 â€“ Filed February 
  2, 2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Robert W. Achurch, III and Mary Bass Lohr, of Beaufort, for Appellants.
Coleman Hookaylo, Jr., of Hilton Head Island, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  Resort Services Incorporated 
  (RSI), employer, and Firemanâ€™s Fund Insurance Company, carrier, appeal an order 
  by the circuit court which adopted the findings of the Workersâ€™ Compensation 
  Commission and granted Ted Frame, employee, full benefits for mental illness 
  under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act. We reverse and remand.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Ted Frame began his employment with RSI, a commercial 
  laundry business, as a route sales driver in March 1985.Â  After establishing 
  himself as a â€œjack of all tradesâ€ and an â€œexcellent employee,â€ Frame was promoted 
  to route sales manager sometime between 1991 and 1993 and again to production 
  manager in 1997. Â By the time he ended his employment with RSI, a family 
  owned business run by the five sons of founder Jerry Reeves, Frame was known 
  within the company as the sixth Reeves brother, having many of the same responsibilities 
  and ostensibly the authority of a co-owner.
Both Frame and RSI agree 
  that he had a very difficult and stress inducing job throughout his employment 
  with RSI.Â  As a route sales driver, he would often work up to fourteen hours 
  a day, and it was not uncommon to put in sixty to seventy hours a week. Â In 
  both the route sales manager and production manager positions, his responsibilities 
  were increased and the amount of time his job required remained around sixty 
  to seventy-five hours a week, depending on the season, often working weekends. 
  Â Furthermore, his level of job-related stress was aggravated by what 
  he perceived to be managementâ€™s continual incompetence, violations of law (Department 
  of Transportation and environmental regulations), conflicting orders, disregard 
  of proper chain of command, overt racism [1] , and sexual misconduct on the 
  part of some of his five bosses. Â Frame professed that many of the circumstances 
  which eventually led to his heightened level of job-related stress, particularly 
  racist remarks by management, reporting and receiving conflicting orders from 
  multiple bosses and having to rush between several different areas of the business, 
  had been present for about five years before the date he left the employ of 
  the company.
Throughout his fifteen years 
  of employment, especially in the last five years, Frame had feelings of frustration, 
  helplessness and outrage at the practices of his supervisors.Â  He testified 
  to several instances where he fired employees for violations of the companyâ€™s 
  drug and alcohol policy, which he was charged to enforce, only to have the Reeves 
  brothers rehire them a month later.Â  There were occasions when truck maintenance, 
  hauling practices, and the plantâ€™s compliance with environmental regulations 
  were responded to with perceived apathy by the Reeves brothers.Â  Frame believed 
  this rose to the level of a violation of law.Â  His dissatisfaction with his 
  job was exacerbated throughout his employment by feelings that its demands were 
  destroying his family life.
On September 9, 1999, an 
  outside vendor of paper goods arrived at RSI with a delivery. Two boxes of paper 
  towels, damaged during delivery, were deemed below the quality standards of 
  the company and were removed from the bill. The driver of the truck, expressing 
  his intention of throwing the products away, instead gave the products to the 
  employees of RSI. One employee, driver Kevin Moore, an outstanding employee 
  by RSIâ€™s own testimony, took some of the towels home with him at the end of 
  his shift.
Frame arrived to work the 
  following morning to find Michelle Johnson, a purchasing agent for the company 
  and Frameâ€™s subordinate, loudly accusing Moore of being a thief.Â  Frame attempted 
  to explain to Johnson the situation, namely that the paper products were given 
  free of charge from the vendor, but Johnson continued to accuse Moore and seek 
  action from Frame. When Frame became annoyed by Johnsonâ€™s continual finger pointing, 
  he inquired into the cost of the paper towels had the company been charged by 
  the vendor, wrote the company a check for that amount (about thirty-five dollars) 
  and handed it to Johnson.
The Reeves brothers were 
  conducting a family business meeting on the day in question.Â  Johnson, alleged 
  paramour of Michael Reeves, quickly approached him as he left the meeting and 
  told him of the events of the day.  
  [2] Â  Michael Reeves, siding with his alleged girlfriend, sought out Frame 
  and explained to him that it was a violation of company policy to allow an employee 
  to receive free items. According to Frame, Michael Reeves expanded on the policy 
  by adding, â€œ[Kevin Moore] is a thief and liar.Â  [A]ll black people are thieves 
  and liars and . . . youâ€™ve got to watch out for it.â€Â  
Over Frameâ€™s assertions 
  that Moore was innocent of any wrongdoing, Michael Reeves continued to state 
  his position on the alleged towel theft until Frame suffered a complete mental 
  breakdown. In his own words, â€œI think really what topped the notch was with 
  Michelle and the paper products that said that Kevin stole and then Michael 
  told me that blacks were all thieves and liars.Â  I think thatâ€™s what really 
  snapped.â€Â  Frame told his boss to leave Moore alone, placed his pager and phone 
  down, went out to his truck and started crying. Â He never returned to 
  work in his previous capacity.
After expressing to family 
  and friends his breakdown and an onslaught of suicidal tendencies following 
  the above incident, Frame was examined by a psychologist and a psychiatrist.Â  
  The psychiatrist and psychologist agree: (1) that Frame suffers from a bipolar 
  type of psychosis; (2) on the day in question he experienced what is known as 
  a â€œdecompensationâ€ (a mental breakdown); (3) there is a certain genetic predisposition 
  to this kind of psychosis; (4) this â€œdecompensationâ€ was the result of job-related 
  stress; and (5) it was in no way certain that Frame would experience such a 
  mental collapse regardless of exterior stimuli (i.e., his job).Â  According to 
  the psychiatrist and psychologist, Frame is not currently capable of full-time 
  work.
Frame claimed entitlement 
  to benefits under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  A hearing before a single 
  commissioner resulted in an order granting Frame full benefits.Â  The order of 
  the single commissioner reads: 

  1.      
  The Claimant was predisposed to mental illness, although it is unclear whether 
  the predisposition was as a result of genetics or something else.Â  The basis 
  of the predisposition is not relevant.
  2.      
  The Claimantâ€™s work stress was a contributing factor to the decompensation and 
  was the major contributing factor.
  3.      
  Particular stressors in the workplace included:Â  answering to â€œfive bossesâ€; 
  the constant anxiety resulting from escalating pressure associated with being 
  on call.Â  Other examples were trying to cut costs without cooperation, insufficient 
  fire extinguishers to put out fires in the plant, conflict with DOT standards 
  or regulations, lack of cooperation from mechanics and drivers, etc.
. . . .
  2.      
  Under Section 42-1-160, Claimant did sustain a mental injury by repeated stresses, 
  and specific trigger event, arising out of and in the course of his employment 
  within the meaning therein.

RSI appealed the order of 
  the single commissioner to the Full Commission.Â  The Full Commission adopted 
  the order of the single commissioner.Â  The order of the Full Commission states:

In an Appellate Review, 
  the Commission has the power to weigh the evidence as presented at the initial 
  hearing and, after careful review in the instant case, the Commission, by majority 
  vote, has determined that all of the Hearing Commissionerâ€™s Findings of Fact 
  and Rulings of Law are correct as stated.Â  Accordingly, they shall become, and 
  hereby are, the law of the case; and therefore, the Order is sustained in its 
  entirety.

ORDER

The Order of the Single 
  Commissioner filed in the above entitled matter on December 21, 2000, is hereby 
  affirmed by the Panel and same shall constitute the Decision and Order of the 
  Appellate Panel.

On appeal, the circuit court 
  affirmed the findings of the Full Commission.Â  The order of the circuit court 
  provides:

On appeal to the commission 
  tribunal, the law of mental injury on the job, without accompanying physical 
  injury, was extensively debated by both counsel in their briefs and in their 
  argument.
. . . .
The tribunalâ€™s order was 
  based on their detailed knowledge of the facts of this case and their intimate 
  knowledge of the law as relates to mental injury on the job, but said order 
  does not cite such specifics even while upholding the rulings of the single 
  commissioner.
. . . . 
The single commissionerâ€™s 
  opinion noted a specific trigger event for Frameâ€™s mental injury, arising from 
  the facts specified on the date in question, such substantial evidence leading 
  one to reasonably conclude that such facts represent unusual and extraordinary 
  conditions of the employment, notwithstanding any conflicting argument which 
  reasonably could also be made.

STANDARD 
  OF REVIEW
The substantial evidence rule of the Administrative 
  Procedures Act governs the standard of review in a Workersâ€™ Compensation decision.Â  
  Corbin v. Kohler Co., 351 S.C. 613, 571 S.E.2d 92 (Ct. App. 2002);Â  Gray 
  v. Club Group, Ltd., 339 S.C. 173, 528 S.E.2d 435 (Ct. App. 2000); Lake 
  v. Reeder Constr. Co., 330 S.C. 242, 498 S.E.2d 650 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  In 
  an appeal from the Commission, this court may not substitute its judgment for 
  that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, 
  but may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Hamilton 
  v. Bob Bennett Ford, 336 S.C. 72, 518 S.E.2d 599 (Ct. App. 1999); Stephen 
  v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 478 S.E.2d 74 (Ct. App. 1996); S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(d) (Supp. 2001); see also Etheredge v. 
  Monsanto Co., 349 S.C. 451, 562 S.E.2d 679 (Ct. App. 2002) (stating court 
  may reverse or modify Commissionâ€™s decision if substantial rights of appellant 
  have been prejudiced because administrative findings, inferences, conclusions 
  or decisions are affected by other error of law).Â  This courtâ€™s review is limited 
  to deciding whether the Commissionâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial 
  evidence or is controlled by some error of law.Â  See Lark v. Bi-Lo, 
  Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 276 S.E.2d 304 (1981); Gibson v. Spartanburg Sch. 
  Dist. No. 3, 338 S.C. 510, 526 S.E.2d 725 (Ct. App. 2000); see also 
  Lyles v. Quantum Chem. Co. (Emery), 315 S.C. 440, 434 S.E.2d 292 (Ct. 
  App. 1993) (in reviewing decision of Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission, Court 
  of Appeals will not set aside its findings unless they are not supported by 
  substantial evidence or they are controlled by error of law).
Substantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of 
  evidence, nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is 
  evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds 
  to reach the conclusion the administrative agency reached in order to justify 
  its action.Â  Etheredge, 349 S.C. at 456, 562 S.E.2d at 681-82; Broughton 
  v. South of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 520 S.E.2d 634 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The 
  Appellate Panel is the ultimate fact finder in Workersâ€™ Compensation cases and 
  is not bound by the Single Commissionerâ€™s findings of fact.Â  Muir v. C.R. 
  Bard, Inc., 336 S.C. 266, 519 S.E.2d 583 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  The final determination 
  of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to 
  the Appellate Panel.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 535 S.E.2d 
  438 (2000); Parsons v. Georgetown Steel, 318 S.C. 63, 456 S.E.2d 366 
  (1995); Gibson, 338 S.C. at 517, 526 S.E.2d at 729.Â  The findings of 
  an administrative agency are presumed correct and will be set aside only if 
  unsupported by substantial evidence.Â  Anderson v. Baptist Med. Ctr., 
  343 S.C. 487, 541 S.E.2d 526 (2001); Hicks v. Piedmont Cold Storage, Inc., 
  335 S.C. 46, 515 S.E.2d 532 (1999).Â  It is not within our province to reverse 
  findings of the Commission which are supported by substantial evidence.Â  Broughton, 
  336 S.C. at 496, 520 S.E.2d at 637.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Frame asserts that he has 
  suffered an accidental injury within the scope and course of his employment 
  with RSI pursuant to section 42-1-160 of the South Carolina Code, and is entitled 
  to benefits under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act for his mental 
  illness.Â  RSI contends there is no â€œinjuryâ€ as defined by the statute.
Mental injuries are compensable 
  if they are induced either by physical injury or by unusual or extraordinary 
  conditions of employment.Â  Anderson v. Baptist Med. Ctr., 343 S.C. 487, 
  493, 541 S.E.2d 526, 528 (2001); Getsinger v. Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corp., 
  335 S.C. 77, 80, 515 S.E.2d 104, 106 (Ct. App. 1999); Stokes v. First Natâ€™l 
  Bank, 298 S.C. 13, 21, 377 S.E.2d 922, 926 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  A mental-mental 
  injury is a purely mental injury resulting from emotional stimuli.Â  Shealy 
  v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).

Mental or nervous disorders 
  are compensable accidental injuries under the statute when â€œthe emotional stimuli 
  or stressors are incident to or arise from unusual or extraordinary conditions 
  of employment.â€Â  Powell v. Vulcan Materials, Co., 299 S.C. 325, 384 S.E.2d 
  725 (1989).Â  In Powell, this Court held that courts should use the â€œheart 
  attack standardâ€ to determine when a mental-mental injury is compensable.Â  A 
  heart attack suffered by an employee constitutes a compensable accident if it 
  is induced by unexpected strain or overexertion in the performance of his duties 
  of employment, or by unusual and extraordinary conditions in employment.Â  Bridges 
  v. Housing Auth., City of Charleston, 278 S.C. 342, 295 S.E.2d 872 (1982).Â  
  However, if a heart attack results as a consequence of ordinary exertion that 
  is required in performance of employment duties in an ordinary and usual manner, 
  and without any untoward event, it is not compensable as an accident.Â  Fulmer 
  v. South Carolina Elec. & Gas Co., 306 S.C. 34, 410 S.E.2d 25 (Ct. App. 
  1991).Â  According to this Court in Powell, the heart attack standard 
  applies to mental-mental injuries:
  
Mental or nervous disorders 
  resulting from either physical or emotional stimuli are equally compensable 
  provided the emotional stimuli or stressors are incident to or arise from unusual 
  or extraordinary conditions of employment.Â  Powell, 299 S.C. at 327, 
  384 S.E.2d at 726; see also, Stokes v. First Natâ€™l Bank, 306 S.C. 
  46, 410 S.E.2d 248 (1991).
  

Shealy, 341 S.C. 
  at 457, 535 S.E.2d at 443.Â  The requirement of â€œunusual or extraordinary conditions 
  in employmentâ€ for a claimant to recover for a mental-mental injury refers to 
  conditions to the particular job in which the injury occurs, not to conditions 
  of employment in general.Â  Id. at 456, 535 S.E.2d at 442.Â  

In order for [a claimant] 
  to recover workersâ€™ compensation benefits, he must prove both: (1) that he was 
  exposed to unusual and extraordinary conditions in his employment; and (2) that 
  these unusual and extraordinary conditions were the proximate cause of his mental 
  breakdown.Â  See generally Powell, supra; Gambrell v. 
  Burleson, 252 S.C. 98, 165 S.E.2d 622 (1969) (must prove causal connection 
  between injury and subsequent condition in workersâ€™ compensation cases).

Id. at 459, 535 S.E.2d at 444.
We find the Full Commission, 
  as the ultimate fact finder in Workersâ€™ Compensation cases, failed to sufficiently 
  specify its factual findings to the degree required by the amended statute.Â  
  See Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 535 S.E.2d 438 (2000) 
  (holding the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission is the ultimate finder of fact).Â  
  Specifically, by simply adopting the order of the single commissioner, no 
  finding of â€œextraordinary or unusual circumstancesâ€ leading to the injury was 
  articulated.Â  
Frame relies on Powell 
  v. Vulcan Materials Co., 299 S.C. 325, 384 S.E.2d 725 (1989), for the proposition 
  that a work-related altercation could legally amount to an â€œunusual and extraordinaryâ€ 
  condition of employment notwithstanding the lack of any specific stated finding 
  on the issue.Â  Frameâ€™s reading of the case is misguided. 
In 1996, partially in response 
  to Powell, the legislature amended section 42-1-160 of the South Carolina 
  Code to include the following provisions:

Stress arising out of and 
  in the course of employment unaccompanied by physical injury and resulting in 
  mental illness or injury is not a personal injury unless it is established 
  that the stressful employment conditions causing the mental injury were extraordinary 
  and unusual to the normal conditions of the employment.
[A mental injury] is not 
  considered compensable if it results from any event or series of events which 
  is incidental to normal employer/employee relations such asâ€¦ [nonexclusive 
  list]â€¦ except when these actions are taken in an extraordinary and unusual 
  manner.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 
  (Supp. 2002) (emphasis added).
While this amendment 
  maintains the part of Powell that held a purely mental injury compensable 
  under the statute, it adds the requirement, non-existent when the court decided 
  Powell, that the finder of fact make a specific finding that such an 
  injury arose from â€œextraordinary and unusualâ€ circumstances.Â  The circumstances 
  must be â€œextraordinary and unusualâ€ in regard to the particular employment in 
  question and not as applied to some general notion of the average reasonable 
  employment. See Shealy, 341 S.C. at 457, 535 S.E.2d at 443.Â  
Frame argues, per the â€œsubstantial 
  evidenceâ€ rule and this courtâ€™s standard of review, that the record provides 
  a significant number of facts to allow a reasonable person to conclude his injury 
  was a result of unusual and extraordinary conditions.Â  We agree that a reasonable 
  mind could possibly make such a finding based on the evidence of this case.Â  
  The issue here, however, is not whether such conclusion could be reached as 
  an issue of fact, but rather, was such conclusion reached as required by law.Â  

The findings of fact made 
  by the Full Commission must be sufficiently detailed to enable the reviewing 
  court to determine whether the evidence supports the findings.Â  Parsons v. 
  Georgetown Steel, 318 S.C. 63, 66, 456 S.E.2d 366, 368 (1995).Â  The mere 
  mention of a â€œspecific trigger eventâ€ by the single commissioner, later cited 
  by the circuit court as proof that this required finding was made, is not a 
  satisfactory showing that the Full Commission found the conditions on the date 
  of Frameâ€™s decompensation â€œextraordinary and unusual to the normal conditions 
  of the employment.â€Â  Although evidence on record indicates that this may very 
  well have been the case, â€œthe reviewing court may not make findings of fact 
  as to basic issues of liability for compensation, where, to do so, would impose 
  upon the court the function of determining such facts from conflicting evidence.â€Â  
  Fox v. Newberry County Memâ€™l Hosp., 319 S.C. 278, 280, 461 S.E.2d 392, 
  394 (1995).Â  When an administrative agency acts without first making the proper 
  factual findings required by law, the proper procedure is to remand the case 
  and allow the agency the opportunity to make those findings.Â  See id.Â  

CONCLUSION
We reverse the order of 
  the circuit court and remand this case to the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission 
  to make the appropriate findings of fact on the issue of whether the stressful 
  employment conditions causing the mental injury were extraordinary and unusual 
  to the normal conditions of employment of Frame.Â  Accordingly, the case is 
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
GOOLSBY, J. and CURETON, A.J. concur.

 
   
    [1]  Frame, a Caucasian, was often troubled by the dishonorable treatment 
    African-American employees under his charge received from upper management, 
    exacerbated by comments by certain members of the Reeves family.

 
   [2]  Although Frame asserted that the adulterous relationship 
    between Michael Reeves and Michelle Johnson was common knowledge within the 
    company, he offered no proof at the hearing and admitted to never actually 
    witnessing intimate sexual relations.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Ernest J. Smith, Sr.,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Joanne Rucker,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Orangeburg County
Olin  D.Â  Burgdorf, Master-In-Equity

Opinion No.Â  3733
Heard December 9, 2003 â€“ Filed February 2, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Thomas B. Bryant, III, of Orangeburg, for Appellant.
S. Jahue Moore and M. Ronald McMahan, Jr., of West Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: This case asks us to determine whether 
  an estate owned by Ernest Smith and his wife, Joanne Rucker, is subject to partition.Â  
  The case was heard by a master-in-equity, who partitioned the property after 
  finding that the parties owned it as joint tenants with rights of survivorship, 
  a cotenancy subject to partition. Wife appeals, arguing the property is not 
  subject to partition because she and her Husband own the property as tenants 
  in common for life with indestructible survivorship rights.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Husband and Wife married in June 2000.Â  On August 
  17, 2000, Wife deeded Husband a one-half interest in her home and land.Â  The 
  deed contained a granting clause that gave the property to Husband and Wife 
  â€œfor and during their joint lives and upon the death of either of them, then 
  to the survivor of them, his or her heirs and assigns forever in fee simple, 
  together with every contingent remainder and right of reversion.â€Â  The habendum 
  clause used similar language, providing Husband and Wife owned the property, 
  â€œfor and during their joint lives and upon the death of either of them, then 
  to the survivor of them, his or her heirs and assigns whomever lawfully claiming, 
  or to claim the same, or any party thereof.â€ 
Husband filed a complaint in the court of common 
  pleas seeking partition of the subject property, and the case was referred to 
  a master-in-equity.Â  The master granted Husbandâ€™s motion for summary judgment, 
  finding the parties owned the real property at issue as joint tenants with rights 
  of survivorship. As such, the master held the property could be partitioned 
  pursuant to section 15-61-10 of the South Carolina Code. [1] Â  Wife appeals, arguing the parties owned the 
  property as tenants in common for life with indestructible survivorship rights.Â  

LAW/ANALYSIS
The deed at hand unquestionably creates survivorship 
  rights.Â  The crux of this case is whether those survivorship rights are paired 
  with a tenancy in common and therefore indestructible or whether they are paired 
  with a joint tenancy, in which case the property would be subject to partition 
  at the whim of either party.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-7-40 (Supp. 2002); 
  Davis v. Davis, 223 S.C. 182, 75 S.E.2d 46 (1953).Â  We find that the 
  deed created a joint tenancy with rights of survivorship and affirm the masterâ€™s 
  decision to partition the property.
Section 27-7-40 of the South Carolina Code provides 
  that a joint tenancy with rights of survivorship is conclusively established 
  when a deed grants land to two or more persons â€œas joint tenants with rights 
  of survivorship, and not as tenants in common.â€Â  However, this language is not 
  the only means by which joint tenancies are created, but rather is â€œ[i]n addition 
  to any other methods for the creation of a joint tenancy in real estate which 
  may exist by law . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-7-40 (Supp. 2002).
The common law method of creating a joint tenancy 
  requires a conveyance to have four unities: unity of interest, unity of title, 
  unity of time, and unity of possession.Â  Jenkins v. Jenkins, 8 S.C.L. 
  (1 Mill) 48 (1817).Â Â Â Â Â  When a joint tenancy is coupled with a right of survivorship, 
  the right of survivorship can, under certain circumstances, be destroyed by 
  one party acting alone.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-7-40 (Supp. 2002).Â  
  Because survivorship rights often encumber land, our courts require clear, unambiguous, 
  and express language to create a joint tenancy with rights of survivorship and 
  will construe instruments in favor of tenancies in common whenever possible.Â  
  Herbemont v. Thomas, Chev.Eq. 21 (S.C. 1839).Â  The reason South Carolina 
  courts favor tenancies in common over joint tenancies is due to â€œthe harsh results 
  of survivorship rights incident to joint tenanc[ies] [which] usually defeated 
  the intention of the grantor.â€ 6 S.C. Jur. Cotenancies Â§ 18 (1991).Â Â  
  We do not believe this general rule favoring tenancies in common is applicable 
  to cases involving deeds that unequivocally grant rights of survivorship because 
  construing a deed to convey a tenancy in common with a right of survivorship 
  would result in finding an estate that has indestructible survivorship rights 
  and would thereby render the land less rather than more marketable.Â  See, 
  e.g., Harold W. Jacobs, Cotenancies, Estates of in South Carolina, 
  11 S.C.L.Q. 520, 523 (1958) (explaining that South Carolina courts favor estates 
  that do not have harsh survivorship rules).Â  
Although the deed in the instant case does not 
  contain the language suggested by section 27-7-40, it does satisfy the four 
  unities required to create a joint tenancy: both Husband and Wife have the same 
  interest, created by the same conveyance, which commenced at the same time, 
  and they hold the property in undivided possession.Â  Furthermore, the deed clearly 
  and unambiguously grants the right of survivorship, a distinguishing characteristic 
  of joint tenancies. 6 S.C. Jur. Cotenancies Â§ 17 (1991) (â€œThe distinguishing 
  characteristic of joint estates is survivorship.â€).Â  Thus, we find the language 
  of the deed unambiguously created a joint tenancy with rights of survivorship.Â  
  See Lake View Acres Development Co. v. Tindal, 306 S.C. 477, 479, 
  412 S.E.2d 457, 458 (Ct. App. 1991) (â€œThe main object in construing a deed is 
  to ascertain the intention of the grantor from the language used in the deed.â€). 
  [2] 
In support of her position that the property is not 
  subject to partition, Wife relies on Davis v. Davis, 223 S.C. 182, 75 
  S.E.2d 46 (1953), in which our supreme court recognized indestructible survivorship 
  rights attaching to a tenancy in common.Â  However, in that case, the court was 
  called upon to determine what quantum of estate was created by a deed that purported 
  to create a tenancy by the entirety [3]  after such estates were no longer recognized in South Carolina. 
  [4] Â  Here, the deed did not purport to create a tenancy by the entirety.Â  
  Instead, as explained above, Wifeâ€™s deed created a joint tenancy by satisfying 
  the four unities required under common law and by unambiguously creating a right 
  of survivorship.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the language of the deed and South Carolinaâ€™s 
  penchant for construing deeds in favor of marketability, we find Wifeâ€™s deed 
  created a joint tenancy with rights of survivorship.Â  As a joint tenancy, the 
  property is subject to partition pursuant to section 15-61-10 of the South Carolina 
  Code.Â  Accordingly, the masterâ€™s decision to partition the property isÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â   
AFFIRMED.
HOWARD and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Section 15-61-10 states: â€œAll joint tenants and tenants in common 
    who hold, jointly or in common, for a term of life or years or of whom one 
    has an estate for a term of life or years with the other that has an estate 
    of inheritance or freehold in any land, tenements or hereditaments shall be 
    compelled to make severance and partition of all such lands, tenements and 
    hereditaments.â€

 
   
     
    [2]   When the language in a deed is ambiguous, extrinsic evidence 
    is admissible to aid the court in determining the grantorâ€™s intentions.Â  See 
    Bellamy v. Bellamy, 292 S.C. 107, 111, 355 S.E.2d 1, 3 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  
    Here, extrinsic evidence was unnecessary because we find the language of the 
    deed sufficiently clear to create a joint tenancy with rights of survivorship. 
    Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

 
   
    [3]   Tenancies by the entirety, which were premised on the 
    common law fiction that a man and woman merged into one person upon marriage, 
    were recognized as valid estates in South Carolina until 1907.Â  Green v. 
    Cannady, 77 S.C. 193, 57 S.E. 832 (1907).Â  Because of the â€œunity of personâ€ 
    notion, property conveyed to spouses was automatically deemed a tenancy by 
    the entirety, and as such, neither Husband nor Wife could convey or alienate 
    the property without the otherâ€™s permission and the surviving spouse was entitled 
    to the entire estate upon the otherâ€™s death.Â  In Green v. Cannady, 
    the supreme court abolished tenancies by the entirety, finding that the Married 
    Womanâ€™s Separate Property Acts and the state constitutions of 1868 and 1895 
    effectively destroyed the fiction that, upon marriage, a couple merged into 
    one, unified person.Â  Instead, the Green court held that property titled 
    to both Husband and Wife created a tenancy in common.Â  Id. at 197, 
    57 S.E. at 834.

 
   
    [4]   When called upon to determine what quantum of estate the 
    deed actually created, the Davis court held that a tenancy in common 
    with indestructible survivorship rights was created either because the cotenants 
    had â€œ(1) a tenancy in common for life with a contingent remainder in favor 
    of the survivorâ€ or â€œ(2) a tenancy in common in fee simple with an executory 
    limitation in favor of the survivor.â€ Davis v. Davis, 223 S.C. 182, 
    192, 75 S.E.2d 46, 50 (1953).Â  In reaching its decision, the court â€œapproached 
    the question . . . by first undertaking to ascertain the intention of the 
    parties . . . .â€Â  Id. at 185, 75 S.E.2d at 47.In doing this, the court 
    found that the purported creation of a tenancy by the entirety â€œ[threw] some 
    light on the intention to create an indestructible right of survivorshipâ€ 
    and that â€œby adding the phrase â€˜and the survivor of them,â€™ the parties . . 
    . clearly indicated the nature of the estate intended to be created, namely 
    that upon the death of either of the grantees the absolute estate should vest 
    in the survivor.â€Â  Id. at 191-192, 75 S.E.2d at 50.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
South Carolina Department of Social Services,       
Plaintiff,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Carolina Ledford, James P. Berlin, and Leigha Berlin, DOB 02/02/93,       
Defendants.
Of Whom South Carolina Department of Social Services is,       
Respondent,
And, James P. Berlin is,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Peter R. Nuessle, Family Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  3734Â Â Â 
Heard December 9, 2003 â€“ Filed February 2, 2004 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Ziva Peleg Bruckner, of Augusta, 
  for Appellant.
Dennis M. Gmerek, of Aiken, for Respondent.
Lark W. Jones, of N. Augusta, for Guardian Ad Litem
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: The South Carolina Department 
  of Social Services (DSS) brought this termination of parental rights (TPR) action 
  against Carolina Ledford (Mother) and James Berlin (Father).Â  The family court 
  terminated the parental rights of both parties, and Father appeals.
FACTS
In 1993, the partiesâ€™ daughter, Leigha, was born.Â  Three 
  years later, Father was convicted of first-degree forgery and incarcerated in 
  Georgia.Â  Shortly thereafter, Father was paroled, and he received permission 
  to work in South Carolina.Â  At some point during 1998, that permission was revoked, 
  and Father knew that if he continued to work outside the State of Georgia, he 
  would be in violation of his parole.Â  Despite this knowledge, Father continued 
  working in South Carolina, and he was incarcerated for violating his parole.Â  
  While Father was in prison, he and Mother divorced.Â  
Once divorced, Father lost contact with both Mother 
  and Leigha. In 1999, Leigha was taken into emergency protective custody after 
  Mother left her with friends in Hilton Head, supposedly for a day, and did not 
  return after two weeks. Mother had a serious drug problem, and her whereabouts 
  were unknown at the time of the TPR hearing. 
At the hearing, Father testified that during the time 
  he and Mother were together, she did not have a drug problem and was a good 
  mother.Â  He further testified that he was very active in his daughterâ€™s life, 
  though he offered very few details.Â  
Father admitted that while he was in prison, he attempted 
  to contact Leigha on only two occasions.Â  According to his testimony, his first 
  attempt occurred when he asked prison officials to help him locate his daughter.Â  
  When they did not help him, Father became frustrated and did nothing else.Â  
  His second attempt occurred when he sent Leigha a birthday card by way of her 
  older half-sister, [1]  but the 
  card was returned as undeliverable.Â  According to Fatherâ€™s own testimony, no 
  other attempts were made to contact his daughter.
DSS attempted to locate Father, but the only information 
  it received from Mother was that he was incarcerated in Georgia.Â  When asked 
  if he did anything to aid in DSSâ€™s search for him, Father stated:Â  â€œI remained 
  breathing oxygen.â€Â  Eventually, a caseworker found him through the Internet 
  listings of the Georgia Department of Corrections, and in January of 2001, he 
  was served with a summons and complaint to terminate his parental rights.Â  
Even after learning of the TPR, Father failed to establish 
  any contact with the caseworker or DSS.Â  The caseworker testified that Father 
  knew or should have known how to contact her or DSS from the time he received 
  the summons and complaint in January of 2001.Â  Father also made no attempt to 
  contact the guardian for the minor child until after he was released from prison, 
  about one week prior to the TPR hearing.Â  
DSS sought to terminate Fatherâ€™s parental rights on 
  the grounds that he abandoned his daughter, he willfully failed to visit within 
  the previous six months, and he willfully failed to provide support during the 
  previous six months.Â  Father denied the allegations.Â  
The family court found that Father abandoned his daughter 
  and that TPR was in the childâ€™s best interest.Â  In making this finding, the 
  family court explicitly stated that Fatherâ€™s testimony was without credibility 
  and was completely self-serving.Â  Father appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œA ground for termination of parental rights must be 
  proved by clear and convincing evidence.â€Â  Richland County Depâ€™t of Soc. 
  Servs. v. Earles, 330 S.C. 24, 32, 496 S.E.2d 864, 868 (1998) (citing Greenville 
  County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Bowes, 313 S.C. 188, 437 S.E.2d 107 (1993)).Â  
  â€œIn reviewing a termination of parental rights, the appellate court has the 
  authority to review the record and make its own findings of whether clear and 
  convincing evidence supports the termination.â€Â  Earles, 330 S.C. at 24, 
  496 S.E.2d at 868 (citing S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Brown, 317 S.C. 
  332, 454 S.E.2d 335 (Ct. App. 1995)).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Father maintains the family court erred both 
  in finding that he had abandoned daughter and in finding that termination of 
  his parental rights would serve her best interests.Â  We disagree.
Pursuant to section 20-7-1572(7) of the South 
  Carolina Code, the court can terminate the rights of a parent who abandons his 
  or her child if termination of those rights is in the childâ€™s best interest.Â Â  
  Abandonment occurs when â€œa parent or guardian willfully deserts a child or willfully 
  surrenders physical possession of a child without making adequate arrangements 
  for the childâ€™s needs or the continuing care of the child.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 20-7-490(19) (Supp. 2002).Â  
Willfulness is â€œa question of intent 
  to be determined by the facts and circumstances of each case.â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t 
  of Soc. Servs. v. Wilson, 344 S.C. 332, 336, 543 S.E.2d 580, 582 (Ct. App. 
  2001) (citing S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Broome, 307 S.C. 48, 52, 413 
  S.E.2d 835, 838 (1992)).Â  â€œOur supreme court has defined willfulness as â€˜[c]onduct 
  of the parent which evinces a settled purpose to forego parental duties . . 
  . because it manifests a conscious indifference to the rights of the child to 
  receive support and consortium from the parent.â€™â€Â  Id. (quoting Broome, 
  307 S.C. at 53, 413 S.E.2d at 839).Â  â€œGenerally, the family court is given wide 
  discretion in making this determination.Â  However, the element of willfulness 
  must be established by clear and convincing evidence.â€Â  Id.
Father argues that the only evidence of 
  abandonment was his incarceration and that incarceration alone is insufficient 
  to terminate his parental rights.Â  We agree that pursuant to South Carolina 
  Department of Social Services v. Wilson, incarceration alone is insufficient 
  to justify termination.Â  However, in Wilson, the incarcerated father 
  made extensive efforts to maintain contact with his children, but DSS prevented 
  the visitation.Â  The Wilson court held: â€œThe record contains overwhelming 
  evidence that SCDSS not only refused to facilitate visitation, it actually took 
  an active role in preventing the father from visiting his children.Â  Despite 
  the fatherâ€™s repeated requests, the caseworkers refused to allow visitation 
  both at the correctional facility and after the review hearings.â€Â  344 S.C. 
  at 338, 543 S.E.2d at 583.
 In the instant case, aside from unsuccessfully 
  sending Leigha a birthday card via her older half-sister, Father admitted he 
  only attempted to locate his daughter one time and that his effort to find her 
  ended when prison officials were unhelpful.Â Â Â  Even after learning Leigha was 
  in DSSâ€™s custody, Father made no attempt to inquire about her health and wellbeing.Â  
  Father neither made arrangements for his childâ€™s care nor showed concern for 
  the status of her current arrangements.Â  Unlike the father in Wilson, 
  Father made only a miniscule attempt to remain a part of his daughterâ€™s life 
  while in prison.Â Â Â  In addition to â€œbreathing oxygen,â€ Father was required to 
  take the necessary steps to assure that his daughter was being continually cared 
  for, and because he failed to do this, we find he effectively abandoned her.Â  
  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-490(19) (defining abandonment as the willful 
  surrender of a child by a parent without making adequate arrangements for the 
  childâ€™s continuing care). 
Father asserts that he did not abandon 
  his daughter because he left her in Motherâ€™s care when he was initially incarcerated.Â  
  However, based on the language of section 20-7-490(19), a parentâ€™s responsibility 
  extends beyond making initial arrangements for his or her child while the parent 
  is away; the statute requires that the parent make adequate arrangements for 
  the childâ€™s continuing care. Thus, even if we believe Fatherâ€™s testimony 
  that Mother had been a qualified caregiver at the time of his incarceration, 
  [2]  he had an ongoing responsibility to make efforts to ensure that his 
  daughter was continually cared for while he was serving his sentence.Â  Because 
  Father willfully failed to either inquire about his daughter or verify that 
  Mother was indeed taking care of her, we find no error in the family courtâ€™s 
  determination that Father abandoned his child.Â  Furthermore, based on the lack 
  of recent contact between Father and Leigha, the guardian ad litemâ€™s testimony 
  that termination is in Leighaâ€™s best interest, and the foster motherâ€™s testimony 
  about Leighaâ€™s current living situation, we agree with the family court that 
  termination of Fatherâ€™s parental rights is in Leighaâ€™s best interest.
 Father next argues that the family court 
  judgeâ€™s questions of him displayed bias.Â  After having been examined and cross-examined 
  by his attorney and the attorney for DSS, Father then fielded over thirty questions 
  from the family court judge.Â  While we believe this questioning was certainly 
  excessive and unnecessarily harsh, we find that, ultimately, it did not adversely 
  affect the outcome of the proceedings.
In Fowler v. Laney Tank Lines, Inc., 
  263 S.C. 422, 211 S.E.2d 231 (1975), the court reiterated â€œthe sound and long 
  established rule that â€˜the trial judge, of course, has the right, in his discretion, 
  and in a proper manner, to question witnesses during a trial, in order to elicit 
  the truth.â€™â€Â  Id. at 425, 211 at 232 (quoting Williams v. S.C. Farm 
  Bureau Mut. Ins. Co., 251 S.C. 464, 163 S.E.2d 212 (1968)).Â  The foremost 
  danger in a judge asking a witness questions is that the nature of the questioning 
  might indicate to the jury how the judge feels about a particular witnessâ€™s 
  testimony or how the case itself should be resolved.Â  See, e.g., 
  Williams v. S.C. Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co., 251 S.C. 464, 472, 163 S.E.2d 
  212, 216 (1968) (â€œIf a trial judge in the exercise of his discretion feels called 
  upon . . . to question witnesses to elicit the truth, he should be cautious 
  to see that such questions are propounded in a fair and impartial manner, and 
  should not express or indicate to the jury the judgeâ€™s opinion . . . .â€).Â Â Â  

In this case, the family court judge questioned Father 
  at length about his incarceration and whether he accepted any responsibility 
  for his daughter being in foster care.Â  The judge repeated many questions even 
  after receiving answers from Father.Â  Although we believe the form of the judgeâ€™s 
  questions was adversarial and the number of questions was excessive, we also 
  acknowledge that the family court judge was the fact-finder at this hearing; 
  thus, the â€œforemost dangerâ€ of judicial questioning, i.e., tainting the jury, 
  is not present in this case.Â  Moreover, we find ample evidence in the trial 
  record to support the family court judgeâ€™s decision to terminate Fatherâ€™s rights.Â  
  Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED.
HOWARD and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  Leighaâ€™s half-sister is Motherâ€™s daughter from 
    a previous relationship.

 
   
    [2]  The family court judge discounted Fatherâ€™s testimony regarding whether 
    Mother was a qualified caregiver at the time of Fatherâ€™s incarceration.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Alvin Simuel,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Henry F. Floyd, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  3735
Submitted December 8, 2003 â€“ Filed February 
  2, 2004 

REVERSED and REMANDED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia; 
  for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Assistant Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin, of Columbia; Solicitor Warren 
  Blair Giese, of Columbia; for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â Â Â Â  Alvin 
  Simuel was convicted and sentenced to thirty months imprisonment for escaping 
  from the Kirkland Correctional Center.Â  He appeals, asserting the trial judge 
  erred in sentencing him to an enhanced penalty when the enhancement element 
  was neither charged in the indictment nor submitted to the jury.Â  We reverse 
  and remand.
FACTS
While serving a fifteen-year 
  sentence for armed robbery, Simuel escaped from the Kirkland Correctional Center 
  in January 1976.Â  In 1999, he was apprehended by authorities in Massachusetts.Â  
  After extradition to South Carolina, Simuel was indicted for escape.Â  The body 
  of the indictment read:Â  â€œThat Alvin Simuel did in Richland County on or about 
  January 25, 1976, unlawfully escape or attempt to escape from lawful confinement 
  or custody, to wit:Â  escape while serving time for armed robbery at the Kirkland 
  Correctional Center on 4344 Broad River Road.â€Â  
The statutory section in effect in January 
  1976 regarding escape read, in relevant part, as follows: 

It shall be unlawful for any person, being lawfully confined 
  in any prison . . . to escape . . . and any person so doing . . . shall be guilty 
  of a misdemeanor and punished by a sentence of not less than six months nor 
  more than two years, such sentence to be consecutive to the original sentence 
  and to any other sentences theretofore imposed upon such escapee by any court 
  of this State . . . . Provided however, that should 
  the escapee be recaptured elsewhere than in this State the sentence to be imposed 
  in addition to any remaining unserved portion of the original sentence shall 
  be not less than one year nor more than three years, such sentence to be 
  consecutive to any other sentences theretofore imposed upon such escapee by 
  any court of this State.Â  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 55-6 (1962 & Supp. 1975) (italics in 
  original, emphasis added). [1] 
During sentencing, defense counsel objected, 
  arguing the indictment did not specify Simuel was taken into custody outside 
  of South Carolina. [2] Â  Counsel 
  argued the trial court could not sentence him to an enhanced penalty because 
  the indictment failed to allege this element.Â  The trial judge denied Simuelâ€™s 
  motion, stating: â€œEnhancement of penalty is not an element of the crime.â€Â  Simuel 
  was sentenced to thirty months imprisonment, to be served consecutively with 
  Simuelâ€™s underlying sentence of fifteen years for armed robbery.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Simuel argues the trial court erred in 
  sentencing him to an enhanced penalty when the enhancement element of being 
  apprehended in another state was not charged in the indictment or submitted 
  to the jury.Â  We agree.
The United States Supreme Court addressed the issue of sentence enhancement 
  in Apprendi v. New Jersey, 530 U.S. 466 (2000).Â  In Apprendi, 
  the defendant fired several shots into the home of an African-American family.Â  
  The defendant was indicted on a weapons charge, but not under the hate crime 
  statute, which provided for an enhanced sentence.Â  After pleading guilty, the 
  trial judge granted the Stateâ€™s motion to enhance the defendantâ€™s sentence under 
  the hate crime statute.Â  The Supreme Court reversed, holding:Â  â€œOther than the 
  fact of a prior conviction, any fact that increases the penalty for a crime 
  beyond the prescribed statutory maximum must be submitted to a jury, and proved 
  beyond a reasonable doubt.â€  [3] Â  Id. at 490.Â  The Court noted the Fourteenth 
  Amendment â€œcommands the same answerâ€ in cases concerning state statutes.Â  Id. 
  at 476. 
In the instant case, Simuelâ€™s indictment 
  did not mention the sentence enhancement incurred when an escapee is recaptured 
  outside the state of South Carolina.Â  Nor did Simuelâ€™s indictment allege that 
  he was recaptured in Massachusetts.Â  Additionally, the enhancement provision 
  of section 24-13-410 was not submitted to the jury.Â  As such, under the holding 
  of Apprendi, the trial judge erred in enhancing Simuelâ€™s sentence in 
  excess of the maximum two-year sentence provided for by section 24-13-410.Â Â Â Â Â  

CONCLUSION
Because Simuelâ€™s 
  enhanced thirty-month sentence for escape violated the holding in Apprendi, 
  we reverse and remand for sentencing consistent with our holding in this case.
 REVERSED and REMANDED.
 HOWARD and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  The current statutory section is S.C. Code Ann. 
    Â§ 24-13-410 (1976 & Supp. 2002).

 
   
    [2]  Further, the jury instructions did not include any mention of a statutory 
    sentence enhancement provision.Â  

 
   [3]  We note the Fourth Circuit has found that Apprendi 
    is not implicated when the trial judge makes factual findings increasing the 
    sentencing range; however, such analysis is not applicable here, as the trial 
    judge did not make factual findings.Â  See United States v. Photogrammetric 
    Data Servs., 259 F.3d 229, 257-59 (4th Cir. 2001); United States v. 
    Kinter, 235 F.3d 192, 199-202 (4th Cir. 2000).
