THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The
State,        Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Michael Laquincy
Higgins,        Appellant. 
      
    
  


Appeal From Laurens County
Honorable James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit 
  Court Judge

Opinion No. 3736
Heard December 10, 2003 â€“ Filed February 
  2, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of S.C. Office 
  of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, 
  Assistant Attorney General Deborah R.J. Shupe, of Columbia; and Solicitor W. 
  Townes Jones, IV, of Greenwood, for Respondent.
      
    
  

 HEARN, C.J.:Â  During the 
  sentencing phase of his guilty plea, Michael Higgins asked the trial court to 
  be credited for time served while he was released on bond but placed on house 
  arrest.Â  The trial court denied this request, and Higgins appeals.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Higgins was arrested and indicted for accessory 
  after the fact to murder.Â  He was released on a $50,000 bond, which contained 
  the following conditions:Â Â  

[N]o contact with the victim or the victimâ€™s family in any 
  manner either directly or indirectly; The Defendant must remain on House Arrest 
  and reside with his grandmother [in] â€¦ Laurens, South Carolina and may not leave 
  the residence except for medical appointments or treatment, consultations with 
  his attorney, or for employment reasons.

Higgins remained under house 
  arrest from the date of his release, July 24, 2001, until August 13, 2002.Â  
  There is no evidence that Higgins violated the conditions imposed in the release 
  order.Â  On August 13, Higgins entered a negotiated Alford 
  [1]  plea to misprision of a felony, a lesser included offense of accessory 
  after the fact to murder.Â  
During sentencing, defense counsel argued 
  that Higgins should be given credit for time served on house arrest.Â  The trial 
  court disagreed, and held that credit would only be given for the seven months 
  and eleven days Higgins actually spent in jail.
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, Higgins contends that under 
  section 24-13-40 of the South Carolina Code (1989 & Supp. 2002), the applicable 
  sentencing statute, he was entitled to receive credit for the time he spent 
  under house arrest prior to sentencing.Â  Section 24-13-40 provides, in pertinent 
  part:

In every case in computing the time served by a prisoner, 
  full credit against the sentence shall be given for time served prior to trial 
  and sentencing.Â  Provided, however, that credit for time served prior 
  to trial and sentencing shall not be given: (1) when the prisoner at the time 
  he was imprisoned prior to trial was an escapee from another penal institution; 
  or (2) when the prisoner is serving a sentence for one offense and is awaiting 
  trial and sentence for a second offense in which case he shall not receive credit 
  for time served prior to trial in reduction of his sentence for the second offense.Â  


(emphasis in original).Â  In support of his argument, Higgins 
  asserts that because house arrest is not specifically excluded by the statute, 
  the legislature intended to give credit for the time a defendant serves on house 
  arrest.Â  We disagree. 
Our supreme court has defined â€œtime served,â€ 
  as it is used in section 24-13-40, as â€œthe time during which a defendant is 
  in pre-trial confinement and charged with the offense for which he is 
  sentenced (so long as he is not serving time for a prior conviction).â€Â  Blakeney 
  v. State, 339 S.C. 86, 88, 529 S.E.2d 9, 10-11 (2000) (emphasis in original).Â  
  However, whether time served includes time spent under house arrest is an issue 
  of first impression in South Carolina.Â  Generally, penal statutes are to be 
  construed â€œstrictly against the State and in favor of the defendant.â€Â  Williams 
  v. State, 306 S.C. 89, 91, 410 S.E.2d 563, 564 (1991) (citation omitted).Â  
  â€œFurthermore, in construing a statute, words must be given their plain and ordinary 
  meaning without resort to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the 
  statuteâ€™s operation.â€Â  State v. Leopard, 349 S.C. 467, 471, 563 S.E.2d 
  342, 344 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  However, â€œâ€˜[a]ll rules of statutory construction 
  are subservient to the one that the legislative intent must prevail if it can 
  be reasonably discovered in the language used, and that language must be construed 
  in the light of the intended purpose of the statute.â€™â€Â  Id. (citations 
  omitted).Â  
Initially, we find it important to note 
  that Higgins was placed on house arrest as a condition of his release 
  on bond.Â  Any person charged with a noncapital offense may, in the courtâ€™s discretion, 
  be released pending trial.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-15-10 (2003).Â  The court may 
  impose certain â€œconditions of release,â€ including, but not limited to, requiring 
  an appearance bond, placing the person in the custody of another, or other conditions 
  reasonably necessary to assure appearance as required.Â Â  Id.Â Â  Because 
  Higgins was on house arrest as a condition of his release, we believe it would 
  be illogical to credit him for the time he served while he was â€œreleasedâ€ on 
  bond.Â  
Furthermore, section 24-13-40 consistently 
  uses the language â€œtime served by a prisoner.â€Â  A prisoner is defined as â€œ[a] 
  person who is serving time in prison.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 1213 (7th ed. 
  1999). [2] Â Â  Further, a prison is defined as â€œ[a] state 
  or federal facility of confinement for convicted criminals . . . .â€Â  Id.Â  
  Our statutes have also used the term prisoner to refer to persons confined in 
  a county jail.Â  See, e.g., S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-13-10 et 
  seq. (1989 & Supp. 2002); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-5-10 et seq. 
  (1989 & Supp. 2002).Â  Based on the plain and ordinary meaning of the term 
  prisoner, we believe the legislature only intended to award sentencing credit 
  to those who actually spend time confined in a penal institution.Â  Accordingly, 
  we find the trial court did not err in concluding Higgins was not entitled to 
  credit for time served on house arrest while released on bond.Â  
This view is in accord with that taken 
  by other jurisdictions interpreting similar statutes.Â  See State v. 
  Jarman, 535 S.E.2d 875, 880 (N.C. Ct. App. 2000) (holding that â€œconfinementâ€ 
  as contemplated by a similar statute did not include time spent before trial 
  on house arrest or electronic surveillance); Licata v. State, 788 So.2d 
  1063, 1064 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 2001) (finding house arrest is not the equivalent 
  of incarceration in the â€œcounty jailâ€ as required by the Florida statute); People 
  v. Ramos, 561 N.E.2d 643, 648 (Ill. 1990) (holding the Illinois legislature 
  did not intend the term â€œcustodyâ€ to apply to the period of time the defendant 
  was released on bail for pretrial home confinement).Â  But cf. Commonwealth 
  v. Chiappini, 782 A.2d 490, 497, 501 (Pa. 2001) (stating house arrest could 
  be the equivalent of time spent in an institution when the program was run by 
  the local prison system, and participants were considered inmates who were required 
  to wear electronic devices and submit to constant monitoring). 
Because we find our legislature only 
  intended to allow credit for time served in a penal institution, we find no 
  error in the trial courtâ€™s refusal to afford credit to Higgins for the time 
  he served on house arrest while he was released on bond.Â  Accordingly, the trial 
  courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED. 
HOWARD and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

 
   [1]  North Carolina v. Alford, 400 U.S. 25 (1970).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Billye L. West, Misty M. West, Brandy B. West, Billye L. West, II, Tiffany 
        T. West and Sabin S. West and The Heritage of Newberry, Inc.,       
Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Newberry Electric Cooperative, Inc., and Daniel P. Murphy,       
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Newberry County
James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3737
Heard October 8, 2003 â€“ Filed February 2, 2004 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Thomas H. Pope, III, of Newberry, for Appellants.
James L. Bruner, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

Beatty, J.: Â Newberry Electric Cooperative 
  (NEC) appeals from the trial courtâ€™s finding that Billye West, his children, 
  and their family corporation (collectively, the Wests) were entitled to declaratory 
  relief and ordering NEC to relocate a power line on the Westsâ€™ property.Â  We 
  affirm.Â  
FACTS
W.E. and Edith Matthews owned a 98-acre tract 
  of land in Newberry County.Â  In June 1955, they entered into a written agreement 
  with NEC concerning the construction, operation, and maintenance of a power 
  line on their property. The easement contained several restrictive covenants, 
  including, NEC would not place more than four poles on the property, each pole 
  was to be at least 45 feet tall, and the wires at least 35 feet from the ground 
  â€œat the lowest point of sag.â€ The easement also stated 

should the premises over which these lines 
  pass be developed by cutting into streets or lots or otherwise, then and 
  in that event, with a reasonable time after notice and upon same conditions, 
  [NEC] does hereby agree to remove its lines along a location along said street 
  or streets or elsewhere to be designated by [the Matthews] but at no time 
  shall [NEC] be deprived of the privilege of crossing said property at the general 
  proximity of the same location and in case said line is moved, [NEC] shall have 
  a right to use approved methods of construction in re-locating said line.Â  

(emphasis added).
The easement concludes with a habendum clause 
  which states â€œTO HAVE AND TO HOLD the privileges herein granted unto [NEC], 
  its successors and assigns forever.â€ The document was never recorded, but rather 
  was maintained on file at NEC.Â  In 1989, NEC placed additional poles on the 
  property, in essence violating the covenant, but the Matthews did not complain. 

The Wests purchased the property 
  from the Matthews estate in 1996.Â  While unaware of the unrecorded 1955 easement, 
  the Wests were aware of the NEC power line on the property. Indeed, Billy West 
  spoke with Larry Longshore, the CEO of NEC, before acquiring the property. West 
  wanted to know whether the line could be relocated.Â  West testified Longshore 
  assured him the line would be moved. Longshore admitted to only speaking with 
  West about a possible relocation and maintained that he made no firm commitment 
  to moving the line. However, both an NEC employee and a consulting engineer 
  testified that Longshore indicated a desire to move the line and asked that 
  plans be drawn up for relocation.Â  
In 1999, the Wests decided to 
  develop the property for commercial use, prompting the need for water and sewer 
  service.Â  The City of Newberry (the City) could provide these utilities, but 
  only if the Wests agreed to (1) annex the property into the City limits and 
  (2) receive electric service from the City instead of NEC. The Wests agreed 
  and the City annexed the property in January 2000. After the annexation, the 
  Wests asked NEC to relocate the line, and NEC refused.Â  The Wests then learned 
  about the 1955 easement. They reiterated their request to move the line â€“ this 
  time arguing that NEC had violated the covenants of the 1955 easement. NEC again 
  refused to relocate the line.Â  
The Wests filed a complaint seeking the relocation 
  of the power line, claiming trespass and promissory estoppel.Â  They also sought 
  a declaration that the 1955 easement was a real covenant that touched and concerned 
  the subject property. The trial court found for the Wests on all three issues 
  and ordered NEC to move the line. 
ISSUES

  I.        Did the trial court err in concluding that the 1955 easement on the property 
  was a real covenant?Â  
  II.       Did the trial court err in finding that the Wests had not waived their rights 
  to complain to NEC under the 1955 easement?
  III.     
Did the trial court err in finding that the Wests had met their burden of proving 
  promissory estoppel?
IV.Â Â Â Â  Did the trial court err in finding that NEC had trespassed 
  upon the property?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œA suit for declaratory judgment is neither legal 
  nor equitable, but is determined by the nature of the underlying issue.â€Â  Felts 
  v. Richland County, 303 S.C. 354, 356, 400 S.E.2d 781, 782 (1991).Â  â€œThe 
  determination of the existence of an easement is a question of fact in a law 
  action and subject to an any evidence standard of review when tried by a judge 
  without a jury.â€Â  Slear v. Hanna, 329 S.C. 407, 410, 496 S.E.2d 533, 
  535 (1998). The doctrine of promissory estoppel is equitable in nature.Â  See 
  28 Am. Jur. 2d Estoppel and Waiver Â§Â§ 1, 55 (2000). â€œWhen legal and equitable 
  actions are maintained in one suit, each retains its own identity as legal or 
  equitable for purposes of the applicable standard of review on appeal.â€ Kiriakides 
  v. Atlas Food Systems & Services, Inc., 338 S.C. 572, 580, 527 S.E.2d 
  371, 375 (Ct. App. 2000) (citation omitted). In an action at equity, this court 
  can find facts in accordance with its view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  
  Doe v. Clark, 318 S.C. 274, 276, 457 S.E.2d 336, 337 (1995).Â Â Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  1955 EasementÂ  
NEC argues the trial judge erred in finding the 
  1955 easement was a real covenant that ran with the land. We disagree.
â€œA restrictive covenant runs with the land, and 
  is thus enforceable by a successor-in-interest, if the covenanting parties intended 
  that the covenant run with the land, and the covenant touches and concerns the 
  land.â€Â  Marathon Fin. Co. v. HHC Liquidation Corp., 325 S.C. 589, 604, 
  483 S.E.2d 757, 765 (Ct. App. 1997) (citations omitted).Â  â€œ[A] party seeking 
  to enforce a covenant must show the covenant applies to the property either 
  by its express language or by a plain and unmistakable implication.â€Â  Charping 
  v. J.P. Scurry & Co., Inc., 296 S.C. 312, 314, 372 S.E.2d 120, 121 (Ct. 
  App. 1988) (citations omitted). 
The very language of the 1955 easement reveals 
  it to be a restrictive covenant that runs with the land. In the agreement, NEC 
  promises to relocate the power line should the property ever â€œbe developed.â€ 
  That agreement applies to the land.Â  While the agreement does not specify whether 
  this promise was to be honored only with respect to the Matthews, it does envision 
  the future of the land and thus applies to the Wests. See Marathon, 
  325 S.C. at 604, 483 S.E.2d at 765 (explaining that a â€œrestrictive covenant 
  runs with the land, and is thus enforceable by a successor-in-interest, if the 
  covenanting parties intended that the covenant run with the land, and the covenant 
  touches and concerns the landâ€) (citation omitted).
Moreover, the restrictive covenants in the 1955 easement 
  touch and concern the subject property.Â  The Matthews insisted upon several 
  conditions in order to maintain the safety and value of the property. The subject 
  of the covenants is a power line connected to and crossing over the land. Adherence 
  to the covenants by NEC directly affects the nature and value of the easement 
  to both NEC and the Wests.Â  The covenants in the easement also restrict the 
  manner in which NEC can use the easement. The exact location of the easement 
  on the property is not described in the easement, but its possible relocation 
  is contemplated. The covenants were obviously intended to touch and concern 
  the subject property.Â  See id.Â  While the language of the easement 
  does not expressly state the covenants were intended to touch and concern the 
  subject property, that is clearly implied.Â  See Charping, 296 
  S.C. at 314, 372 S.E.2d at 121.Â  
Accordingly, the trial judge did not err in holding 
  the 1955 easement was a real covenant that ran with the land.Â Â Â  
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Waiver
NEC argues the trial judge erred in failing to apply 
  the doctrine of waiver.Â  Specifically, NEC argues that, as neither the Matthews 
  nor the Wests ever enforced several covenants in the 1955 easement, the right 
  to file a complaint to NEC under the easement was waived.
This issue was neither addressed by the trial judge 
  in the final order nor mentioned in the subsequent Rule 59(e), SCACR, motion.Â  
  As such, it is not preserved for review by this court.Â  See Wilder 
  Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic 
  that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been 
  raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€); 
  see also Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 
  122, 124 (1991) (finding issue was not preserved where the trial judge did not 
  explicitly rule on the appellantâ€™s argument and the appellant did not raise 
  the issue in a Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to alter or amend the judgment).Â  
III.Â Â Â  Promissory EstoppelÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Since we have found that the 1955 easement is valid as to the Wests, 
  we need not address the issue of promissory estoppel.
IV.Â Â Â Â  Trespass
NEC argues the trial judge erred in finding NEC 
  had committed a trespass upon the property.
â€œTrespass is any intentional invasion of the plaintiffâ€™s 
  interest in the exclusive possession of his property.â€Â  Hedgepath v. American 
  Tel. & Tel. Co., 348 S.C. 340, 357, 559 S.E.2d 327, 337 (Ct. App. 2001) 
  (citing Silvester v. Spring Valley Country Club, 344 S.C. 280, 286, 543 
  S.E.2d 563, 566 (Ct. App. 2001)); see also Ravan v. Greenville County, 
  315 S.C. 447, 463, 434 S.E.2d 296, 306 (Ct. App. 1993) (â€œa trespass is any interference 
  with oneâ€™s right to the exclusive peaceable possession of his property.â€). 
In the final order, the trial judge found, â€œthe 
  facts demonstrate that the NEC has violated the covenants in several ways, has 
  technically forfeited its rights by reason of its violation and has committed 
  trespass on the Property.â€Â  This is the only mention of trespass in the final 
  order.Â  Assuming, without deciding, that the trial judge erred in finding NEC 
  guilty of trespass without conducting a more thorough analysis, we conclude 
  this was harmless error.Â  The record supports both the trial judgeâ€™s substantive 
  findings and his ultimate conclusion that NEC violated the terms of the 1955 
  easement.Â  See, e.g., Brown v. Allstate Ins. Co., 344 S.C. 
  21, 25, 542 S.E.2d 723, 725 (2001) (reinstating a trial courtâ€™s decision though 
  the trial court had erred since the error was harmless); 5 Am. Jur. 2d Appellate 
  Review Â§ 711 (1995) (â€œHarmless error provisions are designed to eliminate 
  reversals on purely formal and technical grounds, and to assure that substantial 
  justice has been done.â€).
Based on the foregoing, the trial courtâ€™s order 
  is 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and HUFF, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Robert E. Rumpf, Alice Rumpf Easton, and Theresa Horton as Personal 
        Representative for the Estate of Marvin G. Rumpf, individually and as 
        shareholders in the former Rumpf Truck Line, Inc., a Michigan corporation; 
        Diane Rumpf Ketring, John Rumpf, Philip Rumpf and Keye Rumpf Hennessey 
        as heirs to and beneficiaries of the Estate of Marvin G. Rumpf,       
Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Co., The Palmetto Bank, Phillip
Betette, individually and as agent for The Palmetto Bank, and DOES 1-5, 
        inclusive, Defendants,
of whom Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Co., The Palmetto Bank, 
        and Phillip Betette, are        Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Henry F. Floyd, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3738
Heard January 14, 2004 â€“ Filed February 2, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Marjorie T. Simmons, of Bellingham, Washington; and Rodney F. Pillsbury, 
  of Greenville, for Appellants.
Grady L. Patterson, III, of Columbia, for Respondent 
  Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Co.
James Theodore Gentry, of Greenville, for Respondents 
  The Palmetto Bank and Phillip Betette.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Appellants brought this action against Massachusetts 
  Mutual Life Insurance Company (â€œMass Mutualâ€) and The Palmetto Bank (â€œPalmetto 
  Bankâ€) asserting causes of action for fraud and breach of fiduciary duty relating 
  to the payment of dividends that accrued under an annuity contract with Mass 
  Mutual.Â  The trial court found these claims failed on their merits and were 
  barred by the applicable statute of limitations.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
This case has its origins with a company that no longer exists, Rumpf Truck 
  Line, Inc. (â€œRTLâ€).Â  RTL was a family-owned business with three shareholders: 
  siblings Marvin G. Rumpf, Robert E. Rumpf, and Alice Rumpf Easton.Â  Marvin Rumpf 
  served as president of the company.
In 1966, RTL and Mass Mutual entered into a contract containing a pension plan 
  for the non-union employees of RTL.Â  The contract gave retirement benefits to 
  RTL employees in the form of annuities having defined benefit schedules.Â  Marvin 
  Rumpf served as the pension plan administrator.
In 1975, RTL merged with Duff Truck Line, Inc.Â  Duff decided to discontinue 
  the pension plan.Â  The contract with Mass Mutual was amended so that all of 
  the RTL employees who had participated in the pension planâ€”including Marvin 
  Rumpfâ€”were given paid-up annuities in the value of their pension plan balances.
It was anticipated, however, that the investment returns Mass Mutual received 
  under the contract would sometimes exceed the amount needed to pay the benefits 
  under the individual annuity contracts.Â  When those circumstances arose, the 
  amended contract provided that any dividends declared by Mass Mutual after the 
  commencement of the paid-up term would be â€œpaid in cash to the Contractholder 
  or such person, persons, firm or corporation as the Contractholder may designate.â€
On August 7, 1979, Denise A. Wilson, with Mass Mutualâ€™s Group Pension Consulting 
  Department, wrote to Marvin Rumpf as plan administrator informing him that dividends 
  had accrued under the contract that Mass Mutual wished to pay.Â  The letter noted 
  that Mass Mutual did not know to whom it should send the dividendsâ€”advising 
  Rumpf that it could not determine whether the contractholder was RTL or Duff.Â  
  Mass Mutual wrote Duff notifying it of the same information.
Marvin Rumpf replied by letter, dated August 25, 1979, that all dividends should 
  be sent to him and that he would ensure they were distributed among the three 
  stockholders.Â  Duff responded to Mass Mutual claiming it was the proper contractholder.Â  
  Mass Mutual replied to both Marvin Rumpf and Duff informing them of the dispute.
On September 16, 1980, Marvin Rumpf again inquired with Mass Mutual regarding 
  the status of the dividend payment.Â  Mass Mutual advised Marvin Rumpf and Duff 
  by letter dated November 3, 1980 that it could not pay dividends until the parties 
  determined which was the contractholder.
Marvin Rumpf took no further action to claim or ascertain his entitlement to 
  any dividends.Â  He died in South Carolina in 1989, survived by his four children 
  who were the beneficiaries of his estate.
As directed in his will, Palmetto Bank was appointed personal representative 
  of Rumpfâ€™s estate.Â  Phillip Betette, a senior trust officer for Palmetto Bank, 
  carried out much of the bankâ€™s work on the estate, but was not himself named 
  personal representative.Â  The estate was closed after a hearing before the probate 
  court.
In 1993, Duff Truck Lines dissolved.Â  Mass Mutual later escheated the accumulated 
  dividends for the period 1979 through 1989 to the State of South Carolina.Â  
  Throughout the balance of the 1990â€™s, dividends continued to accrue under the 
  contract and were held by Mass Mutual.
No one inquired regarding the status or ownership of these funds until â€œlate 
  April, 1999.â€Â  That year, one of Marvin Rumpfâ€™s surviving daughters discovered 
  the escheated dividend payments â€œwhile browsing the Internet.â€Â  The surviving 
  shareholders and other beneficiaries of Marvin Rumpf confronted Palmetto Bank 
  and Mass Mutual as to why they had not been informed of the accumulated dividends 
  at the time of the distribution of Marvin Rumpfâ€™s estate a decade earlier.
Upon demand from the beneficiaries, Mass Mutual, on October 6, 1999, paid them 
  accumulated dividends, in the amount of $169,873.45, for the period 1990 through 
  1999.Â  The shareholders and heirs obtained the escheated funds from the State 
  in the sum of $186,394.04 by check dated December 13, 1999.Â  Accordingly, all 
  dividends under the contract have been paid.
This Action
Though all of the accrued dividends were ultimately paid, the beneficiaries 
  believed Mass Mutual and Palmetto Bank acted wrongfully by failing to discover 
  or actively concealing their entitlement to the dividend funds.Â  Thus, they 
  brought the present action.Â  Against Mass Mutual, they asserted multiple claims 
  for breach of contract, fraud, breach of fiduciary duty, insurance bad-faith, 
  conversion, and unfair trade practices.Â  They alleged breach of fiduciary duty 
  and fraud against Palmetto Bank.
The trial court granted summary judgment in favor of both defendants on all 
  of the causes of action.Â  Though the court addressed the merits of the individual 
  claims, it found the entire case against Mass Mutual was barred by the applicable 
  statute of limitations.Â  Likewise, in a separate order addressing the claims 
  against Palmetto Bank, the trial court held that action was barred because the 
  statute of limitations had expired.Â  The court further ruled the action was 
  barred because the probate court overseeing the administration of Marvin Rumpfâ€™s 
  estate had discharged Palmetto Bank from all liability as personal representative, 
  and the beneficiaries of Marvin Rumpfâ€™s estate had signed a full release in 
  favor of Palmetto Bank upon distribution of property from the estate.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court 
  applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP: 
  Summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material 
  fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Laurens 
  Emergency Med. Specialists v. M.S. Bailey & Sons Bankers, 355 S.C. 104, 
  584 S.E.2d 375 (2003); Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 567 S.E.2d 857 
  (2002); Regions Bank v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 582 S.E.2d 432 (Ct. App. 
  2003); Redwend Ltd. Pâ€™ship v. Edwards, 354 S.C. 459, 581 S.E.2d 496 (Ct. 
  App. 2003).Â  In determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence 
  and all inferences which can reasonably be drawn therefrom must be viewed in 
  the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Sauner v. Public Serv. 
  Auth., 354 S.C. 397, 581 S.E.2d 161 (2003); Hendricks v. Clemson Univ., 
  353 S.C. 449, 578 S.E.2d 711 (2003); McNair v. Rainsford, 330 S.C. 332, 
  499 S.E.2d 488 (Ct. App. 1998); see also Laurens Emergency Med. Specialists, 
  355 S.C. at 108, 584 S.E.2d at 377 (stating that in reviewing summary judgment 
  motion, facts and circumstances must be viewed in light most favorable to non-moving 
  party).Â  If triable issues exist, those issues must go to the jury.Â  Baril 
  v. Aiken Regâ€™l Med. Ctrs., 352 S.C. 271, 573 S.E.2d 830 (Ct. App. 2002); 
  Young v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corrections, 333 S.C. 714, 511 S.E.2d 
  413 (Ct. App. 1999).
Summary judgment is appropriate where the pleadings, depositions, answers to 
  interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, 
  show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving 
  party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Russell v. Wachovia Bank, 
  N.A., 353 S.C. 208, 578 S.E.2d 329 (2003); Regions Bank, 354 S.C. 
  at 659, 582 S.E.2d at 438; Hedgepath v. American Tel. & Tel. Co., 
  348 S.C. 340, 559 S.E.2d 327 (Ct. App. 2001); Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  All ambiguities, 
  conclusions, and inferences arising from the evidence must be construed most 
  strongly against the moving party.Â  Schmidt v. Courtney, Op. No. 3719 
  (S.C. Ct. App. filed December 22, 2003) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 1 at 66); Bayle 
  v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 542 S.E.2d 736 (Ct. App. 
  2001); see also Ferguson v. Charleston Lincoln Mercury, Inc., 
  349 S.C. 558, 563, 564 S.E.2d 94, 96 (2002) (â€œOn appeal from an order granting 
  summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, 
  and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to 
  the non-moving party below.â€).
Summary judgment is not appropriate where further inquiry into the facts of 
  the case is desirable to clarify the application of the law.Â  Brockbank v. 
  Best Capital Corp., 341 S.C. 372, 534 S.E.2d 688 (2000); Bayle, 344 
  S.C. at 120, 542 S.E.2d at 738.Â  Summary judgment should not be granted even 
  when there is no dispute as to evidentiary facts if there is disagreement concerning 
  the conclusion to be drawn from those facts.Â  Moriarty v. Garden Sanctuary 
  Church of God, 341 S.C. 320, 534 S.E.2d 672 (2000).Â  However, when plain, 
  palpable, and indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds cannot differ, 
  summary judgment should be granted.Â  Hedgepath, 348 S.C. at 355, 559 
  S.E.2d at 336; Pye v. Aycock, 325 S.C. 426, 480 S.E.2d 455 (Ct. App. 
  1997).
Under Rule 56(c), SCRCP, the party seeking summary judgment has the initial 
  burden of demonstrating the absence of a genuine issue of material fact.Â  Regions 
  Bank, 354 S.C. at 659, 582 S.E.2d at 438; Trivelas v. South Carolina 
  Depâ€™t of Transp., 348 S.C. 125, 558 S.E.2d 271 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Once the 
  party moving for summary judgment meets the initial burden of showing an absence 
  of evidentiary support for the opponentâ€™s case, the opponent cannot simply rest 
  on mere allegations or denials contained in the pleadings.Â  Regions Bank, 
  354 S.C. at 660, 582 S.E.2d at 438.Â  Rather, the nonmoving party must come forward 
  with specific facts showing there is a genuine issue for trial.Â  SSI Med. 
  Servs., Inc. v. Cox, 301 S.C. 493, 392 S.E.2d 789 (1990); Peterson v. 
  West American Ins. Co., 336 S.C. 89, 518 S.E.2d 608 (Ct. App. 1999); Rule 
  56(c), SCRCP.Â  The purpose of summary judgment is to expedite disposition of 
  cases which do not require the services of a fact finder.Â  Dawkins v. Fields, 
  354 S.C. 58, 580 S.E.2d 433 (2003); George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 548 
  S.E.2d 868 (2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Claims Against Mass Mutual
Appellants argue the trial court erred in ruling their claims against 
  Mass Mutual were barred by the statute of limitations.Â  We disagree.
Under the former South Carolina Code section 15-3-530, plaintiffs 
  alleging an action in contract or tort were required to bring suit within six 
  years of the time the cause of action arose.Â  In 1988, this time period was 
  shortened to three years for causes of action arising on or after April 5, 1988. 
  See Annotation, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530 (Supp. 2003) (referencing 1988 
  Act No. 432).
In determining when a cause of action arose under section 15-3-530, 
  we apply the â€œdiscovery rule.â€Â  See Santee Portland Cement Co. v. 
  Daniel Intâ€™l Corp., 299 S.C. 269, 384 S.E.2d 693 (1989), overruled on 
  other grounds by Atlas Food Sys. & Servs., Inc. v. Crane Natâ€™l Vendors 
  Div., 319 S.C. 556, 462 S.E.2d 858 (1995).Â  According to the discovery rule, 
  the statute of limitations begins to run when a cause of action reasonably ought 
  to have been discovered.Â  Hedgepath v. American Tel. & Tel. Co., 
  348 S.C. 340, 559 S.E.2d 327 (Ct. App. 2001); Bayle v. South Carolina Depâ€™t 
  of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 542 S.E.2d 736 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Under this rule, 
  a cause of action accrues for purposes of the statute of limitations when a 
  plaintiff has notice that he might have a remedy for a harm.Â  Dean v. Ruscon 
  Corp., 321 S.C. 360, 468 S.E.2d 645 (1996).Â  The statute runs from the date 
  the injured party either knows or should have known by the exercise of reasonable 
  diligence that a cause of action arises from the wrongful conduct.Â  Hedgepath, 
  348 S.C. at 355-56, 559 S.E.2d at 336; Young v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Corrections, 
  333 S.C. 714, 511 S.E.2d 413 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  In explaining the discovery rule, 
  our Supreme Court held:

We have interpreted the â€œexercise of reasonable diligenceâ€ 
  to mean that the injured party must act with some promptness where the facts 
  and circumstances of an injury place a reasonable person of common knowledge 
  and experience on notice that a claim against another party might exist. Moreover, 
  the fact that the injured party may not comprehend the full extent of the damage 
  is immaterial.

Dean, 321 S.C. at 363-64, 468 S.E.2d at 647 (citation 
  and emphasis omitted); see also Wiggins v. Edwards, 314 S.C. 126, 
  442 S.E.2d 169 (1994) (stating exercise of reasonable diligence means simply 
  that injured party must act with some promptness where facts and circumstances 
  of injury would put person of common knowledge and experience on notice that 
  some right of his has been invaded or that some claim against another party 
  might exist; statute of limitations begins to run from this point and not when 
  advice of counsel is sought or full-blown theory of recovery is developed); 
  Burgess v. American Cancer Socâ€™y, 300 S.C. 182, 386 S.E.2d 798 (Ct. App. 
  1989) (noting that statute starts to run upon discovery of such facts as would 
  have led to knowledge thereof if pursued with reasonable diligence).Â  Reasonable 
  diligence is intrinsically tied to the issue of notice.Â  Hedgepath, 348 
  S.C. at 356, 559 S.E.2d at 336; Bayle, 344 S.C. at 126, 542 S.E.2d at 
  741.
The date on which discovery of the cause of action 
  should have been made is an objective, rather than a subjective, question.Â  
  Hedgepath, 348 S.C. at 356, 559 S.E.2d at 336; Joubert v. South Carolina 
  Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 341 S.C. 176, 534 S.E.2d 1 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  In other 
  words, whether the particular plaintiff actually knew he had a claim is not 
  the test.Â  Young, 333 S.C. at 719, 511 S.E.2d at 416.Â  Rather, courts 
  must decide whether the circumstances of the case would put a person of common 
  knowledge and experience on notice that some right of his has been invaded, 
  or that some claim against another party might exist.Â  Id.
In this case, we look to whether Marvin Rumpf knew 
  or should have known that he, along with other shareholders, were entitled to 
  receive the dividend payments from Mass Mutual.Â  It is undisputed that the claims 
  of Marvin Rumpfâ€™s four children as beneficiaries of his estate are derivative 
  only and rest upon the knowledge of Marvin Rumpf as to when the causes of action 
  arose.Â  Appellants contend the trial court erred in finding Marvin Rumpf acted 
  as the agent of his sibling shareholders, and that his knowledge should be imputed 
  to them.Â  We disagree.
Marvin Rumpf was the plan administrator when the pension plan was 
  discontinued and the individual, fully-paid annuities were purchased.Â  All contact 
  with Mass Mutual was handled by Marvin Rumpf or his attorney.
Appellants claim that Marvin Rumpf notified Mass Mutual that he was 
  not acting on behalf of the other shareholders.Â  Specifically, Appellants rely 
  upon a letter dated March 22, 1976, from Marvin Rumpf to Mass Mutual in which 
  Marvin Rumpf indicates that Mass Mutual should correspond with fellow shareholders 
  Robert Rumpf and Alice Easton regarding the pension.Â  Yet, at all times following 
  this letter, Marvin Rumpf continued to handle all pension-related affairs on 
  behalf of his two co-shareholders.
For example, Mass Mutual sent annuity information to Robert Rumpf 
  on May 21, 1976.Â  The reply to Mass Mutual, however, came from Marvin Rumpfâ€™s 
  attorney and contained the Plan Administratorâ€™s Certification of Sufficiency 
  required to close out the pension plan which was signed by Marvin Rumpf.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  There is no proof that anyone other than Marvin Rumpf and his attorney 
  were involved with the pension plan and subsequent annuity contract.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  The evidence establishes that Marvin Rumpf knew or should have known 
  that he and his fellow shareholders were entitled to payment of the dividends 
  received under the annuity contract.Â  Mass Mutual wrote to Marvin Rumpf on August 
  7, 1979, and advised him that dividends had accrued under the contract with 
  Mass Mutual.Â  He was later informed by Mass Mutual on November 3, 1980, that 
  there was a dispute regarding who should receive the dividendsâ€”RTL or Duff Truck 
  Lines.Â  At that time, Mass Mutual explicitly advised Marvin Rumpf that:
We have taken this matter up with our law department and 
  it is our position that Massachusetts Mutual is not the party to determine to 
  whom the dividend is to be paid.Â  May we ask that you contact Mr. Keenan of 
  Duff Truck Line, Inc. and resolve this matter.
We find that any cause of action against Mass Mutual accrued no later than 
  1980.Â  Instead of pursuing his claim to the dividend payments, Marvin Rumpf 
  permitted the then-existing six year statute of limitations to lapse.Â  Concomitantly, 
  we affirm the trial courtâ€™s ruling that the entire action against Mass Mutual 
  is barred by the statute of limitations.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Claims Against Palmetto Bank
A.Â  Applicable Statute of Limitations
We do not reach the merits of Appellantsâ€™ claims against Palmetto 
  Bank because their action is barred by the statute of limitations.Â  As with 
  the claims against Mass Mutual, the action against Palmetto Bank rests on the 
  fact that Palmetto Bank failed to secure ownership of the disputed funds for 
  the estate of Marvin Rumpf.Â  At the time of Marvin Rumpfâ€™s death, his right 
  to bring suit to obtain the dividend funds from Mass Mutual had already expired.Â  
  Consequently, Appellantsâ€™ derivative claims through the Estate are barred by 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530.
B.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-1001
Furthermore, Appellantsâ€™ claims are barred because the probate court 
  overseeing the administration of Marvin Rumpfâ€™s estate discharged the personal 
  representative from any liability for the estate.Â  South Carolina Code section 
  62-3-1001 reads:

[T]he court may enter an order or orders, on appropriate 
  conditions, determining testacy, determining the persons entitled to distribution 
  of the estate, and, as circumstances require, approving settlement and directing 
  or approving distribution of the estate, terminating the appointment of the 
  personal representative, and discharging the personal representative from 
  further claim or demand of any interested person.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-1001 (Supp. 2003) (emphasis added).
Palmetto Bank petitioned the probate court for an order of discharge.Â  
  Notice of the petition was served on all of the parties, and a hearing was held 
  in November 1990.Â  None of the Appellants appeared at the hearing.Â  After the 
  hearing, Probate Judge Ralph Drake signed a form discharge order.Â  Judge Drake, 
  however, did not check any of the boxes on the preprinted form order indicating 
  the action the court intended to take.
In order to clear up the ambiguity surrounding the effect of the 
  probate courtâ€™s order, Palmetto Bank submitted an affidavit of Judge Drake as 
  evidence of his intent in signing the order.Â  In the affidavit, Judge Drake 
  declared that his failure to check any of the boxes on the form was an oversight.Â  
  He further stated that his intention was to check Box 3 on the form, which provides: 
  â€œ[T]he Personal Representative is released and discharged as the Personal Representative, 
  and any and all liability arising in connection with the performance of the 
  Representativeâ€™s duties and the administration of the estate be closed.â€
 We first note that Appellants failed to appeal the trial courtâ€™s 
  findings with regard to the probate courtâ€™s discharge of liability.Â  Any unappealed 
  portion of the trial courtâ€™s judgment is the law of the case, and must therefore 
  be affirmed.Â  See Greenville County v. Kenwood Enters., Inc., 
  353 S.C. 157, 577 S.E.2d 428 (2003); Douglass v. Boyce, 344 S.C. 5, 542 
  S.E.2d 715 (2001); National Grange Mut. Ins. Co. v. Firemenâ€™s Ins. Co., 
  310 S.C. 116, 425 S.E.2d 754 (Ct. App. 1992); see also ML-Lee Acquisition 
  Fund, L.P. v. Deloitte & Touche, 327 S.C. 238, 489 S.E.2d 470 (1997) 
  (emphasizing that unappealed rulings become law of case and should not be reconsidered 
  by this Court).Â  A challenge to the Circuit Courtâ€™s ruling on this point is 
  not properly before this Court.
CONCLUSION
We conclude the trial court correctly found that all 
  of Appellantsâ€™ claims against Mass Mutual are barred by the statute of limitations.Â  
  Similarly, the claims against Palmetto Bank are barred by the statute of limitations 
  as well as the discharge of liability entered by the probate court.Â  Accordingly, 
  the judgment of the trial court is
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Nicholas N. Trivelas and Peggy
Trivelas,        Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
South Carolina Dept. of Transportation,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Rodney A. Peeples, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3739
Heard November 4, 2003 â€“ Filed February 
  2, 2004

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
William H. Davidson II, Andrew F. Lindemann and James M. Davis, 
  Jr., all of Columbia; for Appellant.
Leigh James Leventis, and Richard A. Harpootlian, both of 
  Columbia; for Respondents.
      
    
  


HOWARD, J.:Â  Nicholas and Peggy 
  Trivelas brought this action against the South Carolina Department of Transportation 
  (â€œDOTâ€) for damages arising from an automobile collision involving a DOT truck.Â  
  The case was tried before a jury, resulting in a verdict for DOT.Â  DOT appeals 
  the circuit courtâ€™s grant of a new trial absolute to the Trivelases, arguing 
  the circuit court erred because:Â  1) as a matter of law, Trivelas was more than 
  fifty percent negligent, and thus, the Trivelases should be barred from recovery 
  by the doctrine of comparative negligence; 2) the court applied the incorrect 
  legal standard for granting a new trial absolute based on the thirteenth juror 
  doctrine; and 3) it failed to consider explanatory and excusatory circumstances 
  while sitting as the thirteenth juror.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
A truck hauling lumber in an easterly 
  direction on Interstate 20 spilled its load in the roadway, blocking the eastbound 
  lanes of traffic.Â  In response to a request from police, DOT dispatched a dump 
  truck pulling a trailer and backhoe to assist with the cleanup.Â  
The dump truck approached the spill from the inside, 
  westbound lane of traffic and attempted to cross the median at the location 
  of the spill.Â  In order to do so, the dump truck slowed to approximately ten 
  miles per hour.Â  The dump truck did not have emergency signals or lights and 
  did not cross the median in an area designated for turning.Â  
At the same time, Nicholas Trivelas drove 
  his van in the westbound lane of Interstate 20, and when DOTâ€™s dump truck slowed 
  to turn, Trivelasâ€™ car collided with the dump truck and trailer.Â  Trivelas sustained 
  severe personal injuries, as well as property damage.Â  
Thereafter, Nicholas Trivelas sued DOT 
  for negligence, and Peggy Trivelas sued DOT for loss of consortium.Â  Prior to 
  trial, the Trivelases moved for partial summary judgment on the issue of negligence, 
  asserting that under any view of the facts, DOT was negligent as a matter of 
  law pursuant to South Carolina Code Annotated sections 56-5-1560(a) (Supp. 2002) 
  [1]  and 56-5-1920 (1991). [2] Â  
The circuit court granted the Trivelasesâ€™ motion 
  for partial summary judgment, holding by any view of the evidence, DOT was negligent 
  as a matter of law. 
On appeal, this Court reversed and remanded, 
  [3]  ruling that in a light most favorable to DOT, evidence existed within 
  the record by which the jury could find DOT was acting under explanatory or 
  excusatory circumstances, and thus, a violation of the statutes was not negligence 
  as a matter of law.Â  
On remand, the case was tried to a jury.Â  At the 
  close of the trial, DOT moved for a directed verdict, arguing under any view 
  of the evidence, Nicholas Trivelasâ€™ negligence was greater than DOTâ€™s negligence, 
  and thus, the Trivelasesâ€™ claims were barred by the doctrine of comparative 
  negligence.Â  The circuit court denied the motion.Â  
DOT then requested the circuit court charge the 
  jury that explanatory and excusatory circumstances could justify operating the 
  DOT truck in derogation of the aforementioned statutes.Â  The circuit court declined, 
  ruling explanatory or excusatory circumstances did not apply to the facts of 
  the case.Â  
Subsequently, the jury returned a verdict in favor 
  of DOT, and the Trivelases moved for a new trial absolute, arguing the evidence 
  presented did not sustain the jury verdict. The circuit court agreed and granted 
  the motion pursuant to the thirteenth juror doctrine.Â  DOT appeals.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Comparative 
  Negligence
DOT argues the circuit court erred by granting 
  a new trial absolute pursuant to the thirteenth juror doctrine because, as asserted 
  in its motion for directed verdict, a reasonable jury could not find Trivelas 
  was less than fifty-one percent negligent.Â  Thus, DOT contends the Trivelasesâ€™ 
  claims were barred by the doctrine of comparative negligence.Â  We disagree.
Under the comparative negligence doctrine, a plaintiff 
  may only recover damages if his own negligence is not greater than that of the 
  defendant.Â  Thomasko v. Poole, 349 S.C. 7, 11, 561 S.E.2d 597, 599 (2002); 
  Bloom v. Ravoira, 339 S.C. 417, 422, 529 S.E.2d 710, 712-13 (2000).Â  
  Generally, â€œunder a â€˜less than or equal toâ€™ comparative negligence rule, determination 
  of respective degrees of negligence attributable to the plaintiff and the defendant 
  presents a question of fact for the jury, at least where conflicting inferences 
  may be drawn.â€Â  Brown v. Smalls, 325 S.C. 547, 559, 481 S.E.2d 444, 451 
  (Ct. App. 1997); see also Creech v. South Carolina Wildlife 
  and Marine Res. Depâ€™t, 328 S.C. 24, 32, 491 S.E.2d 571, 575 (1997) (holding 
  comparison of a plaintiffâ€™s negligence with that of the defendant is a question 
  of fact for the jury to decide). 
â€œIn a comparative negligence case, the trial court 
  should only determine judgment as a matter of law if the sole reasonable inference 
  which may be drawn from the evidence is that the plaintiffâ€™s negligence exceeded 
  fifty percent.â€Â  Bloom, 339 S.C. at 422, 529 S.E.2d at 713.
In a light most favorable to the Trivelases, the 
  evidence within the record indicates Trivelas was traveling westbound on Interstate 
  20, during rush hour, at approximately sixty-five miles per hour.Â  There is 
  no indication Trivelas was speeding.Â  Rather, the evidence indicates Trivelas 
  was within the flow of traffic traveling at the posted speed limit.
According to Trivelas, he noticed a brown van immediately 
  in front of his vehicle.Â  The van appeared to be a van he once owned, and for 
  several seconds, Trivelas attempted to determine if the van was his old van.Â  
  Trivelas determined it was not his old van.Â  
Thereafter, the van abruptly switched from the 
  left lane to the right lane, and, for the first time having an unobstructed 
  view of the road in front of him, Trivelas saw the DOT dump truck and trailer 
  attempting to cross the median of the Interstate, without emergency signals 
  or lights, in a non-designated area.Â  Trivelas applied his brakes but was unable 
  to stop his vehicle before it collided with the dump truck and trailer.
Trivelas testified he was traveling at a safe distance 
  from the van at all times, and he could not see past the van until the van moved 
  from the left to the right lane.Â  Additionally both Trivelas and an accident 
  reconstructionist testified Trivelas could not have done anything to avoid the 
  accident.Â  A human factors analyst also testified people in Trivelasâ€™ situation 
  would not have sufficient time to react and avoid the accident.Â  However, if 
  the dump truck had been using emergency signals or lights, Trivelas would have 
  had more time to analyze the situation and perhaps avoid the accident.Â  
Viewing the evidence in the record in a light most 
  favorable to Trivelas, we do not believe the sole reasonable inference was that 
  Trivelas was more than fifty percent negligent.Â  See Bloom, 339 
  S.C. at 422, 529 S.E.2d at 713 (â€œIn a comparative negligence case, the trial 
  court should only determine judgment as a matter of law if the sole reasonable 
  inference which may be drawn from the evidence is that the plaintiffâ€™s negligence 
  exceeded fifty percent.â€).Â  Rather, the jury could reasonably have found the 
  accident was predominantly caused by the actions of DOTâ€™s dump truck driver. 
  Thus, we hold the evidence was conflicting on this point, providing a legal 
  basis for the circuit courtâ€™s grant of a new trial absolute pursuant to the 
  thirteenth juror doctrine.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  The Thirteenth 
  Juror Doctrine
DOT argues the circuit court erred by granting 
  a new trial pursuant to the thirteenth juror doctrine because the circuit court 
  applied an incorrect legal standard.Â  We disagree.
 South Carolinaâ€™s thirteenth juror doctrine allows 
  the circuit court judge to grant a new trial absolute when the judge finds the 
  evidence does not justify the verdict.Â  Norton v. Norfold S. Ry. Co., 
  350 S.C. 473, 478, 567 S.E.2d 851, 854 (2002).
During the hearing on the motion for a new trial 
  absolute, the circuit court stated, 

AS CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL WROTE IN THE BAILEY V. PEACOCK CASE, 
  WHICH WAS TRIED HERE IN AIKEN COUNTY CIRCUIT COURT, AND I QUOTE, â€˜THE THIRTEENTH 
  JUROR DOCTRINE IS A VEHICLE BY WHICH THE TRIAL COURT MAY GRANT A NEW TRIAL ABSOLUTE 
  WHEN HE FINDS THE EVIDENCE DOES NOT JUSTIFY THE VERDICT,â€™ AND THEY CITE FOLKENS 
  V. HUNT.Â  THE COURT IS CONVINCED THAT THE EVIDENCE DID NOT JUSTIFY THE VERDICT 
  AND THE COURT DOES GRANT A NEW TRIAL ABSOLUTE IN THIS CASE.

(emphasis in original).Â  Furthermore, the circuit courtâ€™s 
  subsequent order states in pertinent part:

In view of the facts introduced at trial, and after due consideration 
  of all factual evidence and testimony offered at trial, this Court is of the 
  opinion that conflicting evidence was presented on the issues of liability and, 
  therefore, evidence existed from which the jury might reasonably have inferred 
  that the Plaintiffsâ€™ injuries were proximately caused by the negligence of the 
  Defendant.Â  THEREFORE, IT IS ORDERED, ADJUDGED, AND DECREED that, based upon 
  the factual evidence, this Court finds that justice was not done by the juryâ€™s 
  verdict, and in the exercise of the discretionary powers of this Court . . . 
  the Plaintiffs . . . are . . . granted a new trial absolute.

(emphasis in original).Â  
DOT contends the language in the circuit courtâ€™s 
  order indicates the circuit court granted the new trial absolute merely because 
  conflicting evidence existed within the record.Â  However, viewing the circuit 
  courtâ€™s order as a whole, coupled with the courtâ€™s statements during the hearing, 
  it is clear the circuit court granted the Trivelasesâ€™ motion for a new trial 
  absolute because it believed â€œTHE EVIDENCE DID NOT JUSTIFY THE VERDICT[,]â€ and 
  thus, â€œjustice was not done by the juryâ€™s verdict . . .â€Â  (emphasis as in original).Â  
  See State v. Evans, 354 S.C. 579, 584, 582 S.E.2d 407, 410 (2003) 
  (holding an appellate court must view the circuit courtâ€™s statements as a whole 
  to determine its reasoning); Dibble v. Sumter Ice & Fuel Co., 283 
  S.C. 278, 282, 322 S.E.2d 674, 677 (Ct. App. 1984) (â€œAn order should be construed 
  within the context of the proceeding in which it is rendered.â€); see also 
  Eddins v. Eddins, 304 S.C. 133, 135, 403 S.E.2d 164, 166 (Ct. App. 1991) 
  (holding judgments are to be construed as other instruments, and the determinative 
  factor is the intention of the court, considering the judgment in its entirety).Â  
  This is the appropriate legal standard for granting a new trial absolute based 
  on the thirteenth juror doctrine.Â  See Norton, 350 S.C. at 478, 
  567 S.E.2d at 854.Â  Thus, we hold the circuit court did not err.Â  
DOT next argues the circuit court erroneously refused 
  to charge explanatory or excusatory circumstances, and thus, when the circuit 
  court granted DOTâ€™s motion for a new trial absolute pursuant to the thirteenth 
  juror doctrine, it based its decision on an error of law.Â  
The thirteenth juror doctrine is a vehicle by which 
  the circuit court may grant a new trial absolute when it finds the evidence 
  does not justify the verdict.Â  Norton, 350 S.C. at 478, 567 S.E.2d at 
  854.Â  The effect is the same as if the jury failed to reach a verdict, and thus, 
  the circuit court is not required to give any reason for granting the new trial. 
  Â Â Â Folkens v. Hunt, 300 S.C. 251, 254, 387 S.E.2d 265, 267 (1990).Â  Rather, 
  assuming evidence exists to support the circuit courtâ€™s order, the circuit court 
  â€œjudge . . . [, sitting as] the thirteenth juror, possess[es] the veto power 
  to the Nth degree . . .â€Â  Worrell v. South Carolina Power Co., 186 S.C. 
  306, 313-14, 195 S.E. 638, 641 (1938).Â  Therefore, a circuit courtâ€™s order granting 
  or denying a new trial upon the facts will not be disturbed unless its decision 
  is wholly unsupported by the evidence or the conclusion reached was controlled 
  by an error of law.Â  South Carolina State Highway Depâ€™t v. Clarkson, 
  267 S.C. 121, 126-27, 226 S.E.2d 696, 697 (1976).Â  
The DOTâ€™s argument presumes the circuit court premised 
  its decision to grant a new trial absolute on an earlier legal conclusion that 
  explanatory and excusatory circumstances should not be charged.Â  However, other 
  than the statement, â€œjustice was not done by the juryâ€™s verdict,â€ the circuit 
  court did not state its reasons for granting the new trial absolute.Â  Furthermore, 
  the circuit court is not required to do so.Â  See Folkens, 300 
  S.C. at 254, 387 S.E.2d at 267 (holding a circuit court is not required to give 
  any reason for granting a new trial absolute based on the thirteenth juror doctrine).Â Â Â  

Thus, we decline to speculate on the significance 
  of the courtâ€™s prior rulings as the underlying basis for the decision to grant 
  a new trial absolute.Â  Rather, where, as here, the circuit court applied the 
  correct legal standard for granting a new trial, and conflicting evidence exists 
  on the contested issues, a circuit courtâ€™s decision to sit as a thirteenth juror 
  and grant a new trial absolute is inviolable.Â  See Worrell, 186 
  S.C. at 313-14, 195 S.E. at 641 (holding a â€œjudge . . . [, sitting as] the thirteenth 
  juror, possess[es] the veto power to the Nth degree . . .â€); see also 
  South Carolina State Highway Depâ€™t, 267 S.C. at 126-27, 226 S.E.2d at 
  697 (holding an appellate court may not disturb a circuit courtâ€™s decision to 
  grant or deny a motion for new trial absolute based on the thirteenth juror 
  doctrine unless the decision is wholly without evidentiary support or is the 
  result of an error of law).
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the decisions of the 
  circuit court are 
 AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE, J., concur.

    except when reduced speed is necessary for safe operation or in compliance 
    with law.â€Â  

 
    [2] Section 56-5-1920 provides:
  
  Whenever any highway has 
    been divided into two or more roadways by leaving an intervening space or

    right-hand roadway unless directed or permitted to use another roadway by 
    official traffic-control devices or police officers.Â Â  No vehicle shall be 
    driven over, across or within any such dividing space, barrier or section 
    except through an opening in such physical barrier or dividing section or 
    space or at a crossover or intersection as established, unless specifically 
    prohibited by public authority.Â  For clarification, a left turn across a painted 
    median is authorized unless prohibited by an official traffic-control device.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Gregory Tillotson,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Keith Smith
Builders,        Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Master-In-Equity

Opinion No. 3740
Heard June 11, 2003 â€“ Filed February 
  2, 2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
D. Garrison Hill and Kenneth C. Porter, of Greenville, for Appellant.
James W. Logan, Jr., of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  


BEATTY, J.:Â  Gregory Tillotson (â€œTillotsonâ€) 
  appeals from the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of Keith Smith 
  Builders (â€œBuilderâ€).
FACTS
Tillotson, a self-employed electrical 
  subcontractor, was hired by Builder, a general contractor, to relocate a light 
  fixture box in a residential home.Â  Builder required Tillotson to submit proof 
  of workersâ€™ compensation insurance.Â  Tillotson submitted a â€œCertificate of Liability 
  Insuranceâ€ produced by R.V. Chandler & Associates listing Tillotson as the 
  named insured with Commercial Casualty Insurance Company of Georgia and Capital 
  City Insurance Company as the insurers.Â  Allegedly, Tillotson was subsequently 
  injured at Builderâ€™s job site. 
After the injury, Tillotson 
  informed Builder that Tillotsonâ€™s employees were covered by the insurance policy, 
  but that he was not.Â  Tillotson sued Builder in tort.Â  Builder answered that 
  it was immune from a suit in tort under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-415 (Supp. 2002).Â  
  As such, Builder argued, Tillotson's sole route of recovery was through workers' 
  compensation. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A trial court should grant summary 
  judgment only where there is no genuine issue of material fact and the moving 
  party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  CafÃ© Assocs., Ltd. v. 
  Gerngross, 305 S.C. 6, 9, 406 S.E.2d 162, 164 (1991).Â  Summary judgment 
  is not proper where further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable 
  to clarify the application of the law.Â  Middleborough Horizontal Property 
  Regime Council of Co-Owners v. Montedison, 320 S.C. 470, 479, 465 S.E.2d 
  765, 771 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  An appellate court reviews the granting of summary 
  judgment under the same standard applied by the trial court.Â  George v. Fabri, 
  345 S.C. 440, 451, 548 S.E.2d 868, 873 (2001).
ISSUE

Did the trial court err in granting 
  summary judgment based solely on its belief that Tillotson 
  was barred from bringing his action in tort because of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-415? 

LAW/ANALYSIS
Tillotson 
  argues the trial court erred in granting summary judgment on the sole basis 
  ofÂ  Â§ 42-1-415.Â  We agree.
Generally, coverage under the Workersâ€™ Compensation 
  Act is dependent on the existence of an employer-employee relationship. Neese 
  v. Michelin Tire Corp., 324 S.C. 465, 471, 478 S.E.2d 91, 94 (Ct. App. 1996). 
  Whether an employer-employee relationship exists is an initial fact to be established 
  prior to applying the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  Nelson v. Yellow Cab Co., 
  343 S.C. 102, 108, 538 S.E.2d 276, 279 (Ct. App. 2000); Dawkins v. Capitol 
  Constr. Co., 250 S.C. 406, 410, 158 S.E.2d 651, 653 (1967); Gray v. Club 
  Group, Ltd., 339 S.C. 173, 184, 528 S.E.2d 435, 441 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  In 
  the absence of such a relationship, the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission lacks 
  jurisdiction.Â  Nelson v. Yellow Cab Co., 343 S.C. at 108, 538 S.E.2d 
  at 279; see also Glass v. Dow Chem. Co., 325 S.C. 198, 
  482 S.E.2d 49 (1997).Â  
In the absence of a statutory provision to the 
  contrary, an injured person who is not an employee, but an independent contractor, 
  is not within the scope of the compensation act.Â  McDowell v. Stilley Plywood 
  Co., 210 S.C. 173, 182, 41 S.E.2d 872, 876 (1947).Â  We find nothing in the 
  record to reflect a finding by the trial court that an employer-employee relationship 
  existed between Tillotson and Builder.
Builder argues that Tillotson, by submitting an 
  insurance certificate that listed Tillotson as an insured, subjected himself 
  to the jurisdiction of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act through S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 42-1-415(a). This section provides:

Notwithstanding any other provision of law, upon the submission 
  of documentation to the commission that a contractor or subcontractor has represented 
  himself to a higher tier subcontractor, contractor, or project owner as having 
  workersâ€™ compensation insurance at the time the contractor or subcontractor 
  was engaged to perform work, the higher tier subcontractor, contractor, or project 
  owner must be relieved of any and all liability under this title except as specifically 
  provided in this section. In the event that employer is uninsured, regardless 
  of the number of employees that employer has, the higher tier subcontractor, 
  contractor, project owner, or his insurance carrier shall in the first instance 
  pay all benefits due under this title . . . Any disputes arising as a result 
  of claims filed under this section must be determined by the commission.

A court construing a statute 
  must first seek to ascertain and effectuate legislative intent.Â  Koenig v. 
  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Public Safety, 325 S.C. 400, 403, 480 S.E.2d 98, 
  99 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  The cardinal rule of statutory construction is to give 
  words used in a statute their plain and ordinary meaning without resort to subtle 
  or forced construction.Â  Id.Â  The language must be read to harmonize 
  its subject matter with its general purpose.Â  Id.Â  â€œIn construing statutory 
  language, the statute must be read as a whole, and sections which are part of 
  the same general statutory law must be construed together and each one given 
  effect, if it can be done by any reasonable construction.â€Â  Higgins v. State, 
  307 S.C. 446, 449, 415 S.E.2d 799, 801 (1992); see also Jackson 
  v. Charleston Cty. Sch. Dist., 316 S.C. 177, 181, 447 S.E.2d 859, 861 (1994) 
  (â€œThe true guide to statutory construction is not the phraseology of an isolated 
  section or provision, but the language of the statute as a whole considered 
  in the light of its manifest purpose.â€).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Builder, in advancing its argument, 
  concentrates on the first portion and the last sentence of Â§ 42-1-415(a).Â  Builder 
  argues it is not liable to Tillotson because Tillotson represented himself as 
  having workersâ€™ compensation insurance at the time it engaged him to work.Â  
  Builder also argues the last sentence of the statute vests the adjudication 
  of any dispute in the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission, not the circuit court.Â  
  We disagree.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
When read in its entirety and 
  in harmony with the other statutes within the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, Â§ 42-1-415(a) 
  is inapplicable to this case.Â  First, the statute itself makes clear its purpose 
  is to ensure that statutory employees are protected, although their immediate 
  employer may have misrepresented to a contractor that it had workersâ€™ compensation 
  insurance.Â  The section removes liability from the contractor except in certain 
  circumstances.Â  
Importantly, in keeping with 
  the statutory employee doctrine, Â§ 42-1-415(a) requires the upstream contractor 
  initially pay all benefits due to the subcontractorâ€™s injured employee.Â  The 
  contractor may then petition to transfer responsibility of future payments to 
  the Uninsured Employersâ€™ Fund.Â  In addition, the contractor may be reimbursed 
  by the Fund.Â  
The section may be viewed as 
  enforcing the statutory employee doctrine even when a subcontractor commits 
  fraud by stating it has workersâ€™ compensation coverage.Â  The purpose of the 
  section is further clarified when read in context of surrounding statutes.Â  
  Each section, from Â§ 42-1-410 to 450, deals with certain aspects of the statutory 
  employee doctrine.Â  Section 42-1-415 is principally concerned with protecting 
  a subcontractorâ€™s injured employees.Â  
Additionally, Builderâ€™s reliance 
  on the last sentence in Â§ 42-1-415 (a) is misguided. The sentence states â€œ[a]ny 
  disputes arising as a result of claims filed under this section must 
  be determined by the commission.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 41-1-415 (Supp. 2002) (emphasis 
  added).Â  Tillotson did not file a claim that can be construed as a Â§ 42-1-415 
  claim. Further, absent the existence of an employer-employee relationship, Tillotson 
  cannot file a workersâ€™ compensation claim. 
Accordingly, 
  we reverse the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment and remand this case 
  to the trial court for a determination of whether an employer-employee relationship 
  exists and for any further action appropriate for the disposition of this case.
REVERSED 
  AND REMANDED.
HOWARD, 
  J. and JEFFERSON, A.J. concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Ellie, Inc.,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Ronald R. Miccichi,       
Respondent,
      
    
  



  
    
      
Ronald R. Miccichi and Ronco of Charleston, Inc.,       
Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Ellie, Inc., Maple Games, Inc. and Robert
Stefani, Sr.,        Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Roger M. Young, Master-in-Equity

Opinion No. 3741
Heard January 13, 2004 â€“ Filed February 
  2, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Francis T. Draine, of Columbia, for Appellants.
Justin Oâ€™Toole Lucey, of Mount Pleasant, for Respondents.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  Ellie, Inc., and Ronald R. 
  Miccichi and Ronco of Charleston, Inc., filed competing claims of breach of 
  contract and sought a declaratory judgment on the status of the lease between 
  the parties.Â  The trial court denied all claims by Ellie and found Ellie had 
  breached the lease.Â  The court concluded the breach was accompanied by fraudulent 
  acts and awarded actual and punitive damages, 
  [1]  Miccichi validly terminated the lease, and Stefani was personally liable 
  under his Guaranty.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Miccichi owned and ran Sports, a bar in 
  Mount Pleasant.Â  Robert Stefani and Miccichi entered negotiations regarding 
  Stefani taking over the barâ€™s operations.Â  Stefani established Ellie, Inc., 
  for management of the bar.Â  Miccichi, on behalf of Ronco, and Stefani, acting 
  for Ellie, signed a Management Agreement in July 1995, in which Ellie was hired 
  to operate the bar.Â  The agreement outlined the basic responsibilities and compensation 
  to Ellie.Â  Attached to the Agreement was an Addendum dealing with equipment 
  rental and the installation and maintenance of video gaming machines by Miccichi.Â  
  Under the Addendum, Ellie received nominal compensation for handling the daily 
  payouts for the machines, but did not acquire any portion of the profits.
Simultaneously, Miccichi, as owner of the property, 
  and Ellie entered into a Lease Option Agreement.Â  Ellie was granted the option 
  to lease and operate Sports for five years with possibilities of renewal for 
  three five-year terms.Â  The agreement set forth several acts of default, the 
  failure to observe, keep and perform any of the duties contained within the 
  lease after sixty days notice.Â  Miccichi was given the power to extinguish the 
  lease for default with fifteen days notice.Â  Miccichi signed the lease, but 
  enclosed a corporate authorization by Ronco, indicating he was the president 
  and had authority to sign.Â  An identical Addendum to the one appended to the 
  Management Agreement was attached to the Lease Option Agreement.
Contemporaneously, Stefani executed a 
  Guaranty and non-compete contract.Â  He personally guaranteed the payments required 
  under the lease, and up to $30,000.00 in liquidated damages in the event of 
  Ellieâ€™s default.Â  Stefani signed the Guaranty individually and as president 
  of Ellie.
The parties executed a first amendment 
  on December 18, 1995, which expressly modified the Addendum to the Lease Option 
  and Management Agreements.Â  The amendment established Ellieâ€™s first shares of 
  revenue from video gaming.Â  Ronco would purchase a five-seat gaming machine 
  and the profits would be divided.Â  Ellie would maintain the machine and the 
  payouts.Â  The amendment also ratified the existing contracts and expressly enunciated 
  that the Guaranty remained in full effect. 
A second amendment on April 4, 1996, had 
  more efficacy upon the original agreements.Â  It altered the Lease Option Agreement 
  to allow for installment payments of the fees in the event it was exercised.Â  
  Additionally, it changed some of the equipment rental provisions.Â  The parties 
  agreed a second video gaming machine would be purchased and the parties would 
  share revenues of the second machine.Â  Finally, the amendment acknowledged that 
  the prior agreements remained in effect.
Several months after this amendment, Stefani exercised 
  the Lease Option.Â  Therefore, the Management Agreement was no longer in effect.Â  
  However, there is no indication Stefani was released from the Guaranty as it 
  also applied to the financial responsibilities of Ellie under the Lease Option 
  contract.
Ronco and Miccichi presented a third amendment 
  on July 6, 1998, which provided Ellie a share of all the gaming machinesâ€™ revenues.Â  
  The amendment defined net revenues, and allocated twenty percent to Ellie.Â  
  Miccichi and Ronco retained ownership of the machines, but Ellie was responsible 
  for twenty percent of certain costs, including licenses. Additionally, Ellie 
  was to handle daily collection of money from the machines, insure the collections, 
  and report any problems to Ronco.
On September 28, 1998, the parties adjusted the 
  amount of gaming proceeds being paid to Ellie, as well as allowed Ronco to lease 
  no more than twenty percent of the building for gaming use.Â  This fourth agreement 
  indicated that the revenues allocated to Ellie would pass on to any sublet tenant.Â  
  The agreement further established that the cost of all new machines would be 
  paid off before any profits are distributed. 
The parties next signed off on a â€œletter . . . 
  for the purpose of clarifying the relationship between Ronco/Ron Micciche [sic] 
  and Ellie/Bob Stefani with regard to the operation of video gambling machines 
  . . . .â€Â  The agreement, dated December 2, 1998, allocated seventy-five percent 
  of the first $500,000.00 in net revenue to Ronco.Â  Once net revenue surpassed 
  $500,000.00, the parties divided the revenue evenly.Â  Ellie/Stefani continued 
  to pay twenty-five percent of the expenses, and the parties agreed to add additional 
  rooms onto the property for gaming.Â  The rooms would be paid for seventy-five 
  percent by Ronco and twenty-five percent by Ellie.Â  The agreement included a 
  provision, which made the terms transferable with Ronco having the right of 
  first refusal on any offer.Â  Finally, the contract included a provision, which 
  read:Â  â€œThis agreement is binding on Ellie and Ronco and replaces any previous 
  agreement(s) between these parties.â€
The final amendment on May 1, 1999 introduced 
  a new company, Maple Games, Inc., into the collection of money and sharing of 
  revenues.Â  Maple was owned and operated by Stefani.Â  The amendment continued 
  the $500,000.00 revenue threshold and split Stefaniâ€™s share between Maple and 
  Ellie.Â  The amendment also included a provision allowing for a higher share 
  of revenue for Stefani in the summer months.Â  The provision was not contained 
  in the previous amendment.Â  Finally, the amendment defined net revenue as total 
  income less total payouts and Miccichi wrote in â€œless expenses!â€ that was not 
  objected to by Stefani prior to Miccichi signing.
 The partiesâ€™ disagreements centered around 
  the video gaming and their sharing of revenues.Â  In October 1999, Stefani claimed 
  the revenues had reached the $500,000.00 level at which time the revenues were 
  split evenly.Â  Miccichi wanted an accounting to verify the revenue figures, 
  and claimed Stefani excluded expenses, which should have reduced the net revenues.Â  
  After reviewing the reconciliation, Miccichi identified two â€œphantom entriesâ€ 
  on dates where he knew no reconciliation had been performed because he and his 
  daughter were out of the country on vacation.
In striving to analyze the reports, Miccichi 
  requested additional information to support the figures.Â  Miccichi also attempted 
  to retake control of the collection process.Â  He sent a locksmith to the premises 
  to change the locks on the machines, but Stefani refused the locksmith admittance.
Furthermore, the parties disputed the meaning of 
  the â€œmerger clauseâ€ in the letter clarifying their relationship.Â  Miccichi sent 
  a letter asking Stefaniâ€™s opinion regarding the status of the lease.Â  An additional
