  just that it was not pled.Â  Finally, Stefaniâ€™s motion to alter or amend did 
  not raise the issue of whether the Guaranty was properly pled.Â  As we find the 
  issue regarding the applicability of the Guaranty was tried by consent, we affirm 
  the decision of the Master requiring payment of $30,000.00 by Stefani.
Stefani contends the Guaranty was merged out of 
  existence and, therefore, Ronco and Miccichi could not collect damages.Â  In 
  the brief, Ellie and Stefani fail to cite any supporting authority for the position, 
  and all arguments made are merely conclusory statements.Â  South Carolina Appellate 
  Court Rules specify what is required in the arguments section for an appellantâ€™s 
  brief:Â  â€œThe brief shall be divided into as many parts as there are issues to 
  be argued.Â  At the head of each part, the particular issue to be addressed shall 
  be set forth in distinctive type, followed by discussion and citations of authority.â€Â  
  Rule 208(b)(1)(D), SCACR.Â  Numerous cases have held that where an issue is not 
  argued within the body of the brief but is only a short conclusory statement, 
  it is abandoned on appeal.Â  Glasscock, Inc. v. United States Fid. & Guar. 
  Co., 348 S.C. 76, 81, 557 S.E.2d 689, 691 (Ct. App. 2001); R & G 
  Constr., Inc. v. Lowcountry Regâ€™l Transp. Auth., 343 S.C. 424, 437, 540 
  S.E.2d 113, 120 (Ct. App. 2000); Welch v. Epstein, 342 S.C. 279, 288 
  n.1, 536 S.E.2d 408, 412 n.1 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  We find Stefani and Ellie abandoned 
  the issue on appeal.
IV.Â Â Â  Concealment and other Findings of Fact
Stefani maintains the Master made several errors 
  in his findings of fact.Â  He asserts these errors detail a bias on the part 
  of the judge.Â  Finally, he contends the Master erred in concluding Stefani concealed 
  income from the gaming machines.Â  We find no evidence of bias on the part of 
  the Master and rule his finding of fact that Ellie concealed income was supported 
  by ample evidence.
Stefani first asserts the trial court erred in 
  finding: â€œThe Lease had been amended, modified, and/or superceded by a number 
  of later agreements, giving rise to a dispute as to what agreements were in 
  effect in 1999.â€Â  Stefani avers the Lease Option Agreement played no part in 
  the partiesâ€™ dispute, and the only controversy was regarding the video gaming 
  revenues.Â  
However, there is ample evidence in the record 
  showing Miccichi, through his counsel, requested a statement from Stefani as 
  to what agreements were in effect and whether the merger agreement applied to 
  the lease.Â  Stefaniâ€™s counsel refused to issue a response regarding what agreements 
  were in effect, and instead answered:Â  â€œGiven the present conflict between the 
  parties, my client will not set forth a blanket statement of its position regarding 
  the merger clause.Â  Instead, the applicability and affect [sic] of the clause 
  will have to be determined on a case by case basis if, and when, a conflict 
  arises between two competing agreements.â€Â  While much of the dispute did involve 
  the gaming revenues, there were further questions regarding what agreements 
  were controlling.Â  The finding of fact challenged by Stefani plays little to 
  no part in the ultimate decision of the Master.Â  Regardless, there is evidence 
  in the record to support the finding of the Master.
Stefani next asseverates the Master erred in finding 
  he â€œundertook a course of conduct to leverage and cause Miccichi to give him 
  a share in the revenue.â€Â  Again, the finding of fact is not highly relevant 
  to the ultimate conclusion of the Master.Â  However, we rule it was supported 
  by evidence in the record.Â  Testimony was presented that gaming machines were 
  unplugged or had other problems prior to Stefani being given a share of the 
  machines revenues.Â  A provision in one of the agreements specifically required 
  the machines to stay plugged in during operating hours.Â  The above evidence 
  supports the Masterâ€™s finding of fact.
Next, Stefani contends the trial court erred in 
  finding:Â  â€œHaving Ellie report its computation of money owed first served as 
  a check and balance system to Miccichiâ€™s numbers . . . . Stefani stopped giving 
  Kate his spread sheet [sic], and then stopped giving his numbers first, subtly 
  inducing her to give her numbers from the period Z tapes first.â€Â  Miccichi testified 
  that Stefani gave him the revenue reports, and then they would be reconciled 
  with Miccichiâ€™s reports.Â  His daughter averred that Stefani would get her report 
  first or would not give her a report at all during the reconciliation.Â  Finally, 
  the main conflict over the money reported compared to the money received originated 
  when Miccichi discovered entries in Stefaniâ€™s records for dates when Miccichi 
  and his daughter were both out of town.Â  We find there was evidence presented 
  to support the conclusion of the Master.
Finally, Stefani argues the Master erred in ruling 
  he concealed money from Miccichi.Â  However, there is evidence in the record 
  to support the finding that money was concealed and Stefani had a duty to report 
  the money to Miccichi.
Stefani improperly recorded money on several occasions, 
  and because of the resets, Ellie had more money on hand than it was supposed 
  to collect.Â  The Master found Ellie had additional money and had a duty to disclose 
  that to Miccichi.Â  
â€œThe duty to disclose may be reduced to three distinct 
  classes: (1) where it arises from a preexisting definite fiduciary relation 
  between the parties; (2) where one party expressly reposes a trust and confidence 
  in the other with reference to the particular transaction in question, or else 
  from the circumstances of the case, the nature of their dealings, or their position 
  towards each other, such a trust and confidence in the particular case is necessarily 
  implied; (3) where the very contract or transaction itself, in its essential 
  nature, is intrinsically fiduciary and necessarily calls for perfect good faith 
  and full disclosure without regard to any particular intention of the parties.â€Â  
  Regions Bank v. Schmauch, 354 S.C. 648, 673-74, 582 S.E.2d 432, 445-46 
  (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œParties in a fiduciary relationship must fully disclose to 
  each other all known information that is significant and material, and when 
  this duty to disclose is triggered, silence may constitute fraud.â€Â  Anthony 
  v. Padmar, Inc., 320 S.C. 436, 449, 465 S.E.2d 745, 752 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  
  â€œNondisclosure is fraudulent when there is a duty to speak.â€Â  Ardis v. Cox, 
  314 S.C. 512, 517, 431 S.E.2d 267, 270 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  â€œNon-disclosure becomes 
  fraudulent concealment only when it is the duty of the party having knowledge 
  of the facts to make them known to the other party to the transaction.â€Â  Lawson 
  v. Citizens S. Natl.Â  Bank of S.C., 259 S.C. 477, 481-82, 193 S.E.2d 124, 
  126 (1972); accord Manning v. Dial, 271 S.C. 79, 83, 245 S.E.2d 
  120, 122 (1978); Jacobson v. Yaschik, 249 S.C. 577, 585, 155 S.E.2d 601, 
  605 (1967).Â  
Under the July 1998 agreement, Ellie was responsible 
  for collecting the money from the machines and the agreement stated:Â  â€œIf Ellie 
  withholds any money taken from the machines it will be considered theft . . 
  . .â€Â  The concealment by Ellie of the additional money in its possession amounted 
  to a breach of contract and a fraudulent concealment.Â  

The courtâ€™s order states:Â  
This court finds that while there is no direct evidence 
  that Stefani unlawfully took the money out of the machines and caused the resets, 
  there is substantial circumstantial evidence that proves Ellie, either through 
  Stefani or one of its other agents, did so.
Â . . . .
The handling of another personâ€™s cash is intrinsically fiduciary.Â  
  The operation of the contract necessarily relied in part upon Stefaniâ€™s honesty.Â  
  Silence in the face of these duties constituted concealment and fraudulent activity.

We find evidence in the record to support the ruling 
  by the trial court that Ellie had additional money on hand.Â Â  Stefani had a 
  duty to report it or turn it over to Miccichi, failed to perform on that duty, 
  and therefore, concealed money from Miccichi.Â Â  
V.Â Â Â Â Â  Laches, Equitable Estoppel, and Waiver
Finally, Appellants maintain the trial 
  court erred in not holding Respondents waived their right to complain about 
  the additional revenues in Ellieâ€™s possession, or in the alternative, Respondents 
  were barred from asserting the breaches by operation of the doctrine of laches 
  or equitable estoppel.Â  We disagree.
First, the issue may not be preserved 
  for review on appeal.Â  The Master did not specifically rule on any of the doctrines 
  in his final order.Â  The motion to alter or amend does not appear in the record, 
  and the transcript of the hearing does not evidence the fact that these doctrines 
  were specifically raised to the trial court.Â  As such, they would not be preserved 
  for review on appeal.Â  
â€œIt is well-settled that an issue cannot be raised 
  for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by 
  the trial court to be preserved for appellate review.â€Â  Staubes v. City of 
  Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (citing Creech 
  v. South Carolina Wildlife and Marine Res. Depâ€™t, 328 S.C. 24, 491 S.E.2d 
  571 (1997)).Â  â€œError preservation requirements are intended â€˜to enable the lower 
  court to rule properly after it has considered all relevant facts, law, and 
  arguments.â€™â€Â  Id. (citing I'on v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 
  406, 422, 526 S.E.2d 716, 724 (2000)); 4 C.J.S. Appeal and Error Â§ 213 
  (1993)).Â  â€œWithout an initial ruling by the trial court, a reviewing court simply 
  would not be able to evaluate whether the trial court committed error.â€Â  Id.Â  
  â€œIt is well settled that . . . an appellate court cannot address an issue unless 
  it was raised to, and ruled upon by, the trial court.â€Â  Smith v. Phillips, 
  318 S.C. 453, 455, 458 S.E.2d 427, 429 (1995) (emphasis added) (citing Beaufort 
  County v. Butler, 316 S.C. 465, 451 S.E.2d 386 (1994)).Â  See Wilder 
  Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic 
  that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been 
  raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€). 

On the merits, every indication was that Miccichi 
  trusted Stefani and relied upon Ellie through Stefani to keep proper records.Â  
  Stefani was under obligation to report deviations and not withhold excess money.Â  
  Miccichi found out about the discrepancies in the record keeping as soon as 
  disagreements between the parties began.Â  He immediately took steps to examine 
  the records, including requesting Stefaniâ€™s records and attempting to take control 
  of the collection process.Â  Appellants give no indication that the additional 
  money in Ellieâ€™s possession could have been discovered sooner.Â  There is sufficient 
  evidence to support the conclusion that Respondents did not waive their right 
  to complain about the breaches, nor do the doctrines of equitable estoppel or 
  laches prevent them from maintaining Appellants breached the contract.
CONCLUSION
We find the Lease Option and the numerous 
  subsequent agreements form one contract under which the parties were operating 
  at the time their dispute arose in 1999.Â  Appellants have breached various provisions 
  of the contract, including the video gaming provisions relating to the collection 
  and distribution of revenues.Â  These breaches are sufficient justification for 
  the termination of the lease.Â  We conclude the personal Guaranty signed by Stefani 
  was still in existence and enforceable.Â  The Master correctly found Stefani 
  liable for up to $30,000.00 of damages.Â  Respondents did not waive their right 
  to argue the retention of the money by Appellants was a breach of the contract, 
  and neither the doctrine of equitable estoppel nor laches apply to bar the termination 
  of the lease.Â  Based on our standard of review, we find there was evidence to 
  support the findings of the Master.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the Master 
  is 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and HOWARD, JJ., concur.

 
   
    [1]  The only issues on appeal are whether: (1) the lease was validly 
    terminated; (2) Stefaniâ€™s Guaranty is enforceable; and (3) if several factual 
    findings were supported by the evidence.Â  Neither Stefani nor Ellie has appealed 
    the actual award of damages as a result of the breaches by Stefani.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Larry Dean McCluney,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Cherokee County
J. Cordell Maddox, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3742
Heard January 14, 2004 â€“ Filed February 
  2, 2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
Jack B. Swerling, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson 
  and Assistant Attorney General David Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
  Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.:Â  Larry Dean McCluney was convicted of trafficking in â€œmore 
  than 400 grams of cocaine.â€Â  The trial judge sentenced McCluney to twenty-five 
  years imprisonment and a $200,000 fine.Â  McCluney appeals.Â  We reverse.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In February of 1999, Glenn Hadden, a drug dealer, had a conversation 
  with Scott Simmons â€œabout transferring a large quantity of cocaineâ€ to Simmons.Â  
  Shannon Randolph, Haddenâ€™s friend to whom he sold drugs, introduced Hadden to 
  Simmons.Â  Hadden advised Simmons that he could sell him two or three kilograms 
  of cocaine.Â  The two men reached an agreement whereby Hadden would sell â€œtwo 
  kilos of cocaineâ€ to Simmons for $40,000.
Hadden contacted Lieutenant David Oglesby, with the Cherokee County 
  Sheriffâ€™s Department, and informed him of the drug deal with Simmons.Â  Hadden 
  agreed to work as a confidential informant in this drug transaction.Â  The police 
  then tape recorded Haddenâ€™s next phone call to Simmons.Â  During the phone conversation, 
  Simmons stated that someone from Shelby, North Carolina would be arriving in 
  a black Lexus with the money for the transaction.Â  At trial, Simmons testified 
  the person he was referring to was McCluney.
Hadden arranged to meet with Simmons at a secluded location.Â  Hadden was accompanied 
  by an undercover police officer carrying two blocks of imitation cocaine.Â  Immediately 
  prior to the transaction, Simmons met McCluney and another individual at Brownâ€™s 
  Store, a local gas station.Â  McCluney, a native of Shelby, North Carolina, was 
  driving a black Lexus.Â  Police arrested McCluney at Brownâ€™s Store after Simmons 
  and Hadden completed the drug transaction. 
At trial, defense counsel cross-examined Hadden about the circumstances of 
  the drug transaction.Â  Specifically, counsel asked Hadden whether Shannon Randolph 
  â€œsaid that Simmons was looking for two kilos of cocaine.â€Â  Hadden responded: 
  â€œSomething to that effect.â€Â  At that point, the following exchange occurred:

[The State]:Â  Objection as to what that person may have 
  said.
[Defense Counsel]:Â  This goes to the state of mind of this 
  witness, Your Honor, because heâ€™s the one that ultimately took the ball at that 
  point and ran with it.
[The State]:Â  Iâ€™m not sure how state of mind is relative, 
  based on that conversation.
The Court:Â  Sustained.

At the close of the Stateâ€™s case, defense counsel moved for a directed 
  verdict arguing that, as the substance in this case was imitation cocaine, the 
  State failed to prove the criminal offense of trafficking cocaine.Â  Defense 
  counsel contended that our Supreme Court, in Murdock v. State, 311 S.C. 
  16, 426 S.E.2d 740 (1992), held â€œit is not illegal . . . to possess imitation 
  drugs with intent to distribute.â€Â  The trial judge denied the motion for a directed 
  verdict, finding that (1) Murdock was based on a narrow set of facts 
  and (2) the trafficking statute was very broadly written.
ISSUES

I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial judge err in denying McCluneyâ€™s motion 
  for a directed verdict?
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Did the trial judge err in refusing to allow defense 
  counsel to cross-examine Simmons regarding the mandatory nature of the sentence 
  provided for the crime charged?
III.Â Â Â Â  Did the trial judge err in finding Haddenâ€™s testimony 
  was inadmissible hearsay?

LAW/ANALYSIS
Directed 
  Verdict
McCluney contends the trial judge erred in denying his motion for a directed 
  verdict because, as the substance involved was imitation cocaine, the State 
  was unable to present evidence of trafficking in cocaine.Â  We agree.
On appeal from the denial of a directed verdict in a criminal case, an appellate 
  court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the State.Â  State 
  v. Walker, 349 S.C. 49, 562 S.E.2d 313 (2002); State v. Al-Amin, 
  353 S.C. 405, 578 S.E.2d 32 (Ct. App. 2003); State v. Morgan, 352 S.C. 
  359, 574 S.E.2d 203 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  When ruling on a motion for a directed 
  verdict, the trial court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of 
  evidence, not its weight. State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 564 S.E.2d 87 
  (2002); State v. Wilds, 355 S.C. 269, 584 S.E.2d 138 (Ct. App. 2003); 
  State v. McLauren, 349 S.C. 488, 563 S.E.2d 346 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  If 
  there is any direct evidence or any substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably 
  tending to prove the guilt of the accused, this Court must find the case was 
  properly submitted to the jury.Â  State v. Harris, 351 S.C. 643, 572 S.E.2d 
  267 (2002); State v. Condrey, 349 S.C. 184, 562 S.E.2d 320 (Ct. App. 
  2002).Â  On the other hand, a defendant is entitled to a directed verdict when 
  the State fails to produce evidence of the offense charged.Â  State v. McKnight, 
  352 S.C. 635, 576 S.E.2d 168 (2003); State v. McHoney, 344 S.C. 85, 544 
  S.E.2d 30 (2001); State v. Padgett, 354 S.C. 268, 580 S.E.2d 159 (Ct. 
  App. 2003).Â  
An â€œimitation controlled substanceâ€ is defined as a â€œnoncontrolled 
  substance which is represented to be a controlled substance and is packaged 
  in a manner normally used for the distribution or delivery of an illegal controlled 
  substance.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-110 (2002).Â  In contrast, a â€œcounterfeit 
  substanceâ€ is defined as:

a controlled substance which, or the container or labeling 
  of which, without authorization, bears the trademark, trade name, or other identifying 
  mark, imprint, number, or device, or any likeness thereof, of a manufacturer, 
  distributor, or dispenser other than the person who, in fact, manufactured, 
  distributed, or dispensed such substance and which, thereby, falsely purports 
  or is represented to be the product of, or to have been distributed by, such 
  other manufacturer, distributor, or dispenser.

Id.
Lieutenant Oglesby testified the substance used in the 
  drug transaction was imitation cocaine.Â  Specifically, Oglesby stated the substance 
  was â€œfake cocaine.â€Â  That is, the substance was primarily â€œground upâ€ salt and 
  flour mixed with other substances such as caffeine, lidocaine, and benzocaine.Â  
  However, McCluney was indicted under the trafficking statute, S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 44-53-370 (2002 & Supp. 2003), which refers to only the trafficking of 
  controlled or counterfeit substances.Â  Imitation controlled substances, such 
  as the imitation cocaine used in the present case, are not mentioned in Â§ 44-53-370.Â  
  In fact, the only indictable offense applicable to imitation cocaine would be 
  under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-390(a)(6) (2002), the statute prohibiting the delivery 
  or distribution of imitation controlled substances.Â  Section 44-53-390(a)(6)(A) 
  provides: â€œIt is unlawful for a person knowingly or intentionally to . . . distribute 
  or deliver . . . an imitation controlled substance with the expressed or implied 
  representation that the substance is a narcotic . . . controlled substance . 
  . . .â€Â  Section 44-53-390(a)(6) differs from the general trafficking statute 
  in that the offense of distribution or delivery of imitation controlled substances 
  is not keyed to weight, whereas the trafficking statute is dependent upon it.Â  
  Unlike the mandatory sentence of twenty-five years imprisonment for trafficking 
  in controlled or counterfeit substances, the maximum sentence for delivery or 
  distribution of imitation controlled substances is five years imprisonment and 
  a $10,000 fine.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-390(b) (2002).
The Supreme Court explained the difference between imitation and counterfeit 
  substances in Murdock v. State, 311 S.C. 16, 426 S.E.2d 740 (1992).Â  
  In Murdock, the defendant was found in possession of â€œwhat was believed 
  to be cocaine and . . . LSD.â€Â  SLED tested the substances and determined they 
  were not controlled substances.Â  The defendant subsequently pled guilty to two 
  counts of possession of a counterfeit substance with intent to distribute.Â  
  Id. at 17-18, 426 S.E.2d at 741.Â  The Court declared:

This case revolves around the confusion between â€œcounterfeitâ€ and â€œimitationâ€ 
  substances.Â  [Defendant] was indicted for two counts of possession with intent 
  to distribute a counterfeit substance.
â€œCounterfeit substanceâ€ means a controlled substance which, or the container 
  or labeling of which, without authorization, bears the trademark, trade name, 
  or other identifying mark, imprint, number, or device, or any likeness thereof, 
  of a manufacturer, distributor, or dispenser other than the person who in fact 
  manufactured, distributed, or dispenses such substance and which thereby falsely 
  purports or is represented to be the product of, or to have been distributed 
  by, such other manufacturer, distributor, or dispenser.
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-110 (1985).
The drugs found in [defendantâ€™s] possession were not counterfeit drugs.Â  They 
  were imitation drugs.
â€œImitation controlled substanceâ€ means a noncontrolled substance which is represented 
  to be a controlled substance and is packaged in a manner normally used for the 
  distribution or delivery of an illegal controlled substance.
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-110 (1985).Â  We take this opportunity to clarify the 
  practical difference between counterfeit and imitation substances.Â  While there 
  may be exceptions, such as when these substances are legally used for legitimate 
  medical purposes, ordinarily there is no offense involving counterfeit 
  LSD or cocaine, as these drugs are typically produced illegally and, therefore, 
  usually do not have a trademark or label of a manufacturer.

Id. at 18, 426 S.E.2d at 742 (emphasis in original).Â  After noting the 
  differences in the statutory definitions of these substances, the Court found 
  the defendant had not committed a crime because â€œit is not a criminal offense 
  to possess imitation drugs with the intent to distribute.Â  It is illegal 
  only to actually distribute or deliver imitation drugs.â€Â  Id. at 18-19, 
  426 S.E.2d at 742 (emphasis in original).
Given the differences between sections 44-53-370 and 44-53-390, we find the 
  trial judge erred in denying McCluneyâ€™s motion for a directed verdict. Â Imitation 
  cocaine, the substance at issue in this case, is not a counterfeit substance 
  and does not fall under the purview of the trafficking statute.Â  This error 
  was compounded by the trial judgeâ€™s jury charge on trafficking.Â  The judge did 
  not charge the jury that the substance at issue in this case was imitation cocaine.Â  
  Rather, he referred to the substance as counterfeit five times in the jury charge.
CONCLUSION
We reverse the trial judgeâ€™s denial of McCluneyâ€™s 
  motion for a directed verdict because, as McCluney was in possession of imitation 
  cocaine, he was improperly indicted under the trafficking statute.Â  We do NOT 
  reach any other issues.Â  Based on the foregoing, McCluneyâ€™s conviction and sentence 
  is
REVERSED.
 GOOLSBY, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Richard N. Kennedy,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Scott Edward Griffin and Dick Simon Trucking, Inc.,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Cherokee County
Gary E. Clary, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3743
Heard November 5, 2003 â€“ Filed February 
  3, 2004Â Â Â 

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Kenneth L. Holland, of Gaffney, for Appellant
William S. Brown, of Greenville, for
Respondent(s).
      
    
  

 CONNOR, J.:Â  Richard Kennedy appeals 
  the trial judgeâ€™s denial of his motion for a new trial based upon: (1) the admission 
  of a blood test showing marijuana was in his system at the time of his automobile 
  accident; and (2) the trial judgeâ€™s jury instruction regarding the per 
  se negligence statute.Â  We reverse and remand.Â  
FACTS
On May 29, 1998, Kennedy was driving his pickup 
  truck on U.S. Route 29 in Cherokee County, approaching the intersection with 
  Secondary Road 164.Â Â  Scott Griffin was driving an eighteen-wheeler truck in 
  the scope of his employment with Dick Simon Trucking, Inc., on Secondary Road 
  164.Â Â  At the intersection, Griffin pulled out in front of Kennedy to make a 
  left turn onto U.S. Route 29.Â  Kennedyâ€™s truck collided with the rear set of 
  tires on the trailer of Griffinâ€™s truck.Â Â  The weather was clear on the day 
  of the accident.Â Â  
Maxie Littlejohn witnessed Kennedy applying his brakes at 
  the last second before impact, causing Littlejohn to wonder why Kennedy did 
  not slow down to avoid the accident. Â Â The investigating officer found 
  short skid marks in Kennedyâ€™s lane, suggesting Kennedy was not paying attention 
  or panicked and froze before slamming on the brakes.Â Â Â  Griffin testified that 
  he saw Kennedyâ€™s truck and thought he had a safe distance to make the turn.Â Â  
  Kennedy testified that Griffin bolted out in front of him, blocked both lanes 
  of traffic, and then slammed on his brakes, forcing Kennedy to apply his brakes 
  and swerve.Â Â Â Â  
Kennedy was taken to the hospital by ambulance 
  for treatment of his injuries.Â  As part of a routine practice when treating 
  victims of automobile accidents, the emergency room physician performed a blood 
  test on Kennedy to determine if any substances were present in his system that 
  would react adversely to medicines administered to him.Â Â Â  The results of the 
  blood test indicated the presence of marijuana in Kennedyâ€™s blood stream.Â Â  
  The test results did not indicate the level of drugs in Kennedyâ€™s system or 
  how long the drugs had been in his system.Â Â  Nothing in the record indicates 
  that marijuana was found in or around Kennedyâ€™s vehicle or that Kennedy smelled 
  of marijuana.Â  
 Kennedy filed suit against Griffin and 
  Dick Simon Trucking, Inc., seeking to recover damages for negligence.Â  Prior 
  to trial, Kennedy filed a motion in limine to exclude the admission of 
  the blood test analysis showing the presence of marijuana in his system.Â Â Â  
  The judge denied the motion.Â Â  Kennedyâ€™s treating physician later testified 
  before the jury that the toxicology report showed Kennedy had marijuana in his 
  system, but the report did not indicate the level of intoxication or how long 
  the marijuana had been in his system.Â Â  
The trial judge instructed the jury on 
  the law of negligence per se under the driving under the influence 
  statute.Â Â Â  The jury returned a verdict finding Kennedy was seventy percent 
  at fault for the accident and Griffin and Dick Simon Trucking were thirty percent 
  at fault.Â Â  Kennedy, thus, was unable to recover any damages.Â  He moved for 
  a new trial, and the trial judge immediately denied the motion.Â Â  Kennedy appeals. 
  [1] Â  
ISSUES
I. Did the trial judge err in allowing the admission of evidence 
  that Kennedy had marijuana in his system?
II. Did the trial judge err in charging the jury 
  on the law of negligence per se?
SCOPE OF REVIEW
The denial of a motion for a new 
  trial is within the trial judgeâ€™s discretion and will not be reversed on appeal 
  absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Haselden v. Davis, 341 S.C. 486, 495, 
  534 S.E.2d 295, 300 (Ct. App. 2000), affâ€™d, 353 S.C. 481, 579 S.E.2d 
  293 (2003).
DISCUSSION
I. Admission of Marijuana 
  Evidence
Kennedy argues he was entitled to a new trial due 
  to the admission of the toxicology test results into evidence because the probative 
  value of the results was substantially outweighed by undue prejudice.Â Â Â  
â€œEvidence is relevant and admissible if it tends 
  to establish or make more or less probable some matter in issue.â€Â  Hoeffner 
  v. The Citadel, 311 S.C. 361, 365, 429 S.E.2d 190, 192 (1993); Rule 401, 
  SCRE; Rule 402, SCRE.Â  However, otherwise relevant evidence may be excluded 
  where its probative value is â€œsubstantially outweighed by the danger of unfair 
  prejudice, confusion of the issues, or misleading the jury . . . .â€Â  Rule 403, 
  SCRE.Â  â€œUnfair prejudice means an undue tendency to suggest a decision on an 
  improper basis.â€Â  State v. Owens, 346 S.C. 637, 666, 552 S.E.2d 745, 
  760 (2001).Â  A trial judgeâ€™s decision to admit or exclude evidence is within 
  his discretion and will not be disturbed unless an abuse of discretion occurs.Â  
  Pike v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 343 S.C. 224, 234, 540 S.E.2d 87, 92 (2000).
In support of their argument that the 
  trial judge did not err in admitting the blood test results, Griffin and Dick 
  Simon Trucking cite Gulledge v. McLaughlin, 328 S.C. 504, 492 S.E.2d 
  816 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  In Gulledge, this Court discussed the admissibility 
  of blood test results in a car accident case showing the deceased had a blood 
  alcohol content (BAC) of .166.Â  The deceasedâ€™s spouse argued the BAC test result 
  should not have been admitted because, standing alone, it was insufficient to 
  establish impairment.Â  Reviewing the deceasedâ€™s BAC level of .166, testimony 
  from a medical technologist that a BAC level of .4 or .5 would be inconsistent 
  with life, the beer cans and cooler found near the deceasedâ€™s vehicle, and the 
  circumstances of the accident, the Court found there was evidence sufficient 
  for a jury to conclude the deceased was impaired from alcohol consumption at 
  the time of the accident.Â  This Court held the trial judge did not abuse his 
  discretion in admitting the evidence.Â  Gulledge, 328 S.C. at 511-12, 
  492 S.E.2d at 819-20.Â  
The present case is clearly distinguishable 
  from Gulledge.Â  Although Kennedy tested positive for marijuana, the test 
  did not measure the quantity of marijuana in Kennedyâ€™s system or how recently 
  Kennedy had been exposed to marijuana.Â  Unlike the evidence in Gulledge, 
  no evidence in the present case indicated whether the marijuana was of such 
  a level as to impair Kennedyâ€™s judgment.Â  Further, the circumstantial evidence 
  did not support an inference that Kennedy was impaired due to marijuana use.Â  
  No marijuana was found in or near Kennedyâ€™s truck and there was no testimony 
  that Kennedy smelled of marijuana.Â  Although witnesses noticed that Kennedy 
  delayed in applying his brakes, Kennedyâ€™s actions did not necessarily suggest 
  that he was driving under an impairment.Â  
Under these circumstances, evidence of the mere 
  presence of marijuana, without further indication of impairment, could mislead 
  the jury.Â  The admission of this evidence was more prejudicial than probative 
  because there was no correlation between the marijuana and the accident.Â  Accordingly, 
  the trial judge erred in allowing its admission.Â  See Simco v. Ellis, 
  303 F.3d 929, 933-34 (8th Cir. 2002) (holding that evidence of a 
  truck driverâ€™s cocaine use at the time of the accident should have been excluded 
  as prejudicial where the toxicology test did not support a finding of intoxication 
  and the mere mention of cocaine could inflame a jury); State v. McClain, 
  525 So. 2d 420 (Fla. 1988) (finding the trial court did not abuse its discretion 
  in excluding evidence of trace amounts of cocaine in the defendantâ€™s blood where 
  chemist could not express opinion on whether it would have affected defendantâ€™s 
  driving and it would have seriously prejudiced defendant in the eyes of the 
  jury); Martinez v. Graves, 2003 WL 21466962 (Tex. App. 2003) (affirming 
  the trial judgeâ€™s exclusion of evidence of cocaine in the deceasedâ€™s system 
  because the amount of cocaine was not established and there was no correlation 
  between the cocaine and the accident). 
II. Negligence Per Se charge
Kennedy also asserts he was entitled to 
  a new trial because the trial judge erred in charging the law of negligence 
  per se to the jury.Â  
It is unlawful to drive in this State 
  while under the influence of alcohol or drugs.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2930 (1991). 
  [2] Â  A driver is â€œunder the influenceâ€ when ingestion of drugs or alcohol 
  results in the impairment of the driverâ€™s faculties, impairs the driverâ€™s ability 
  to operate the vehicle with reasonable care, or impairs the driverâ€™s ability 
  to drive as a prudent driver would operate the vehicle.Â  State v. Kerr, 
  330 S.C. 132, 143-44, 498 S.E.2d 212, 217 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  
â€œNegligence per se is established by proof 
  that a party violated a statute which has the essential purpose of protecting 
  persons such as the injured party from the kind of harm suffered.â€Â  Gulledge, 
  328 S.C. at 510, 492 S.E.2d at 819 (internal citations omitted); Coleman 
  v. Shaw, 281 S.C. 107, 314 S.E.2d 154 (Ct. App. 1984) (holding that violation 
  of a statute is negligence per se).Â  â€œWhere there is evidence from which 
  the jury can reasonably infer one is in violation of a statute, that evidence 
  will support a charge of that statute.â€Â  Jefferson v. Synergy Gas, Inc., 
  303 S.C. 479, 481, 401 S.E.2d 427, 428 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  A trial judgeâ€™s decisions 
  on jury instructions will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  
  Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 389, 529 S.E.2d 528, 539 (2000).Â  â€œAn 
  abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error 
  of law or, when grounded in factual conclusions, is without evidentiary support.â€Â  
  Id. at 389, 529 S.E.2d at 539 (citations omitted).Â  
Over Kennedyâ€™s objection, the judge charged the 
  jury on negligence per se as follows:

It is unlawful for any person who is a habitual user of narcotic 
  drugs, or any person who is under the influence of intoxicating liquors, narcotic 
  drugs, barbiturates, paraldehydes or drugs, herbs, or any other substance of 
  like character, whether synthetic or natural, to drive any vehicle within this 
  state.
I charge you that violation of any of the provisions of these 
  statutes is negligence as a matter of law.Â  This means that proof of such violation 
  is in itself proof of negligence, so that should you find such violation, your 
  only concern would be whether the violation caused the injury and damage.Â Â  


 There was no evidence in the present case 
  that Kennedy was under the influence of marijuana.Â  As previously discussed, 
  the blood test indicated the presence of the drug but not the level of intoxication.Â  
  No marijuana was found on Kennedy or in his vehicle and no evidence was presented 
  that Kennedy smelled of marijuana.Â  Although there was evidence that Kennedy 
  hesitated before braking, no evidence was presented to support an inference 
  that his ability to drive was impaired from the ingestion of marijuana.Â  There 
  was no evidence that the marijuana in Kennedyâ€™s system was of such a level as 
  to impair his ability to drive with reasonable care, and thus, there was no 
  evidence to support an inference that Kennedy was driving â€œunder the influence.â€Â  

Accordingly, it was error for the trial judge to 
  instruct the jury on the law of negligence per se where no evidence existed 
  showing Kennedy was driving under the influence.Â  See State v. Cooley, 
  342 S.C. 63, 67, 536 S.E.2d 666, 668 (2000) (holding the trial judge erred when 
  he issued a voluntary manslaughter charge because the record contained no evidence 
  supporting a finding of sufficient legal provocation).Â  Further, there is a 
  reasonable probability that the jury based its verdict on the erroneous charge, 
  in conjunction with the erroneous admission of evidence showing marijuana in 
  Kennedyâ€™s system.Â  As such, it is proper to grant a new trial.Â  See Taylor 
  v. State, 312 S.C. 179, 183, 439 S.E.2d 820, 822 (1993) (â€œ[W]e cannot say 
  beyond a reasonable doubt the jury did not base its verdict on the erroneous 
  jury charge . . . Because there is a reasonable possibility that the error contributed 
  to the verdict, we REVERSE.â€).Â  
CONCLUSION
The trial judge in this case erred in 
  allowing the admission of blood test results showing the presence of an unmeasured 
  amount of marijuana in Kennedyâ€™s system absent any other evidence indicating 
  Kennedy was under the influence or driving under an impairment.Â  Similarly, 
  the trial judge erred in charging the jury on negligence per se when 
  there was no evidence that Kennedy was driving â€œunder the influence.â€Â  The trial 
  judge should have granted Kennedyâ€™s motion for a new trial.Â  Accordingly, the 
  juryâ€™s verdict is REVERSED and the matter is REMANDED for a new 
  trial.Â Â Â Â Â  
 REVERSED AND REMANDED.
ANDERSON, J., concurs and GOOLSBY, J., dissents 
  in a separate opinion.
GOOLSBY, J., dissenting: 
I disagree 
  with Kennedyâ€™s argument that the circuit court erred in denying his motion to 
  suppress the blood test.
â€œâ€˜Relevant evidenceâ€™ means 
  evidence having any tendency to make the existence of any fact that is of consequence 
  to the determination of the action more probable or less probable than it would 
  be without the evidence.â€3Â  â€œAll 
  relevant evidence is admissible.â€4 
â€œAlthough relevant, evidence may 
  be excluded if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger 
  of unfair prejudice, confusion of the issues, or misleading the jury, or by 
  considerations of undue delay, waste of time, or needless presentation of cumulative 
  evidence.â€5 
A trial judgeâ€™s decision to admit or exclude evidence 
  is within his discretion and will not be disturbed on appeal unless an abuse 
  of discretion occurs.6 
Evidence showing the presence of drugs in Kennedyâ€™s 
  system at the time of the accident is highly probative of impairment.7Â  

The circumstances surrounding the 
  accident, as in Gulledge v. McLaughlin, 
  [8]  provide corroborating evidence that Kennedy may have been under the 
  influence of marijuana at the time of the accident and supply the basis for 
  the admission of the blood test results.Â  Kennedyâ€™s failure to stop quickly 
  enough to avoid the accident, even though the tractor-trailer was in plain view, 
  and the presence of marijuana in his blood system support an inference of impairment 
  that the jury should have been allowed to consider in determining fault. 
I also disagree with Kennedyâ€™s argument 
  that the judge erred in instructing the jury that a violation of S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 56-5-2930 (Supp. 2002) would constitute negligence per se.
A trial judge should confine jury 
  instructions to the issues raised by the pleadings and supported by the evidence. 
  [9] Â  Here, the question of Kennedyâ€™s negligence was an issue framed by 
  the pleadings and there was evidence that he had marijuana in his system at 
  the time of the accident.  [10] Â  As our supreme court recognized 
  in Field v. Gregory,  [11] 
   a violation of an applicable statute by a motorist is negligence per 
  se.Â  The jury instruction concerning the statute at issue was, therefore, 
  proper.Â  I would affirm.

 
   
    [1]  Â Dick Simon Trucking filed a Chapter 11 Petition on February 25, 
    2002, and an automatic stay was placed on the appeal.Â  The United States Bankruptcy 
    Court for the District of Utah entered an order liquidating Dick Simon Trucking.Â  
    The order further allowed a lifting of the bankruptcy stay to the extent that 
    Kennedy seeks to recover available insurance coverage.Â  

 
   
    [2]  Â This version of section 56-5-2930 was in effect at the time of the 
    May 29, 1998, accident.Â  Effective June 29, 1998, section 56-5-2930 was substantially 
    revised.Â  The new version incorporates the definition of â€œunder the influence.â€Â  
    It provides that it is unlawful to drive while under the influence of alcohol 
    or drugs â€œto the extent that the personâ€™s faculties to drive are materially 
    and appreciably impaired.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2930 (Supp. 2002).Â  

 
  [3]  
  Rule 401, SCRE .

 
  [4]   Rule 402, SCRE.

 
  [5]   Rule 403, SCRE.Â  

 
  [6]  Elledge v. Richland/Lexington 
    Sch. Dist. Five, 352 S.C. 179, 185, 573 S.E.2d 789, 792 (2002) .

 
  [7]  Gulledge v. McLaughlin, 328 S.C. 504, 510, 
    492 S.E.2d 816, 819 (Ct. App. 1997) (holding evidence of blood alcohol content 
    admissible, stating that â€œobviously, evidence of [blood alcohol content] tends 
    to make the existence of [the fact that plaintiff was driving under the influence] 
    more or less probableâ€); see S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-2930 (Supp. 2002) 
    (declaring unlawful the operation of a motor vehicle while under the influence 
    of a narcotic drug); State v. Long, 186 S.C. 439, 446, 195 S.E. 624, 
    627 (1938) Â (holding it is gross and culpable negligence for a drunken person 
    to attempt to operate an automobile upon a public highway).

 
   [8]  Gulledge, 328 S.C. at 510, 492 S.E.2d at 
    819.

 
   [9]Ellison v. Parts Distribs., Inc., 302 S.C. 
    299, 301, 395 S.E.2d 740, 741 (Ct. App. 1990).

 
   [10]  See supra note 5.

 
   [11]  Field v. Gregory, 230 S.C. 39, 44, 94 S.E.2d 
    15, 18 (1956); see also State v. Wong, 486 A.2d 262, 
    268 (N.H. 1984) (holding a person who is proven to have driven an automobile 
    while intoxicated is criminally negligent per se); cf. 
    State v. Kellison, 11 N.W.2d 371, 373 (Iowa 1943) (holding drunken 
    driving in violation of statute is not merely malum prohibitum, 
    but is malum in se); State v. Mouzon, 231 S.C. 
    655, 662, 99 S.E.2d 672, 676 (1957) (holding that driving an automobile on 
    a public highway while intoxicated is not only malum prohibitum 
    but malum in se).

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH 
  CAROLINA
  In the Court of Appeals

 
   
     
       
        The Late Terry Henson, by 
          Harriet Hunt, his Aunt and Appointed Guardian ad Litem and Personal 
          Representative,Â  Appellant,
        v.
        International Paper Company, 
          Georgetown Steel Corporation, The 
          City of Georgetown and Georgetown County, Defendants, Of Whom International 
          Paper Company is, Respondent.
      
    
  

 
  
  Appeal From Georgetown 
    County
    Â Paula H. Thomas, Circuit 
    Court Judge
  
  Opinion 
    No.3745
    Heard December 11, 2003 â€“ 
    Filed February 17, 2004
  
  AFFIRMED

 
   
     
       
         
          
          
        
        
          Gregg E. Meyers, of Charleston 
            and J. David Flowers, of Greenville, for Appellant.
          Sean K. Trundy, of Charleston, 
            for Respondent.
        
      
    
  


  GOOLSBY, J.: This is a wrongful 
    death action brought by Harriet Hunt against the respondent International 
    Paper Company (â€œIPCâ€) and others. [1] Â  The issues on appeal 
    relate to the verdict, which Hunt challenges as inconsistent, and to the trial 
    judgeâ€™s failure to instruct the jury regarding the doctrine of attractive 
    nuisance.Â  We affirm.
  FACTS 
  
  Hunt 
    commenced this action against IPC for the wrongful death of Terry Henson (â€œTerryâ€).Â  
    Huntâ€™s complaint alleged negligence, attractive nuisance, and unguarded dangerous 
    condition.Â  IPC answered, pleading affirmative defenses of comparative negligence 
    and sole negligence of others.
  IPC 
    owns and operates a canal that runs twenty-seven miles through Georgetown 
    County.Â  The canal eventually terminates in the City of Georgetown.Â  Several 
    pumping stations aid the flow of the water through the canal.Â  When water 
    reaches the Church Street pumping station, it rushes through an underground, 
    forty-two-inch pipe at 19,000 gallons per minute.
  Access 
    roads that IPC uses for maintenance run alongside the entire length of the 
    canal.Â  IPC employees travel these roads Monday through Friday, inspecting 
    the canal.Â  With the exception of some small areas near two schools, the canal 
    is not fenced.Â  â€œNO TRESPASSINGâ€ signs, which IPC erected when it constructed 
    the canal, have disappeared.Â  On Saturday, April 25, 1998, there were no signs 
    warning trespassers of the hazard created by the swift, flowing water.

 
  On 
    that day, ten-year-old Terry and his older brother went to the home of Donnie 
    Lippert, a friend.Â  Another friend, Dustin, had been riding his go-cart near 
    the canal and wanted to show the boys something the record describes as â€œa 
    dirt jumping hill.â€Â  The boys walked to the canal and entered the canal property, 
    using a dirt path by a fence that protected the Church Street pumping station. 
    
  The 
    boys eventually walked over to a pipe that spans the canal.Â  Metal bracing, 
    which serves as support for the pipe, gives it the appearance of a bridge.
  The 
    boys used the pipe to cross over to the other side of the canal, where they 
    found a cast net.Â  Terry decided to enter the water, holding on to the cast 
    net while his friends held the other end.Â  After being in the water for a 
    short period, Terry attempted to grab the metal supports to lift himself out 
    of the water.Â  In the process, he slipped and fell back into the water.Â  With 
    his friends unable to hold on to the cast net, the swift current swept Terry 
    away and he drowned.
  IPC 
    knew of at least three other people who had drowned in the canal, two of whom 
    were reportedly good swimmers.
  The 
    trial judge directed a verdict in favor of IPC as to attractive nuisance and 
    submitted the case to the jury, using a verdict form to which no one objected. 
    
  The 
    form consisted of four questions.Â  The first asked whether IPC was negligent 
    and whether its negligence proximately caused Terryâ€™s death.Â  The jury answered 
    â€œyes.â€Â  The second question asked whether Terry was negligent and whether 
    his negligence proximately caused his death.Â  Again, the jury answered â€œyes.â€Â  
    Question three instructed the jury to allocate the percentage of negligence 
    attributable to each party.Â  The jury attributed 75 per cent to Terry and 
    25 per cent to IPC.Â  Question four asked for the total amount of damages sustained 
    by the plaintiff.Â  The jury found $400,000.Â  The question, however, instructed 
    the jury not to reduce the amount of damages by the negligence attributed 
    to Terry.Â  It did not do so.

 
  When 
    the jury reached its verdict, the trial judge instructed the clerk to publish 
    the answers to the verdict form.Â  The clerk read the answers to questions 
    one through three.Â  Once the clerk stated the jury had allocated 75 per cent 
    of the negligence to Terry and 25 per cent to IPC, the trial judge instructed 
    the clerk not to read any further; consequently, the clerk did not publish 
    the juryâ€™s answer to the fourth question in the juryâ€™s presence. 
  After 
    affirming the verdict, the judge asked the parties if there was anything else 
    they wanted from the jury.Â  Receiving negative responses from both parties, 
    she dismissed the jurors.
  Afterward, 
    the judge published the answer to the fourth question.Â  She explained she 
    did not publish the answer earlier because of the percentage of negligence 
    attributed to the child would not have entitled Hunt to a judgment against 
    IPC. 
  
    LAW/ANALYSIS
    I. 
  
  Hunt 
    argues the juryâ€™s verdict is inconsistent and also contends the trial judge 
    erred by discharging the jury before publishing the juryâ€™s answer to the fourth 
    question.
  A.

 
 
  Hunt 
    maintains the verdict was inconsistent because the jury, which experienced 
    confusion concerning certain issues it was to decide, found Terry 75 per cent 
    at fault, damages notwithstanding.
  While 
    it is true the record reflects the jury raised several questions with the 
    trial judge during its deliberations and twice returned to the courtroom for 
    further instructions, the trial judge responded to each question without objection 
    from Hunt. In particular, Hunt did not object to the judgeâ€™s additional instructions 
    on comparative negligence. [2] 
  Regarding the verdict 
    form, the trial judge explained to the jury how it was to complete it.Â  She 
    told the jury:
  

  Now, if you answered number three 
    [which instructed the jury to apportion fault if it found the negligence of 
    both parties proximately caused Terryâ€™s death] and you put a percentage, and 
    this is again for instructions only, if this should happen, you put a percentage 
    of negligence on the part of the deceased, Terry Henson, you do not lower 
    the amount of damages by that percentage.Â  Do not do it.Â  In other words, 
    even if you found negligence on the part [sic] for this question I want to 
    see the total amount of damages.Â  Do you understand what Iâ€™m saying?Â  Do not 
    reduce it by any amount of negligence you might apply.

 
  Hunt did not 
    object to these instructions and, as indicated above, did not object to the 
    verdict form. [3] 

 
  Hunt, 
    however, cites cases concerning inconsistent verdicts or the failure of a 
    jury to follow instructions. [4] Â Â  These cases have no application 
    here.Â  In this instance, the jury rendered a verdict that was consistent on 
    its face with the structure of the form submitted to it and the jury completed 
    the verdict form in accordance with the trial judgeâ€™s instructions.

 
 
  B.

 
 
  Hunt 
    also argues the trial judge erred in discharging the jury before publishing 
    the verdict form to counsel in its entirety.Â  We disagree.
  The trial judge properly determined 
    the jury returned a defense verdict based on the law of comparative negligence 
    and in accordance with her instructions; thus, there was no need to publish 
    the entire verdict form in the juryâ€™s presence. 
    [5] 

 
  II.
  A.
  Tragic as this case is, 
    the trial judge committed no error in directing a verdict in favor of IPC 
    on the issue of attractive nuisance.Â  Settled law supports what the trial 
    judge did. [6] Â  When viewed in the light most favorable to Hunt, 
    [7]  the evidence shows Terry was not attracted to the premises 
    by reason of the canal.Â  He went there for another purpose entirely, i.e., 
    to see â€œa dirt jumping hill.â€Â  The attractive nuisance doctrine â€œis not applicable

  â€“, such authority was not necessary to the decision in the case.Â  Id.
Although in the 
  past this position was accepted by a number of jurisdictions, see United 
  Zinc & Chemical Co. v. Britt, 258 U.S. 268, 42 S.Ct. 299, 66 L.Ed. 615 
  (1922) (holding same), the principle is now generally rejected.Â  See 
  Restatement (Second) of Torts Â§ 339 cmt. b (1965).Â  Section 339 of the Restatement 
  provides:
 
  A possessor of land is subject 
    to liability for physical harm to children trespassing thereon caused by an 
    artificial condition upon the land if
   (a) the place where the condition 
    exists is one upon which the possessor knows or has reason to know that children 
    are likely to trespass, and
   (b) the condition is one of which 
    the possessor knows or has reason to know and which he realizes or should 
    realize will involve an unreasonable risk of death or serious bodily harm 
    to such children, and
   (c) the children because of their 
    youth do not discover the condition or realize the risk involved in intermeddling 
    with it or in coming within the area made dangerous by it, and
   (d) the utility to the possessor 
    of maintaining the condition and the burden of eliminating the danger are 
    slight as compared with the risk to children involved, and
   (e) the possessor fails to exercise 
    reasonable care to eliminate the danger or otherwise to protect the children.

As the drafters 
  of the Restatement explain, â€œ[i]t is now recognized by most of the courts that 
  the basis of the rule is merely the ordinary negligence basis of a duty of reasonable 
  care not to inflict foreseeable harm on another, and that the fact that the 
  child is a trespasser is merely one of the facts to be taken into consideration.â€Â  
  Restatement (Second) of Torts Â§ 339 cmt. b; see also 62 Am. Jur. 2d Premises 
  Â§Â§ 313, 316 (1990) (noting attractiveness requirement has been relegated to 
  little importance, or more commonly, disposed of altogether).
Pre-Hancock cases demonstrate 
  and post-Hancock cases confirm South Carolina has never been one of the 
  few jurisdictions which adhere to this rule.Â  In Perrin v. Rainwater, 
  186 S.C. 181, 195 S.E. 283 (1938), a cause of action under attractive nuisance 
  was stated when a seven-year-old girl, while on appellantâ€™s property for dance 
  class, was attracted to a fire escape and fell to her death.Â  Id. at 
  185-186, 195 S.E. at 284.
Similarly, in Daniels 
  v. Timmons, 216 S.C. 539, 59 S.E.2d 149 (1950), tenants in an apartment 
  complex stated a cause of action for attractive nuisance, when their fifteen-month-old 
  son was attracted to and injured by a defective stairway located on the rented 
  property.Â  Id.; see also Lynch v. Motel Enters., Inc., 
  248 S.C. 490, 151 S.E.2d 435 (1966) (finding it a jury question whether or not 
  child was attracted to the pool in which he drowned).
In Kirven v. 
  Askins, 253 S.C. 110, 169 S.E.2d 139 (1969), a child was injured by being 
  struck with a clod of dirt or clay while on the property of the defendant.Â  
  Id. at 112, 169 S.E.2d at 139.Â  Although it was known to all parties 
  that children frequented the premises, there was no evidence to suggest the 
  children were attracted to the premises by the desire to throw dirt clods.Â  
  Id. at 113-114, 169 S.E.2d at 140.Â  The main issue in Kirven concerned 
  whether the clods of dirt could be considered â€œunreasonably dangerous to children.â€Â  
  Id. at 115, 169 S.E.2d at 141.Â  Based on the facts of the case, the Court 
  found that a clod of dirt â€œwas not a dangerous thing or instrumentality as is 
  required to establish liability under either the attractive nuisance doctrine 
  or the alternate ground of recovery stated in Everett v. White.â€Â  Id. 
  at 117, 169 S.E.2d at 141.
Concerning the 
  prerequisites for sustaining a cause of action based on attractive nuisance, 
  the Kirven Court explicated: â€œ[I]t is necessary that the condition or 
  instrumentality which caused the injury, should have actually attracted the 
  child into danger.Â  It follows that the doctrine is not applicable where the 
  injured child went into the dangerous situation for some other reason.â€Â  Id. 
  at 117, 169 S.E.2d at 142.Â  Had the Court stopped its commentary here, I would 
  be in total agreement, as this is a correct interpretation of the law of attractive 
  nuisance as it has developed in South Carolina.Â  However, the Court went on 
  to quote the language from Hancock requiring the child to be on the property 
  because of the attractiveness of the instrumentality causing injury.Â  Id.
A review of the 
  facts in the current case elucidates the contrariety of the two statements.Â  
  It is undisputed the children went to the canal property for a reason unrelated 
  to the canal itself and there were no signs warning of the dangers posed by 
  the water or effective fencing to prevent unsuspecting children from coming 
  into contact with it.Â  One of the boys testified that once on the property, 
  Terry saw the pipe bridge and wanted to walk across it.Â  He further maintained 
  that upon finding a cast net on the other side of the pipe bridge, Terry got 
  the idea to tie the rope from the net around his waist so he could enter the 
  water of the canal.
Under the first 
  explanation in Kirven, Terry would clearly meet the prerequisites for 
  maintaining an attractive nuisance action.Â  Explicably, the â€œinstrumentality 
  which caused the injury . . . actually attracted the child into danger.â€Â  Kirven, 
  253 S.C. at 117, 169 S.E.2d at 142.Â  Terry was attracted to the pipe bridge, 
  and it was the accessibility of this pipe bridge, coupled with the latent dangerousness 
  of the water in the canal, that created the danger.Â  Furthermore, there is no 
  evidence that Terry went into the dangerous situation, i.e., onto the pipe bridge 
  and into the water, â€œfor any other reasonâ€ than his attraction to the water.Â  
  
Alternatively, 
  if the second proposition is followed, the fact that Terry was attracted to 
  the dangerous condition has no consequence whatsoever even if IPC knew children 
  often frequented the property.Â  Once it is determined Terry and his friends 
  entered the property without the canal in mind, the analysis ends.Â  To follow 
  this position would undermine nearly every case decided to date in South Carolina.Â  
  It would emasculate the idea that the doctrine of attractive nuisance is one 
  â€œbased upon humanity and the wholesome maxim, â€˜Sic utere tuo ut alienum non 
  laedasâ€™ [(So use your own as to not injure anotherâ€™s property)].â€Â  Franks 
  v. S. Cotton Oil Co., 78 S.C. 10, 19, 58 S.E. 960, 963 (1907).
Therefore, I find 
  that the trial court erred in granting a directed verdict as to Terryâ€™s cause 
  of action for attractive nuisance.Â  The issue should have been submitted to 
  the jury.
Finally, IPC asserts 
  as an additional sustaining ground that, even if the trial court erred in not 
  sending the attractive nuisance cause of action to the jury, this error is harmless.Â  
  Specifically, IPC argues, â€œ[W]hile the Plaintiff may have lost the attractive 
  nuisance doctrine, she retained the similar unguarded condition cause of action.â€
Juxtaposition of the theories of 
  â€œattractive nuisanceâ€ and â€œunguarded conditionâ€ demonstrates with clarity the 
  dissimilarities of elements in each theory.Â  In contrariety to the argument 
  of IPC, there is no amalgamation of these theories in this case.Â  An academic 
  review of the law of attractive nuisance reveals a separate and distinct cognizable 
  theory of the common law with venerable origins.
Because it is axiomatic that a party 
  may bring as many causes of action as he or she may have, I find this argument 
  to be without merit.Â  See Rule 8, SCRCP (noting a party may state as 
  many separate causes of action as he has regardless of their consistency).
 
  CONCLUSION

Based 
  on an illogical and strait-jacket analysis, the majority engrafts on the doctrine 
  of attractive nuisance an exception: the child was not attracted 
  to the venue by the dangerous condition.Â  This ill-conceived notion and idea 
  ignores the reality of the case sub judice.Â  Incipiently, the 
  child visited the venue for â€œhill jumping purposesâ€ but was attracted to the 
  dangerous condition existing at the venue: â€œthe canal.â€
The factual duality of this case, 
  i.e., the initial non-attraction and the actual attraction to the dangerous 
  condition proves the necessity to recognize the position articulated by Â§ 339 
  of the Restatement (Second) of Torts (1965).
Relying upon Hancock v. Aiken 
  Mills, Inc., 180 S.C. 93, 185 S.E. 188 (1936), the majority eviscerates 
  the basic doctrine of attractive nuisance. Â The factual dissimilarities of Hancock 
  and the present case dissuade the Court from any precedential impact of Hancock.Â  
  Additionally, the actual holding in Hancock does not give 
  credence to the conclusion that the doctrine of attractive nuisance has no efficacy 
  if there is no initial attraction of the child to the dangerous condition.
An academic review of Hancock 
  leads to the ineluctable conclusion that a venue may be bifurcated in the originality 
  of the attraction and the attraction of an actual dangerous condition at the 
  same site.
The holding of the majority renders 
  the attractive nuisance doctrine impotent and non-utilitarian.Â  This result 
  is neither warranted nor desirable in South Carolina jurisprudence.
The most troubling and vexatious 
  aspect of the ruling of the majority is the failure to recognize the attraction 
  of the child to this dangerous condition existing on the property.Â  Several 
  children have already drowned in this canal; yet, the majority creates a legalistic 
  and protective barrier against the application of the doctrine of attractive 
  nuisance.
Accordingly, based on the foregoing, 
  I VOTE to AFFIRM IN PART, REVERSE IN PART, and REMAND for trial 
  disposition.

    [5]  See Nelson v. Concrete Supply Co., 303 S.C. 243,

    [9] On the issue 
    of "unguarded condition," the trial judge stated, "[I]n looking 
    at the evidence in the light most favorable to the non-moving party, it is 
    a jury issue for their determination and I'm speaking clearly [sic] on the 
    unguarded condition issue."

 
    [10]  Everett 
    v. White, 245 S.C. 331, 335, 140 S.E.2d 582, 584 (1965).
  
   
   [11] Id. at 335, 140 S.E.2d at 584.


 
    
    [12]  See 65A C.J.S. Negligence Â§ 507, at 240 (2000) (â€œAlso, 
    even though a thing or a condition may be both attractive and dangerous to 
    children, the attractive nuisance doctrine cannot apply to it unless it is 
    maintained or left in an unprotected or unguarded condition.â€).

 
    
    [13]  See, e.g., Daniels v. Timmons, 216 S.C. 539, 
    550-51, 59 S.E.2d 149, 155 (1950) Â (â€œAll of the  so-called attractive nuisance cases spring from negligence of the defendant 
    in regard to his or her own property which is subject to being entered upon 
    by a child who may be attracted onto the premises.â€); 65A C.J.S. Negligence 
    Â§ 494, at 220 (2000) (â€œThe attractive nuisance doctrine is merely a detailed 
    articulation of ordinary negligence, and under that doctrine, a trespassing 
    child is afforded the protection of ordinary negligence doctrine . . . .â€).

 
    
    [14]  In fact, counsel for Hunt agreed that principles of negligence 
    applied.Â  In discussing IPCâ€™s motion for a directed verdict, he agreed it 
    was â€œfor the jury to say under the circumstances was it reasonable what [IPC] 
    did and how they set it up and was the kid himself liable for it.â€

 
    
    [15]  See State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 
    S.E.2d 691, 694 (2003) (â€œNo point will be considered which is not set forth

    should not have addressed an issue not preserved for review.Â  The difference 
    between Hendrix and this case is that here the question of whether 
    the directed verdict issue is procedurally barred from appellate review is 
    not, like the one in Hendrix, a settled one.Â  Moreover, in this case, 
    the dissent addresses the merits of the issue of attractive nuisance; therefore, 
    under the circumstances and in the interest of judicial economy, we think 
    we should likewise do so.

    786, 789 (1981) Â (â€œFailure to contemporaneously object to [a] question now

    v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Highways and Transp., 314 S.C. 427, 429-30, 445 S.E.2d
