THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Palmetto Homes, Inc.,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Philip Bradley, Chad Summerall, B&S masonry, 
        Inc., Bradley and Summerall Masonry, Inc.,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Henry F. Floyd, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3717
Submitted September 8, 2003 â€“ Filed 
  December 23, 2003
Withdrawn, Substituted and Re-Filed 
  February 19, 2004

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
H. W. Pat Paschal, Jr., of Greenville, for Appellant.
John R. Devlin, Jr., Christopher R. Antley, both of Greenville, 
  for Respondents.
      
    
  


HOWARD, J.:Â  Palmetto Homes, Inc. (â€œContractorâ€) 
  sued Philip Bradley, Chad Summerall, B&S Masonry, Inc., Bradley and Summerall 
  Masonry, Inc. (collectively â€œSubcontractorâ€), asserting causes of action for 
  breach of contract, breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act, breach 
  of warranty, and negligence.Â  In response, Subcontractor pled a previously obtained 
  arbitration award as a bar to Contractorâ€™s causes of action, simultaneously 
  moving to confirm the arbitration award.Â  The circuit court confirmed the arbitration 
  award and entered judgment in favor of Subcontractor.Â  Contractor moved to vacate 
  the award and compel another arbitration, arguing it had not been provided notice 
  of the arbitration proceeding and thus had not appeared to defend it.Â  The circuit 
  court denied the motion to vacate the arbitration award, ruling Contractor had 
  been provided notice. Additionally, the court granted Subcontractorâ€™s motion 
  to dismiss Contractorâ€™s claims, ruling they were barred by res judicata.Â  Contractor 
  appeals.Â  We affirm as modified.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Contractor is a residential homebuilder.Â  Contractor entered into 
  a contract with Subcontractor, whereby Subcontractor agreed to provide the masonry 
  work on a residential homebuilding project.Â  The contract between the parties 
  provided for the arbitration of disputes with the American Arbitration Association 
  (â€œAAAâ€).Â  Specifically it read:

Arbitration: Should a dispute 
  arise between the contractor and sub-contractor as to any matter concerning 
  the within sub-contractor agreement and or any work performed, materials furnished 
  on payment made or requested for same, said dispute shall be resolved in accordance 
  with the rules and regulations of the American Arbitration Association.Â  

(emphasis as in original).Â  
Following Subcontractorâ€™s completion of 
  the masonry work, Contractor asserted there were defects in the masonry work 
  and refused to pay Subcontractor.Â  Subcontractor then filed a demand for arbitration 
  with the AAA, asserting a claim for a mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  Contractor never responded 
  to the demand for arbitration.Â  
After numerous notices were mailed and 
  faxed to Contractor by the AAA, the arbitration took place without the participation 
  of Contractor, and the arbitrator issued an award in favor of Subcontactor.  

Following the arbitration award, Contractor brought 
  this action asserting causes of action for breach of contract, breach of contract 
  accompanied by a fraudulent act, breach of warranty, and negligence.Â  
Subcontractor filed a Petition to Confirm Arbitration 
  Award, and the circuit court issued an order confirming the arbitration award 
  and entering judgment.Â  Contractor then filed and served a motion to vacate 
  the arbitration award and compel another arbitration of the dispute, arguing 
  Rule 4, South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, applied, and Contractor never 
  received proper notice of the arbitration proceedings.Â  Subcontractor then filed 
  and served its motion to dismiss Contractorâ€™s action on the grounds that res 
  judicata barred the suit.Â  
The circuit court denied Contractorâ€™s motion to 
  vacate, ruling numerous attempts were made to serve and provide notice of the 
  arbitration proceedings, but Contractor intentionally avoided service.Â  Additionally, 
  the circuit court granted Subcontractorâ€™s motion to dismiss Contractorâ€™s causes 
  of action on the grounds of res judicata.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Contractorâ€™s Motion to 
  Vacate the Arbitration Award
Contractor argues the circuit court erred by finding 
  Contractor received service of process because the service did not comply with 
  Rule 4, South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure. 
  [1] Â  We hold Palmetto received sufficient service of process and affirm 
  as modified.Â  
An appellate court may affirm the circuit courtâ€™s 
  ruling using any sustaining grounds that are both raised by the respondentâ€™s 
  brief and found within the record.Â  See Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. 
  Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 420, 526 S.E.2d 716, 723 (2000).
In the present case, the contract signed by the 
  parties specifically stated the rules and regulations of the AAA apply to the 
  arbitration.Â  Thus, we analyze whether service of process was effected pursuant 
  to the AAA rules.Â  See Dowling v. Home Buyers Warranty Corp. II, 
  311 S.C. 233, 236, 428 S.E.2d 709, 710 (1993) (holding an agreement to arbitrate 
  is a contract, and the parties are free to determine its terms); see also 
  Simmons v. Lucas & Stubbs Assocs., Ltd., 283 S.C. 326, 332-33, 322 
  S.E.2d 467, 470 (Ct. App. 1984) (holding arbitration is a matter of contract, 
  and the range of issues that can be arbitrated is restricted by the terms of 
  the agreement); Marolf Const. Inc. v. Allenâ€™s Paving Co., 572 S.E.2d 
  861, 863 (N.C. Ct. App. 2002) (holding parties may alter statutory service of 
  process rules through valid arbitration agreements).Â  
The AAA publication of the Construction Industry 
  Dispute Resolution Procedures (1999) contains Rule R-40, which states:Â  

Each party shall be deemed to have consented that any papers, 
  notices, or process necessary or proper for the initiation or continuation of 
  an arbitration under these rules; for any court action in connection therewith; 
  or for the entry of judgment on any award made under these rules, may be served 
  on a party by mail addressed to the party or its representative at the last 
  known address or by personal service.

Additionally, the rule provides for the following methods 
  of service:Â  â€œThe AAA, the parties, and the arbitrator may also use overnight 
  delivery, electronic facsimile (fax), telex, and telegram.â€Â  Rule R-40.
The record indicates Subcontractor utilized regular 
  mail as provided by the AAA rules for the service of the demand for arbitration.Â  
  Subsequent notices sent by the AAA were sent by certified mail, regular mail, 
  and facsimile.Â  Sometimes the same notice was sent by more than one method.Â  

The record also indicates the facsimiles were transmitted 
  properly.Â  Additionally, there is no evidence the regular mail was returned 
  as undeliverable or for any other reason.Â  The certified mail was returned. 
  However, it was returned because its acceptance was refused or it went unclaimed. 
   [2] Â  
Given the facts of this case, we hold service of 
  process was effected pursuant to the AAA rules. 
  [3] Â  Thus, Contractor received proper service of process. 
  [4] 
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Subcontractorâ€™s 
  Motion to Dismiss
Contractor argues the circuit court erred by granting 
  Subcontractorâ€™s motion to dismiss, ruling Contractorâ€™s causes of action for 
  breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act and negligence were barred 
  by principles of res judicata.Â  We disagree.
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Scope of the Arbitration Agreement
As a threshold matter, Contractor contends its 
  causes of action for breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act and 
  negligence are not within the scope of the arbitration agreement, and thus, 
  the arbitration award cannot bar the claims. 
  [5] Â  
South Carolina law favors arbitration 
  of disputes.Â  Tritech Elec., Inc. v. Frank M. Hall & Co., 343 S.C. 
  396, 399, 540 S.E.2d 864, 865 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Arbitration is a matter of contract, 
  and the range of issues that can be arbitrated is restricted by the terms of 
  the agreement.Â  Simmons, 283 S.C. at 332-33, 322 S.E.2d at 470.Â  
â€œTo decide whether an arbitration agreement 
  encompasses a dispute, a court must determine whether the factual allegations 
  underlying the claim are within the scope of the broad arbitrationÂ  clause . 
  . . . [U]nless the court can say with positive assurance the arbitrationÂ  clause 
  . . . [does] not cover[] the dispute, arbitration should be ordered.â€Â  South 
  Carolina Pub. Serv. Auth. v. Great W. Coal (Kentucky), Inc., 312 S.C. 559, 
  563, 437 S.E.2d 22, 25 (1993).
The arbitration agreement states, â€œany 
  matter concerning the within sub-contractor agreement and or any work performedâ€ 
  will be subject to arbitration.Â  (emphasis as in original).Â  
The partiesâ€™ agreement provided Subcontractor 
  would perform masonry work for Contractorâ€™s homebuilding project.Â  Contractorâ€™s 
  causes of action for breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act and 
  negligence essentially allege Subcontractor defectively installed the masonry 
  work on a residential homebuilding project. 
  [6] Â Â Â  These claims are matters concerning the agreement or the work performed.Â  
  Therefore, the claims are within the scope of the arbitration agreement.Â  See 
  Zabinski v. Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 597-98, 553 S.E.2d 110, 
  119 (2001) (holding where the partnership agreement provided all claims arising 
  from the partnership agreement were to be arbitrated, any torts related to the 
  partnership agreement were also matters for arbitration); Long v. Silver, 
  248 F.3d 309, 316 (4th Cir. 2001) (holding claims are within the scope of the 
  arbitration clause if a â€œsignificant relationshipâ€ exists between the asserted 
  claims and the contract in which the arbitration clause is contained).
B.Â Â Â Â Â  The Doctrine of Res Judiciata
Contractor next argues the circuit court erred 
  by ruling res judicata bars his claims for breach of contract accompanied by 
  a fraudulent act and negligence.Â  We disagree.
â€œUnder the doctrine of res judicata, 
  â€˜[a] litigant is barred from raising any issues which were adjudicated in the 
  former suit and any issues which might have been raised in the former suit.â€™â€Â  
  Plum Creek Dev. Co., Inc. v. City of Conway, 334 S.C. 30, 34, 512 S.E.2d 
  106, 109 (1999) (quoting Hilton Head Ctr. of South Carolina, Inc. v. Pub. 
  Serv. Commâ€™n of South Carolina, 294 S.C. 9, 11, 362 S.E.2d 176, 177 (1987)).Â  
  â€œThe doctrine requires three essential elements:Â  (1) the judgment must be final, 
  valid and on the merits; (2) the parties in the subsequent action must be identical 
  to those in the first; and (3) the second action must involve matter properly 
  included in the first action.â€Â  Town of Sullivanâ€™s Island v. Felger, 
  318 S.C. 340, 344, 457 S.E.2d 626, 628 (Ct. App. 1995).Â Â  
Intially, we note, an arbitration award is a final, 
  binding award on the merits.Â  See Pittman Mortg. Co. v. Edwards, 
  327 S.C. 72, 76, 488 S.E.2d 335, 337 (1997) (â€œGenerally, an arbitration award 
  is conclusive and courts will refuse to review the merits of an award.â€); Trident 
  Technical Coll. v. Lucas & Stubbs, Ltd., 286 S.C. 98, 111, 333 S.E.2d 
  781, 788-89 (1985) (holding an arbitration award is meant to signify the end, 
  not the commencement, of litigation; thus, arbitration awards are presumptively 
  correct).Â  Furthermore, it is uncontested the parties in the first arbitration 
  proceeding are the same parties in this litigation.Â  Thus, we need only determine 
  if the causes of action for breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act 
  and negligence involved matter properly included in the first action.
Contractor, by its own admission, began discovering 
  defects in the brick work in the fall of 2000.Â  It was subsequently served process 
  of the arbitration proceedings over the course of several months beginning in 
  December of 2000, and the arbitration award was granted in April 2001.Â  Contractor 
  did not participate in the proceedings, and thus, it did not present any of 
  its claims to the arbitrators.Â  
Contractorâ€™s failure to participate in the proceedings 
  did not preclude its claims from being submitted to the arbitration proceeding.Â  
  Rather, pursuant to the contract, all claims arising from the agreement were 
  to be submitted to arbitration.Â  see District of Columbia v. Bailey, 
  171 U.S. 161, 171 (1898) (holding a submission is an agreement between two or 
  more parties to refer a dispute to a third party and be bound by the third partiesâ€™ 
  decision); H.S. Cramer & Co. v. Washburnwilson Seed Co., 195 P.2d 
  346, 349 (Idaho 1948); 4 Am. Jur. 2d Alternative Dispute Resolution Â§ 
  85 (1995) (stating a matter is submitted to arbitration when â€œtwo or more parties 
  agree to settle their respective legal rights and duties by referring the disputed 
  matters to a third party . . .â€); Id. Â§ 88 (holding an agreement to arbitrate 
  all issues arising from a contract submits all issues within the scope of the 
  contract to the arbitrators).Â  
As previously noted, Contractorâ€™s claims arose from 
  the Subcontractor agreement, and thus, its claims were within the scope of arbitration.Â  
  Therefore, when the arbitration proceedings began, all claims arising from the 
  contract were submitted to the arbitration proceeding, and, as with civil litigation, 
  Contractor was procedurally required to arbitrate all claims arising therefrom 
  or be barred by res judicata.Â  See 4 Am. Jur. 2d Alternative Dispute 
  Resolution Â§ 214 (1995) (â€œThe award of the arbitrators acting within the 
  scope of their authority determines the rights of the parties as effectually 
  as a judgment secured by regular legal procedure . . . . [Thus,] [i]f otherwise 
  sufficient, an arbitration award is conclusive and binding . . . as to all matters 
  submitted to the arbitrators, even though one of the parties neglects to present 
  portions of his claim.â€) (emphasis added); see Rodgers Builders, 
  Inc. v. McQueen, 331 S.E.2d 726, 730 (N.C. Ct. App. 1985) (holding res judicata 
  applies to bar arbitration of claims actually arbitrated, as well as claims 
  that could have been arbitrated in the prior proceeding); Lee L. Saad Construc. 
  Co. v. DPF Architects, P.C., 851 So.2d 507, 517-18 (Ala. 2002) (holding 
  an arbitratorâ€™s award is res judicata as to a subsequent claim if the original 
  claim was within the scope of the arbitration agreement and all of the other 
  elements of res judicata are met); Springs Cotton Mills v. Buster Boy Suit 
  Co., 275 A.D. 196, 199-200 (N.Y. App. Div. 1949) (holding an arbitratorâ€™s 
  award is res judicata as to all matters reasonably submitted, and thus, where 
  one party does not participate in the arbitration proceedings, its claims, if 
  they otherwise meet the elements of res judicata, will be barred); Hurley 
  v. Fox, 587 So.2d 1 (La. Ct. App. 1991).
Notwithstanding the traditional res judicata analysis, 
  Contractor argues, in an arbitration setting, res judicata only bars claims 
  that were actually arbitrated, not claims that merely could have been arbitrated.Â  
  In that regard, Contractor predicates its contention on Renaissance Enterprises, 
  Inc. v. Ocean Resorts, Inc., 330 S.C. 13, 496 S.E.2d 858 (1998).
In Renaissance, our Supreme Court stated 
  in a footnote:

Res judicata can only apply to those matters included within 
  the submission agreement.Â  4 Am. Jur. 2d Alternative Dispute Resolution Â§ 
  214 (1995) (arbitrator is limited to decide only those issues submitted 
  by the parties and res judicata may bar only issues submitted).Â  The issue of 
  . . . [plaintiffâ€™s] right to future fees was not submitted for arbitration in 
  the prior proceeding.Â Â Â Â Â  Therefore, . . . [plaintiff] is not precluded from 
  raising this issue once it becomes entitled to the fees . . . .

Id. at 17, 496 S.E.2d at 860.Â  Contractor 
  contends this passage establishes that res judicata only applies to issues actually 
  litigated in an arbitration proceeding and not to issues that could have been 
  litigated.Â  We do not read Renaissance so broadly.
In Renaissance, the plaintiff arbitrated 
  its disputes against the defendant for breaches of the contract that occurred 
  prior to the arbitration.Â  The arbitrator then issued an award encompassing 
  the breaches occurring prior to the arbitration but did not rule the contract 
  was rescinded.Â  Subsequently, the plaintiff brought another action against Defendant 
  to recover damages for the breaches of contract occurring after the original 
  arbitration award.Â  In response, the Defendant moved for summary judgment, claiming 
  res judicata barred the action because the prior arbitration award terminated 
  the contract.Â  The circuit court dismissed the action, ruling the arbitration 
  award terminated the contract.Â  
On appeal, this Court reversed and remanded, ruling 
  further inquiry into the facts and circumstances surrounding the arbitration 
  award was necessary to clarify the application of the law, and thus, summary 
  judgment was inappropriate.Â  On writ of certiorari, our supreme court vacated 
  this Court, ruling the issue was not properly preserved at the trial level.Â  

Reading Renaissance as a whole, we believe 
  the supreme courtâ€™s footnote merely reflected that the plaintiff could not have 
  been required to submit issues, or arbitrate breaches of contract, that had 
  not yet occurred.Â  In the present case, Contractorâ€™s claims existed at the time 
  of the original arbitration and thus could have been arbitrated in the original 
  proceeding.Â  Consequently, Renaissance is inapposite.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the 
  circuit court is 
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
STILWELL and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

    [2]  As an ancillary argument, Contractor contends the circuit court erred 
    by ruling Contractor received service of process pursuant to Patel v. Southern 
    Brokerâ€™s Ltd., 277 S.C. 490, 493-95, 289 S.E.2d 642, 644-45 (1982) (holding 
    a defendant cannot avoid process of the court by intentionally avoiding service).Â

    Contractor argues this Court erred by considering the AAA rules because the

    South Carolina Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 327 S.C. 220, 223, 489 S.E.2d 467, 469

    [4] Contractor also argues the circuit court

    [5]  Contractorâ€™s Summons and Complaint stated causes of action for breach 
    of contract, breach of contract accompanied by a fraudulent act, breach of 
    warranty, and negligence.Â  The circuit court dismissed all of Contractorâ€™s 
    claims, ruling the causes of action were barred by res judicata.Â  Contractor 
    has only appealed the dismissal of its causes of action for breach of contract 
    accompanied by a fraudulent act and negligence.Â  Therefore, the dismissal

   [6]  Contractorâ€™s cause of action for breach of contract 
    accompanied by a fraudulent act alleges:
  
  [Subcontractor] did commit 
    an act of fraud by installing the brick veneer and other brick masonry products 
    on a dwelling without adequate code required wall ties, by using and installing

description: The court of appeals found that the offense of tampering with a motor vehicle, prohibited by SC Code Ann. Sec. 16-21-90 (Supp. 2003) is not a lesser-included offense of breaking into a motor vehicle, which is prohibited by SC Code Ann. Sec. 16-21-90 (Supp. 2003).
text:
State v. Arthur (12122)


STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        The State, Respondent, 
        
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Darryl Arthur, Appellant. 
        
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland 
  County
  Â Clifton Newman, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 3746
  Submitted January 12, 2004 
  â€“ Filed February 23, 2004

  AFFIRMED


 
   
     
      
        Chief Attorney Daniel T. 
          Stacey, of the Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan 
          McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant 
          Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, Assistant Attorney General 
          David A. Spencer; and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, all of Columbia, 
          for Respondent.
      
    
  


KITTREDGE, J.:Â  This appeal 
  presents the question of whether the offense of tampering with a motor vehicle 
  [1]  (auto-tampering) is a lesser- included offense of breaking into a motor 
  vehicle [2]  (auto-breaking).Â  
  We hold it is not and affirm Darryl Arthurâ€™s convictions and sentence.
FACTS 

Arthur broke into the vehicle of 
  Michael Hendrix, a lieutenant with the City of Columbia Police Department, while 
  the vehicle was in the parking lot of the Departmentâ€™s North Region Headquarters.Â  
  Arthur gained entry by breaking into the driverâ€™s side rear window.Â  A pair 
  of night vision binoculars was discovered missing from the vehicle.Â  In the 
  rear of the vehicle was a fishing rod with a lure, known as â€œtorpedo plug,â€ 
  attached.Â  While in the vehicle, it appears Arthur caught his hand in the fishing 
  lure because blood was found in the vehicle.Â  Â Â 
The crime was quickly discovered 
  and a police radio dispatch was given, alerting officers of the incident.Â  Officer 
  Allen Barber, who was in the area of the police department parking lot, heard 
  the radio broadcast and observed Arthur walking away from the parking lot.Â  
  As Officer Barber circled the area, he observed Arthur in the area of nearby 
  apartments.Â Â  Arthur was observed leaning into a vehicleâ€™s passenger side window.Â  
  When Officer Barber approached, the vehicle â€œpulled off.â€Â  Arthur â€œput his hands 
  up,â€ revealing blood on his hands.Â  Arthur then fled, and a foot pursuit ensued.Â  
  Arthur was eventually apprehended and, following a struggle, placed in custody.Â  
  Arthurâ€™s DNA matched the blood found in the vehicle near the fishing lure.Â  
  The night vision binoculars were not recovered.
Arthur was convicted of breaking 
  into a motor vehicle, for which he was sentenced to prison for five years, and 
  resisting arrest, for which he received a consecutive sentence of one year imprisonment.Â  
  Arthur was found not guilty of larceny.Â  Â Â Â 
Regarding the charge of auto-breaking, 
  Arthur requested the trial court charge the jury on the offense of auto-tampering.Â  
  Arthur asserted the State had not proven the item stolen from the vehicle was 
  connected to Arthur.Â Â  The trial court denied Arthurâ€™s request.Â  Arthur appeals.Â Â Â  
  
LAW/ANALYSIS 

Arthur argues the trial court erred 
  in failing to give a jury charge on the purported lesser-included offense of 
  auto-tampering.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe test for determining if a crime 
  is a lesser included offense is whether the greater of the two offenses includes 
  all the elements of the lesser offense.â€Â  State v. McFadden, 342 S.C. 
  629, 632, 539 S.E.2d 387, 389 (2000) (citing Knox v. State, 340 S.C. 
  81, 530 S.E.2d 887 (2000); Carter v. State, 329 S.C. 355, 495 S.E.2d 
  773 (1998); Hope v. State, 328 S.C. 78, 492 S.E.2d 76 (1997); Browning 
  v. State, 320 S.C. 366, 465 S.E.2d 358 (1995); State v. Bland, 318 
  S.C. 315, 457 S.E.2d 611 (1995)).Â  We find the offense of auto-breaking does 
  not contain all the elements of auto-tampering.Â  Accordingly, we conclude auto-tampering 
  is not a lesser-included offense of auto-breaking.Â  
Section 16-13-160 concerns the felony 
  offense of auto-breaking:

  (A) It is unlawful for a person 
    to:
  (1) break or attempt to 
    break into a motor vehicle or its compartment with the intent to steal 
    it or anything of value from it, or attached or annexed to it, or used 
    in connection with it or in the perpetration of any criminal offense

.Â  .Â  . 
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-13-160 (2003) 
  (emphasis added).Â  
Section 16-21-90, in contrast, concerns 
  the separate offense of auto- tampering:

  A person who, with intent and without 
    right to do so, damages a vehicle or damages or removes any of its parts or 
    components is guilty of a misdemeanor.
  A person who, without right to 
    do so and with intent to commit a crime, tampers with a vehicle or goes in 
    or on it or works or attempts to work any of its parts or components or sets 
    or attempts to set it in motion is guilty of a misdemeanor.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-21-90 (2003).
To satisfy the first paragraph of 
  the auto-tampering statute, one must either intentionally damage a vehicle or 
  intentionally damage or remove vehicle parts.Â  The auto-breaking statute, however, 
  contains neither damage nor removal elements.Â  The essence of the auto-breaking 
  offense is the breaking into, or the attempt to break into, a vehicle with the 
  intent to steal it or anything of value from it.Â  As such, the conduct described 
  in the first paragraph of the auto-tampering statute cannot be considered a 
  lesser- included offense of auto-breaking.
The second paragraph of the auto-tampering 
  statute lists four additional means by which an individual can violate the statute:Â  
  (1) tampering with the vehicle; (2) going in or on the vehicle; (3) working 
  or attempting to work any of the vehicleâ€™s parts or components; and (4) setting 
  or attempting to set the vehicle in motion.Â  Similar to our findings regarding 
  the first paragraph of section 16-21-90, we find the offense of auto-breaking 
  does not include any of these four types of conduct.Â  While it logically follows 
  that auto-tampering includes the intentional tampering with a vehicle, auto-breaking 
  does not include mere tampering.Â  Moreover, auto-breaking embraces an attempt, 
  while the auto-tampering statute reaches only completed acts.Â  Next, auto-tampering 
  could include an element of â€œgoing in or onâ€ the vehicle.Â  Such element does 
  not exist in auto-breaking, as one need not actually touch the vehicle to be 
  convicted of that crime.Â  Similarly, the â€œworkingâ€ or attempting to work any 
  of the vehicleâ€™s components is not contained in auto breaking, and one need 
  not work components in order to break into a vehicle.Â  Auto-breaking could involve 
  a vehicleâ€™s component parts, but only in the context of stealing, or attempting 
  to steal, â€œanything . . . attached or annexed toâ€ the vehicle.Â  S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 16-13-160.Â  Finally, auto-tampering also could include the act of setting 
  or attempting to set the vehicle in motion.Â  Such conduct clearly does not fall 
  under the â€œbreak or attempt to break intoâ€ language of the auto-breaking statute.Â  
  Therefore, the four modes of conduct described in the second paragraph of section 
  16-21-90 cannot be properly considered as lesser-included offenses of section 
  16-13-160.Â Â  
CONCLUSION 

Auto-tampering is not a lesser-included 
  offense of auto-breaking.Â  The trial court properly refused to charge the auto-tampering 
  statute.Â  Arthurâ€™s convictions and sentences are 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J. and HOWARD, J., concur.Â

    [2]  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-13-160 (Supp. 2003)
